SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) is not present to hear the debate on this Bill—I can understand that he probably thought another Bill was coming on first. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation Amendment Bill 1992 [1993] seeks to amend the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983.

PARA.TAB: This Bill contains two major proposed amendments. The first is designed to introduce more stringent accountability requirements for the commercial activities of the ABC. The coalition believes that these amendments should be welcomed as they reduce the prospect of risk to the taxpayer. However, the second major proposed amendment regarding the ABC's access to transmitters is of considerable concern to the Opposition.

The current Act states that the Minister for Communications shall hand over all transmitters free of charge to the ABC. These transmitters are currently owned by the Commonwealth but are made available to the ABC through the newly created government agency, the National Transmission Agency. Prior to the creation of the NTA, the department itself owned and operated the transmitters.

For reasons perhaps best known to the Minister and his department, despite the clear statement in the ABC Act 1983, none of the approximately 1,000 radio and television transmitters has ever been transferred to the ABC. Therefore, the ABC relies on a third party, another government agency, for access to the one service it cannot do without—its transmission.

The ownership and control of transmitters is not an incidental point. It would be like Telecom without phones or the air force without planes. To say that the ABC is nothing without access to transmitters is not an exaggeration. The transmitters are absolutely vital—without them there would be no ABC television and no ABC radio. The ABC could spend billions of dollars a year on making programs, but without the ability to transmit them it would be a wasted effort.

Of course, the public do not understand that the ABC does not control its own transmissions. When ABC radio goes off the air or snow appears on people's TV screen when they are watching the news, they do not ring up the Department of Transport and Communications or the NTA; they ring up the ABC. Outside cities people ring their local ABC regional radio station to complain about TV—not that ABC radio staff know the first thing about TV reception. Why should they? I am sure that those staff do a sterling job trying to explain that it is not the ABC's fault, but I am also sure that many people think they are being fobbed off. After all, who would be responsible for the transmission of ABC programs if not the ABC?

If the ABC owned and ran its own transmitters as envisaged by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983, then many problems that the ABC currently experiences could be overcome. Firstly, the ABC could balance its total resources. If the ABC could make savings in the area of transmissions, which it believes it could, that money could be used elsewhere. Secondly, following a government decision to extend Triple J, for instance, to 42 regional areas across Australia, as was announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) during the election campaign, the ABC itself could decide the timetable, rather than waiting for the NTA which might have different priorities. Thirdly, the ABC would be entirely responsible for the transmission of its own programs and, if a problem occurred with transmission, the ABC itself would be able to fix the problem, or at least relay directly to its audience just what the problem is.

The result would no doubt be fewer problems fixed more quickly. Honourable senators might ask why, and the answer really is that ABC managers and employees, in taking pride in their work and dealing directly with the public, would have the incentive to make sure the ABC was off air as little as possible.

I would have thought that the Government would have agreed to such a concept—that increased productivity comes from employees who have a sense of purpose, who are linked to their end product and who care about their service level and reputation. That is why the commercial stations own their own transmitters and why major overseas public broadcasters, like the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and the BBC, own their own transmitters. I do not wish to imply for one second that the staff of the NTA are not highly qualified and that their technical expertise is not appreciated, but that is not the point. If the ABC is off the air, it is the ABC's reputation that is on the line, not the NTA's.

In addition, transferring ownership of transmitters to the ABC could put an end to what I believe is a regular occurrence at Senate estimates committee hearings where senators regularly ask ABC representatives why this network or that network has been delayed, why there is not Triple J in certain areas or why people living in another place have such bad reception for ABC television. But the ABC cannot answer these questions simply because transmission is not its responsibility. The existing arrangement has long been held to be unsatisfactory. For all the reasons I have outlined, the 1983 ABC Act, in section 75 paragraph (3), provided:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister shall cause all transmitters that are provided by the Commonwealth for use in connection with the performance of the functions of the Corporation to be transferred, without charge to the Corporation, to the ownership of the Corporation.

However, clauses 12 and 13 of this Bill that is now before us seek to repeal the whole of part VII of the Act, which includes the section regarding transferring ownership of the transmitters to the ABC. In its place, this would be substituted by paragraph 76 and 77. The coalition is particularly concerned about paragraphs (1) and (3) of section 76. The amendments contained in clauses 12 and 13 of the Bill result from the decision last year by the Government to establish the National Transmission Agency to manage the Government's multipurpose transmission facilities.

PARA.TAB: The Minister, in his second reading speech, stated that in view of the establishment of the NTA, the Act would be amended to remove the provision for the Minister to transfer technical equipment and land relating to the transmitting stations used for the purpose of broadcasting ABC programs to the public. As a consequence, paragraph (1) of the new section 76 provides only that the Minister may arrange for the provision and operation of transmission facilities for the purposes of broadcasting programs of the corporation.

This is not an amendment to the Act which provides that the Minister may transfer ownership of the transmitters without charge; it is not even an amendment which provides the Minister may transfer ownership at all. The amendment would give the Minister the power to decide whether the ABC may have access to transmission facilities. The amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister may arrange for the provision and operation of the transmission facilities.

I do not believe that if this amendment went through the Minister would suddenly decide that he may not arrange for the ABC to have access to the transmitters, but that is not the point. If this amendment were to go through, a future Minister could decide not to give the ABC access to transmitters. The coalition does not believe that a Government Minister should have that power, a power which potentially threatens the independence of the ABC.

PARA.TAB: The ABC should not operate in the knowledge or under any threat that its access to transmitters which it does not own is at the discretion of the Minister of the day. Paragraph (3) of section 76 of the amendment Bill provides:

SPEECH.PARA: If the Minister so arranges under this section, he or she may stipulate what charges, if any, are to be paid by the Corporation in respect of the provision and operation of those facilities.

According to the Minister's second reading speech, a review will be held later this year in which it will be decided whether the National Transmission Agency will become a government business enterprise, in which case the NTA would operate as a separate cost centre and the Minister would be able to direct that the ABC be charged for the use of its transmission facilities. In the event of the ABC being required to pay, it would be provided with an additional appropriation. This would result in a greater transparency in the system, but again there are implications arising from this which could impact on the independence of the ABC.

PARA.TAB: The ABC is the NTA's major client. In fact, it forms 85 per cent of the NTA's client base. If the NTA did become a government business enterprise, what sort of pressure would it be under to seek additional clients from the private sector? Could this impinge on its responsibilities to our national broadcaster? Would the NTA make decisions in favour of private sector clients over the ABC? I am not suggesting that this will happen, but there are serious questions that need to be addressed when the matter is discussed later this year.

The coalition believes that it is desirable that the ABC's transmission facilities be placed on a commercial footing, but clauses 12 and 13 of this Bill before us unnecessarily threaten the ABC's guaranteed access to transmission facilities. Therefore, these clauses should be opposed.

The ABC, like commercial radio and television stations across Australia, should own its own transmitters, not only because it makes good business sense to reduce bureaucracy and not to create it, but also because it is commonsense that transmitting is an integral part of the ABC's product. Moreover, we must protect the independence of the ABC.

The Minister of the day, whoever he or she may be, should not have the power to decide whether he or she may provide the ABC with access to transmitters. The ABC must be able to work with any government and any Minister without fear or favour. For all of these reasons, the coalition will be seeking to omit clauses 12 and 13 of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Amendment Bill 1992 [1993].

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Broadcasting Corporation Amendment Bill 1992 [1993] does not present any real difficulties, except, as Senator Ferguson has said, in relation to the insertion of clause 12 and clause 13, regarding transmitters, and the amendment of section 25 of the Act, which allows the ABC to provide its own transmitters, including the purchase of satellite transponders and earth stations. The Australian Democrats are happy to support the amendments to section 25, which will expedite the involvement of the ABC in pay TV, if we ever come to it.

PARA.TAB: The insertion of clauses 12 and clause 13, however, is not something we are prepared to support. Under the present legislation, the Minister has an obligation to give control of transmitters to the ABC at some stage and at no charge. The Government has not hitherto acted to fulfil this obligation. The claim that it is imperative to remove this obligation now, because it is immediately required to act, seems a little spurious, especially at this stage.

The Government also claims that the purpose of these amendments is to prevent the pre-emption of the National Transmission Agency's 18-month review. Its proposed amendments do pre-empt the review by allowing the Government to renege on its legislated promise to the ABC and to hand the transmitters over to the NTA. These amendments pre-empt any recommendations that the review might make by effectively ensuring that the NTA will be formally enshrined as an autonomous government business enterprise with the possession of the transmitters. The ABC, the SBS and others would then be forced to seek commercial contracts for transmitter use, with no firm commitment from the Government to provide them with extra funding to meet those additional costs.

The Democrats believe that, if the Government was seriously trying to avoid pre-empting the NTA review, the Senate would not be wasting its time on any amendments pertaining to transmitters until that review is tabled later this year. In any case, it is almost certain that the Parliament will be faced with further amendments after the review. The appropriate time to deal with consequential changes to the ABC Act, if they are required, would be after that review, not now. The Democrats will therefore not be supporting clauses 12 and 13, but will be supporting Senator Ferguson's very sensible amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: (Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to the Senate for not being here from the start of the debate. I was caught short by the efficiency of the Senate business this morning. After the Senate's performance over the past two weeks, I thought we would be lucky if the second reading debate was resumed by midnight. I apologise particularly to Senator Ferguson, who has already spoken in this second reading debate.

PARA.TAB: In speaking on behalf of the Government, I am pleased to note that, apart from a couple of clauses that relate to one issue, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Amendment Bill 1992 [1993] is being accepted by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. I would like to make a couple of points about the issues raised by Senator Ferguson and Senator Bourne. First of all, I can count as well as anybody, and the Democrats and the Opposition combined have the numbers to carry the amendment. I want to put on the record the Government's view about the issues they raised with regard to the amendment.

In 1991, after a review process involving extensive consultation with all stakeholders, the Government decided to establish the National Transmission Agency, NTA, as a separate body to provide, operate and maintain the Commonwealth's network of transmission facilities. The Government decided that this was the best means of ensuring the effective delivery of all national broadcasting services, not only ABC services but also SBS television and radio services and parliamentary broadcasting services.

The NTA was established under an administrative arrangement as a separate cost centre within the Department of Transport and Communications to operate on a more commercial basis, using accrual accounting to fully disclose the costs of operation of the transmission network, with commercially oriented performance targets under a resource agreement negotiated with the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis)—I must say that it is no mean feat to achieve that outcome with the ministry of finance—and with obligations to tender work for the transmission system to a number of service providers, not just Telecom as in the past. These arrangements were established on an interim basis for 18 months and were designed to achieve greater economy and efficiency of service delivery, together with better information on costs of operating the transmission system.

At the end of the trial period the Government will review whether the NTA should be converted to a government business enterprise. The ABC amendment Bill before us would amend the Broadcasting Act 1983 to remove the obligation for the Minister to transfer to the ABC transmitters used for the purpose of broadcasting ABC programs to the public, which is an important element of the Commonwealth's transmission facilities.

Why do we want to amend the Act now? The existing provision is inconsistent with current Government policy and longstanding administrative arrangements. This anomaly was noted in Auditor-General's report No. 22 of 1989-90 on national broadcasting transmission facilities which recommended that arrangements for the ownership of, and the funding of costs associated with, the ABC and SBS transmission facilities be clarified and that future arrangements be consistent with all the relevant legislative provisions.

The Government subsequently considered the arrangements and agreed to establish the NTA and to amend the legislation to align with its policy and actual practice. I would emphasise that the amendment does not pre-empt any future decision about ownership of the transmitters. Under the terms of the amendment the transmitters could continue to be operated by the NTA or, alternatively, the national broadcasters could be funded to arrange their own transmitting facilities. The Bill specifically enables the ABC to own and operate transmission facilities if the Government provides it with funds for that purpose.

To remain with the current legislative provisions would be inconsistent with arrangements approved by Parliament in 1991 for the SBS in the Special Broadcasting Service Act 1991. The SBS has not made any criticisms of these arrangements.

Transfer of transmitters to the ABC in isolation from other transmission facilities would result in a split responsibility for transmission infrastructure. To transfer all transmission facilities to the ABC would not take account of the reality that these facilities are also used for the broadcast of SBS and the parliamentary service, as well as commercial and community broadcasters and radio communications operators.

Finally, will the NTA review consider transfer of ownership to the ABC? Senator Ferguson and Senator Bourne specifically raised this issue in their remarks. The Government has decided that, within 18 months after the set-up of the National Transmission Agency, the situation should be reviewed to establish whether the National Transmission Agency should become a government business enterprise. The review will also consider whether funds should be transferred to the ABC and SBS to pay for transmission services. If the Government concludes that it is not appropriate to establish the NTA as a GBE, it will consider alternative arrangements.

That is the background for the Government's view about the transmission facilities with the NTA. I think it is quite a reasonable proposal. It certainly does not close off the option, which I know the ABC management has been concerned about, of the facilities being transferred to the ABC. I must point out to the Senate that the facilities are not used purely for the ABC; those facilities are also used for the SBS and other bits and pieces. In the end I do not think that some of those other users would automatically welcome having the ABC run their transmission facilities. We would then be back here arguing whether there should be further amendments to split those transmission facilities off to the SBS or to the other users.

In my view, I do not think the Senate should be greatly concerned that there is a hidden agenda. Maybe the criticism could be that for a long time it has been in the Act that the facilities would be transferred to the ABC. Those opposite may say that the Government has hastened very slowly to reach that outcome. I know that is the view of ABC management.

I ask the Senate to consider that the Government is very open about this process and that there is no hidden agenda. My personal view—and I have had some interest in broadcasting matters for a long time—is that there is a good case for the ABC to have control of its own transmission facilities and the same principle to apply to SBS. Each should take responsibility for those facilities. It is not a one way street.

If an organisation is running the transmission facilities then it will need to manage them efficiently. It cannot whinge and whine and if something goes wrong somebody will bail it out. It could be argued that the ABC and the SBS in running their own transmission facilities need the discipline to run those facilities and if they get it wrong they have to take the consequences. I understand that argument.

I believe that the review which is under way at the moment and will continue for another 18 months will not unduly cripple the ABC, the SBS or the other operators. I think it will give us an opportunity to make a more considered decision. I put that view in closing the debate on the second reading, and I ask the Senate to consider the view that the Government has no hidden agenda and it is not an unreasonable proposition that we are putting.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL HEALTH AMENDMENT BILL 1993HEALTH INSURANCE COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 6 May, on motion by Senator Crowley:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address two important Bills before the Senate—the National Health Amendment Bill 1993 and the Health Insurance Commission Amendment Bill 1993. My colleague Senator Patterson will be speaking at some length on the National Health Amendment Bill, which the coalition will not be opposing. I should point out that it is largely due to the work of Senator Patterson and Senator Walters that this Bill appears before us today. On behalf of the coalition, they have been pursuing the Government on the issue of the retention, retrieval and destruction of personalised information held by the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services and the Health Insurance Commission since 1989.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Patterson discovered, the Government had no policy on this issue. While the Health Insurance Commission does now have a policy of deleting files after a period of five years, it is still not being applied in practice. It seems that this policy will finally be put into practical effect in July.

In amendments to the National Health Act in June 1991, the Privacy Commissioner was required to provide guidelines for the conduct of the Medicare and pharmaceutical benefits programs. Guidelines had been prepared prior to the Government being forced to drop its plans for a new computer link between the Health Insurance Commission and pharmacists to check on eligibility for pharmaceutical benefits. Following this backdown, new draft guidelines were prepared in February 1992.

However, rather than presenting these guidelines to Parliament, the Privacy Commissioner made a report to Parliament indicating that he had decided not to issue guidelines by 1 April 1992 as required. The concern of the Privacy Commissioner, based largely on the advice of the Office of General Counsel, was that the guidelines would not be valid under the provisions of the Act. In particular, the Privacy Commissioner suggested that if his guidelines were to be tabled, the Parliament ought to clarify its intention with respect to three issues: firstly, the limited re-identification of claims information after five years; secondly, that the guidelines should apply only to patient claims information; and thirdly, that the guidelines apply to claims information collected before their introduction.

In essence, this Bill amends the National Health Act so that Parliament's intentions are clear on each of these three issues, thus allowing the Privacy Commissioner to issue his guidelines. As I said earlier, the coalition is not opposing the Bill. Senator Patterson will be addressing the Bill in greater detail in her speech.

I wish to turn now from a Bill that sets out to strengthen privacy provisions to one that represents a potentially important step in the violation of the privacy of a great many Australians. I refer to the Health Insurance Commission Amendment Bill 1993. The Bill itself would seem quite straightforward. It is seeking to extend the charter of the Health Insurance Commission so that it is able to plan, establish and administer the Government's proposed child-care cash rebate scheme. However, as with many proposals this Government puts forward, it is not nearly so straightforward as it may seem at first. While the Bill leaves it entirely open as to what administrative system the Health Insurance Commission may develop, the decision has already been made. The Government, yet again, wants to extend the use of the tax file number.

The Government's intention is that child carers provide their tax file number to the Health Insurance Commission, which would then pass it on to the Tax Office for checking purposes. Not only does this violate past assurances of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on the extent to which the tax file number would be used in Government activities but it also violates a specific assurance made by the Government during the election campaign. In other words, the Government has once again been playing fast and loose with the truth.

After the Government launched its child-care policy during the recent election campaign, briefings were provided to selected child-care organisations. The Minister's office also provided advice to the Australian Privacy Foundation. Why, one might ask, would the privacy foundation be seeking advice on the Government's child-care policy? The answer is that the privacy foundation had heard reports that the Government was flagging the use of a tax file number in the administration of its proposed child-care rebate scheme. Not surprisingly the foundation was alarmed at such a prospect and sought clarification from the Minister's office.

After initially being told that a tax file number would be used, at the end of the day the foundation was provided with a clear assurance by then Minister Staples's private staff that a tax file number would not have to be provided to the Health Insurance Commission. This assurance, as I say, was provided by an adviser to Minister Staples, speaking on behalf of Minister Staples. But only two months later Senator Crowley has told the Senate that as part of the new scheme it is the Government's wish that a tax file number be provided to the Health Insurance Commission. Clearly, there has been a deceptive and highly misleading campaign run by the Government during the election on the proposed use of the tax file number.

The Vice-Chairman of the Australian Privacy Foundation has appeared on national radio on this matter and has written a letter to Senator Crowley outlining his anger at being lied to by Minister Staples's office. This is what the vice-chairman has told Senator Crowley:

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to draw to your attention that Mr Gration, who was at the time explicitly speaking as Mr Staples' representative, stated unequivocally to me on Friday 26 February that the rumour that the HIC would acquire the TFN was entirely unfounded, and that the HIC would not gain the TFN. I stressed to him that I was writing his words down, in order to quote them in my interviews with the media, and read them back to him.

In the Senate on 6 May Senator Crowley said that to the best of her understanding false assurances had not been made by the Government on the use of the tax file number, but nonetheless undertook to check to see whether it was the case. It is now nearly two weeks since that commitment was made and Senator Crowley has yet to report back to the chamber.

PARA.TAB: That false assurances were made is, as I have demonstrated, pretty clear. While there can be no confusion on this point, there has been some confusion on the part of the Minister and her department about exactly what decisions have been taken. For example, at an Estimates Committee C hearing last week the First Assistant Secretary to the Family and Children's Services Division, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The decision has not actually been taken that it—
that is, the child-care rebate scheme—
will be linked with the tax file number.

Later, at the same committee meeting, Senator Crowley said that it was the Government's policy that `people would provide their tax file numbers to the Medicare office'. Despite the obfuscation of the department, it is clear that the Government has made up its mind that it wants to further extend the use of the tax file number. I believe this is a stunning and an outrageous decision. The Government has made a number of assurances regarding the use of the tax file number. For example, on 25 May 1988 the Prime Minister, then Treasurer, said that the only purpose of the tax file number:
. . . will be to make it easier for the Tax Office to match information it receives about money earned and interest payments.
On 1 September 1988, Mr Keating said:

No other government or non-government agency will have access to the Tax Office file number registration system, nor will it be able to use an individual's tax file number for any registration system of its own.

As I have already recounted, assurances were forthcoming from the Government during the election campaign that the tax file number would not be linked to the child-care rebate scheme. Of course, the tax file number is now being used by many government agencies for matching and eligibility checking purposes: for instance, by DSS and DVA to detect duplicate payments; by DVA for superannuation fund information; by DSS and the Department of Finance; by DSS and the Health Insurance Commission; by ATO and the Australian Customs Service; by DSS and the Australian Electoral Commission; by DSS and the Child Support Agency; and by DEET and the department of immigration. There are more examples. The list goes on and on, and it is growing all the time. With the benefit of hindsight, it is clear that Senator Crowley had no doubt that the use of the tax file number would become widespread. In April 1987, showing remarkable prescience, Senator Crowley said:
The tax file number differs not much at all from the Australia Card . . . it would be aiming to do exactly the sorts of things that the Australia Card will do.

There is an acknowledgment. Senator Crowley in 1993 is out to prove the wisdom of her words in 1987. To propose an extension of the tax file number in the way that she has is to propose a de facto Australia Card. When asked on national radio what the danger was with the latest proposal, Roger Clarke, the Vice-Chairman of the Australian Privacy Foundation said:
The danger is that the Government is the possessor of a vast amount of information about individuals, that currently that information is kept by a large number of different government agencies.

Each of those government agencies identifies members of the public using different identification mechanisms. As soon as all of those agencies or even all of the principal agencies use the same identifier, it's possible to have what we call technically a virtual single data base—a single national data base which may run on different machines, but which can be combined at any time that the Government wants it to be combined.

When asked whether this represented a de facto Australia Card, Mr Clarke responded, `It's exactly a de facto Australia Card'. This latest proposal is unprecedented in two important respects. For the first time, service providers, as opposed to benefit recipients, will be required to provide their tax file number. The Government is attempting to cross yet another bridge in its assault on the privacy of Australians. If child-care providers are required to provide a tax file number, how long will it be before doctors and pharmacists and other service providers are required to do the same?

PARA.TAB: The second way in which this latest proposal is unprecedented is that it allows the Health Insurance Commission access to both Medicare claims information and tax information. For Senator Crowley to be advocating this position is remarkable. It illustrates the extent to which members of this Government are prepared to compromise themselves. Back in September 1987 when defending the Australia Card, Senator Crowley said:

SPEECH.PARA: Medicare information will remain separate and secure. . . Tax information will stay with the tax office. . . Medicare information will stay with Medicare.

In other words, she was specifically recognising the importance of keeping Medicare information and tax information separate. Yet now, in an astonishing reversal of this position, Senator Crowley is arguing for the Health Insurance Commission to have access to both Medicare and tax information.

PARA.TAB: I challenge the Minister to explain just how it is that she can reverse her position on the integrity of personal information and retain any credibility at all. I challenge her to set out clearly why it is that the Government has chosen a policy for the administration of its child-care rebate scheme which advocates an extension of the use of the tax file number. What other options has the Government considered and why have they been judged to be less preferable to an extension of the tax file number?

I direct the Minister to page five of the coalition's child-care policy for the details of a simple and effective means of checking the eligibility of those seeking rebates for care provided by a legitimate care provider. I ask the Minister: what consideration was given to the coalition's proposal and why was it not taken up?

The Australian Privacy Foundation has endorsed the coalition's proposed system as a sensible one which gets around the problems raised by the use of a tax file number. Why was it not chosen? One can only say that, given the Government's track record, it is clear that the tax file number option has been chosen over other better options in order to further the Government's real agenda to develop an Australia Card by the back door.

Let us not forget: the Australia Card was overwhelmingly rejected by this Parliament and by the people of Australia. The Australia Card was rejected because it represented an encroachment upon the rights and freedoms of all Australians. It was judged by the people of Australia whom we are here to represent to be a threat to individual privacy and civil liberties. It represented something contrary to everything that this country has represented and stood for. Back in 1987 when the Australia Card was in its death throes, Senator Puplick on behalf of the coalition said:

SPEECH.PARA: We will vigorously oppose any attempt to turn the tax file number system into a de facto Australia Card.

I put the Minister and this Government on notice that we will not stand by and see that happen. In the planning that is about to take place as a result of this legislation, the Opposition's position will need to be taken into account because the child-care legislation amendments will come before us as a result of that planning in the Budget sittings.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition's position should not be ignored because, although we are prepared to allow the Health Insurance Commission to expand its role to plan for the introduction of the Government's promised child-care rebate scheme, we are not prepared to support the extension of the tax file number system in the way that is being detailed to us at this stage.

In detailing the Government's duplicitous and capricious extensions to the tax file number and its plans to catch child carers in its big brother network, I have not yet commented on the deficiencies inherent in the Government's child-care policy. When it was released in February, the Government's policy was widely and accurately perceived as being a child-care policy for millionaires. Under the government rebate scheme as promised, no means test is to be applied, so that two-job families enjoying very high incomes will be the main beneficiaries. This is an extraordinary policy outcome in the economic circumstances currently facing Australia. It represents a gross distortion of priorities. To be actively directing government assistance to those in well-paid employment while we have a million people out of work—370,900 of whom have not had a job in 12 months or more—makes a mockery of the social justice pretensions of this Government.

I can say a great deal more about this but, given the time limits that are imposed on us all now, thanks to the views of the Government and the Democrats about speeches during second reading debates, I intend to bring my speech to a close. We will have an opportunity for debating these issues further when the child-care legislation comes before us in the autumn sittings.

The Health Insurance Commission Amendment Bill 1993 does not set out the program details of the child-care rebate scheme. As I said earlier, that will be achieved in the changes to the Child Care Act in the autumn sittings. So, for this reason, the coalition will not oppose this particular Bill. However, in allowing this Bill to pass I would put the Minister on notice that she cannot assume the support of the coalition for the changes to the Child Care Act which are to follow later, if they include the tax file number provisions.

The coalition will act in the best interests of Australians when that legislation is brought forward. If it threatens the basic freedoms and liberties of Australians, and if it disregards legitimate social justice principles, the coalition will have no part of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal first with the National Health Amendment Bill 1993. This Bill repeals and replaces an important section of the National Health Act dealing with privacy guidelines for the Medicare and pharmaceutical benefits programs. This section was inserted in the Act by this chamber in June 1991. It is as a result of amendments put up by Senator Patterson. However, the section did prove to be something of a problem, resulting in a report to Parliament in May last year by the Privacy Commissioner in which the commissioner indicated that he was not prepared to issue guidelines under this section until Parliament had tidied it up.

PARA.TAB: The Privacy Commissioner found several interpretation difficulties arising out of some of the provisions of section 135AA and some of these, he believed, would have given the Department of Health major administrative headaches. His view on this point was subsequently verified by the Office of General Counsel. The Privacy Commissioner felt these amendments were unacceptable for several reasons, probably the most significant of which was that they would prevent the follow-up of patients when adverse side effects of drugs or particular treatments became apparent several years after the person was treated.

It is worth noting that complete de-identification would also presumably have prevented patients from getting access in the future to their own medical records and their own information or data. At the time when the consumers of health services are—rightly—demanding more information from service providers and better access to their personal medical files and records, complete de-identification of data has the potential to cut across that trend. The Democrats certainly do not believe that that is a desirable outcome.

The commissioner also pointed out that the section may have the consequences of completely de-identifying data within five years of information relating to providers, prescribers and pharmacists. This, he believes, could hinder work in a diverse range of areas including specialist recognition, vocational registration, and the review of the Medicare schedule.

Other doubts were raised about the scope of the privacy guidelines, including the advice being received by the commissioner that the guidelines could only apply to data used in the conduct of the Medicare and pharmaceutical benefits programs after 27 June 1991. I think the commissioner was well on the way to resolving these problems, but I concede doubts exist about the true meaning of the section. Therefore, in conclusion, I note that the doubts were sufficiently compelling to halt the Privacy Commissioner in his tracks and, in these circumstances, we will support the Government's redraft of this section.

With regard to the second Bill, the Health Insurance Commission Amendment Bill 1993, I want to say from the outset that this Bill has caused us some considerable concern—not because of its actual content but because of the bombshell dropped by Senator Crowley in this chamber a week or so ago when she admitted that the Government was looking at further extending the tax file number. Senator Crowley stated quite clearly:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in general, what will be required is that all carers will provide their tax file number to the Medicare officers.

This was the first indication that we had from the Government of its intention to use the tax file number in this fashion. Although in the Bill there is no specific mention of it, we are surely at this stage—and we will be doing so in detail in committee—entitled to ask some quite serious questions. I say that given Senator Crowley's recent comments and also comments made in the Estimates committee.

PARA.TAB: For a start, is Senator Crowley telling us that the Government has firmly and finally decided to require carers to provide their tax file numbers to Medicare officers in order to receive the rebate? Or is this issue just being run up the flagpole to see how far it will go and how far the Government can get with it? Has she consulted with or sought the opinions of the Privacy Commissioner? What alternative identification measures have been looked at? What can Senator Crowley tell us about the realistic possibilities of high-level fraud within the scheme? Where does she see the Australian Taxation Office fitting into the scheme?

Essentially, the Democrats want to know how far along the Minister is in the actual detail of the scheme. I do not have any great difficulties with the notion of the Health Insurance Commission planning, developing and administering the payment of child-care rebates. If claims are to be made through Medicare offices, then presumably the commission will have to play a role. However, I do have some concerns about where this process is headed and we need to know from the Minister precisely what stage the process has reached.

If we in the Senate pass this Bill today, are we giving the Health Insurance Commission the authority to go ahead and carry out some genuine work on how the scheme should be established and administered, and come back to the Parliament with those details set out in subsequent legislation, or are we just rubber stamping what has already been decided? I believe Senator Crowley owes the Senate an explanation on all this.

For a start, she needs to state categorically to the Senate that the passage of this Bill will not be seen as a mandate for the Health Insurance Commission to set up a system that is geared to having health care providers or anyone else provide their tax file numbers to Medicare officers. The fact of the matter is that this Government has never really given up on the idea of an Australia Card. What the Government could not get by being up-front about its intentions, it has proceeded to get by stealth and deceit—aided and abetted by the Liberal Party, I have to say—and steadily we have seen the growing encroachment of the tax file number requirements.

Today Senator Newman has mentioned some of the areas where the tax file number changes have been made, but I must state quite categorically that every time on every single issue the Liberals have voted for it. I will go through the departments: data matching now covers the Department of Social Security, Department of Veterans' Affairs, Department of Employment, Education and Training, the Health Insurance Commission, the Commonwealth Employment Service, community services, Immigration and the Tax Office. It is a bit much for the Opposition to stand up and carry on now about tax file numbers and privacy and whether or not it is a de facto Australia Card,when the Opposition has been a part of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is different in this case: very different in this case.
—The Opposition has allowed the Government to reach this point. Really, what we now have is, in effect, a de facto Australia Card.
—Come on!

—I stress to Senator Newman that the Opposition has helped the Government to put it there. This Bill adds to the functions of the Health Insurance Commission and enables the commission to plan and establish a system under which it can pay rebates for child-care costs. The Democrats are prepared to accept this Bill, because we want to see the child-care rebate scheme up and running. However, we will not support a situation where people have to go down to their local Medicare office and give their tax file number to the Health Insurance Commission in order to claim a rebate.

PARA.TAB: I will now turn briefly to the scheme itself and make a few comments. As far as the Democrats are concerned, accessible, affordable, quality child care is not a welfare service; it is an essential service and one which is necessary to give all family members, particularly women, the opportunity to fully participate in all aspects of society.

We put child care on the same basic list of human rights and entitlements as health care and education. We see child care as being especially crucial to four issues of basic fairness and equity in Australian society. Firstly, child care plays a crucial role in the current and future opportunities available to Australian women. Secondly, child care is crucial to ensure that women have the opportunity to make the transition from full-time to part-time employment. Thirdly, child care is crucial as it gives the options of more flexible employment chances for both men and women. Finally, child care is crucial to our recognition of the value of unpaid work.

The last concern often gets lost in the flurry of debate and it is one that can be very easily hijacked by those who think that a woman's place is in the home or by those who really do have a bent on getting married women out of the paid work force. But it is a crucial concern, and it is one that the Government's child-care rebate scheme will not address. The rebate will only be available to people who are in employment or training, studying, or looking for work, and, while I certainly understand the Government's priorities in this area and endorse the scheme, I really do not think it goes far enough.

I think it is time we looked seriously at some formal recognition of unpaid work by what is generally called the invisible work force. At present we have no way of calculating the work done by the invisible work force because we simply ignore unpaid work. We do not take it into account when we calculate our gross domestic product or when we discuss national productivity. When we talk of industry policy, we do not consider the home care industry and its unpaid workers. We do not consider their wages or conditions and whether they have insurance to cover themselves if they are injured on the job.

Basically the policies and plans we make as a nation simply ignore the contribution of a large proportion of the Australian population, but it is a massive contribution. Its value has been estimated at between 52 per cent and 65 per cent of GDP. A survey last year by the Centre for Applied Research on the future indicates that Australian households actually produce about three times the output of Australia's entire manufacturing industry. So we have a lot of people out there doing a lot of work which is of value to us as a society but which is not measured or acknowledged.

I am certainly concerned about two things which this rebate scheme does not address. Firstly, if we do not provide access to child-care for carers at home, we are not only refusing to acknowledge their significant economic contribution but also denying them the opportunity to fully participate in Australian society. Whether that participation is just working on the family farm, doing a few days voluntary work or undertaking some part-time study, it does not matter.

Secondly, I think it is time we looked at the idea of a payment to carers who are staying at home and caring for children, whether those carers are men or women. I appreciate that there are some problems, not the least being the biases which many of the participants bring to this debate. But I really think we should be moving towards such a payment, and for this type of payment to be successful it must go hand in hand with a range of employment related measures.

We must ensure that it is not an option that women feel forced to take, or one that they are forced to take through any sort of economic necessity because they cannot earn sufficient income from employment while also having to cover their child-care costs. It is rather annoying that in this debate we are constantly hearing everyone else trying to organise women's lives for them and tell them how to run their lives, but as this debate moves on we really should be talking about choice. In a changing employment and social environment it is no longer good enough to run the old ideologically driven argument either for or against a payment to carers—and I am not talking about $20 or $30 a week; I am talking about a payment at a level that gives men and women a real choice.

This debate must be about ensuring that both men and women can make choices which suit them, their families, their employment situations, their careers and their personal desires—without incurring a significant serious disadvantage because we do not recognise their contribution when one of their choices is to be a carer. The challenge before us is to recognise the value of unpaid work without further disadvantaging women. I cannot see why we cannot meet that challenge. I urge the Minister to look beyond this child-care rebate scheme and to begin an exploration of some of these issues, including a total redefinition of what we value formally as work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the two Bills before the Senate—the National Health Amendment Bill 1993 and the Health Insurance Commission Amendment Bill 1993. If nothing else, it is ironic that the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) has decided to put these two Bills together to be debated cognately. The National Health Amendment Bill seeks to make amendments to the parent Act that will enable the Privacy Commissioner to issue guidelines in regard to the separation and de-identification of personalised Medicare and pharmaceutical benefits data. I hope these amendments and the subsequent guidelines will be the culmination of four years of the coalition's efforts to persuade this Government to develop a policy on how it handles the vast array of health information it maintains on individual Australians.

PARA.TAB: My concern in this area developed when the pharmaceutical benefits scheme data went to the Health Insurance Commission. It crossed my mind to ask for how long the Health Insurance Commission kept data both from Medicare and the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. I and, I suppose, most other Australians were stunned to find out that the Health Insurance Commission kept the data indefinitely. So every visit to the doctor is recorded; the type of doctor we visit can be identified by provided number, whether it be a psychiatrist or a venereologist; the type of pathology test we have is recorded; and sometimes the type of treatment, especially the type of surgery, is recorded. All of that information can be obtained from the Health Insurance Commission and somebody could see fit to use the information indiscreetly or for some sort of commercial purpose. As has been seen from the ICAC investigations in New South Wales, some people in departments, such as social security, have been tempted to release private information. Every script that has been dispensed is also recorded.

In Estimates Committee C, I expressed my concern by asking the officers of the department whether it would be feasible to identify families with genetic disorders, such as phenylketonuria, thalassaemia and fibrocystic disease, from the type of doctor they visit, the type of treatment they receive and the type of drugs they are prescribed. The answer I was given was, `Yes, Senator, it would be possible'. That is something about which our community ought to be very concerned. That led me to push for a period of four years for the department to develop a much better privacy policy in relation to Medicare data.

The community has to debate—and this still has to take place properly; I believe that we are only on the edge of it—whether that data ought to depersonalised totally and kept in a form that can be used for epidemiological purposes or whether for the common good we ought to keep the information so that people can have revealed 20 years down the track whether they took a certain drug that has been discovered to have a deleterious effect later in their lives. That is a debate that I think the Australian community ought to have and that rightfully ought to be put on the agenda. I hope the press take it up; it has not shown much interest in it in recent years. This is something that we need to have a discussion about.

This legislation goes part way to allaying my fears. At least it looks at the depersonalisation of the information which can then be reconstituted within the guidelines set out. It is something that Australians ought to be concerned about. It is not too brave new worlde to suspect that in 20 years time a government may not be as reasonable about the information that it holds. The fact that the Health Insurance Commission has all that data ought to be of concern to Australians. I think the debate ought to start. The fact ought be made public that this sort of sensitive data is being stored and kept by the Government. At least now we have some move towards developing a policy.

As I said before, it is ironic that, at the same time as the Government is finalising a policy in relation to the retention of health records, it is introducing a Bill that seeks to extend the role of the Health Insurance Commission in a way that inevitably raises major privacy concerns. At the same time as the Senate is passing a Bill that will facilitate the introduction of privacy guidelines relating to Medicare and the PBS, it is being asked to pass another Bill which, on Senator Crowley's admission, will result in a further extension of the tax file number system to the administration of child-care cash rebates. While facilitating the introduction of one set of privacy guidelines, we are being asked to support a proposition that contradicts another set of privacy guidelines, namely the tax file number guidelines.

It is pertinent to trace the history of the development of the Government's health data retention policy. When one does, it becomes obvious that this policy certainly has not been nurtured by any concern from the government benches about this important issue. It has come from concern by people such as Senator Walters, Senator Watson and Dr Woods, who was formerly a member of the House of Representatives. They deserve special mention.

As Senator Newman has said, over a significant period I have pursued the Government during Estimates committee hearings. It is because of our constant efforts that the Government has been forced to address this issue of the vast amount of personalised health information which, since the inception of Medicare, has been retained in a readily identifiable form, albeit with another number.

On 2 November 1989, in a speech on the 1988-89 annual report of the Health Insurance Commission, I first expressed my concern about the excessive amount of data held by this Government. In that speech, I asked the Health Insurance Commission to devote a section to privacy in its subsequent annual reports—it did not have anything on privacy in its annual report—so that the Parliament could examine how its data was dealt with and for how long it was kept.

In the Senate estimates hearings in May 1990, the Health Insurance Commission admitted that its Medicare claims data was maintained off-line indefinitely. It is interesting to look at Hansard for that estimates committee hearing. I was told that the data was held on-line for two years. I asked the question, `How long do you keep it off-line?' and I was told, `They hold it on-line for two years'. We then dragged out the fact that it was held off-line in paper form and possibly some other forms. I asked, `How long do you hold it for?'. Finally, after I had to squeeze the information out of them, the officers of the commission said, `We keep it indefinitely'. The commission also conceded that the retention of personalised health data was an issue that deserved debate and that there was a need to discuss a policy relating to the destruction and depersonalisation of this data. That was when the estimates committee had squeezed the witnesses to the point where they had to admit that maybe they ought to think about the fact that the commission kept this data for so long.

In an answer to questions on notice in the estimates hearings of September 1990, the Health Insurance Commission stated that it was looking at developing a policy for the depersonalisation of personalised health data. It also stated that previous questioning from Opposition senators had provided the impetus for this initiative and that it was hoped that agreement would be reached within the department within six months. Senator Crowley can see that admission by the department in the Hansard—not because her Government pressured for it but because over a period of time the Opposition pressured that department to address the issue of privacy in relation to health information. It was our pressuring that achieved that; it was nothing to do with the Government.

On 26 November, I reported to the Senate that the Health Insurance Commission had seen fit to include in its annual report—I was watching it by that time—a section on data security and privacy. When we give those five-minute speeches we may think that they are not listened to, but the commission must have listened because in that report was a little section on privacy and security. Slowly but surely we could see the wheels of change turning.

By the Additional Estimates in April 1991, the then Department of Health, Housing and Community Services announced that a draft joint departmental and Health Insurance Commission policy on the retention of health data was being developed and that it was expected that this policy would be finalised by the end of the month—we are getting closer. The department outlined the matters to be covered in this policy and said that it was hoped that a provisional policy statement would be released in July.

This process was expedited through the introduction of the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill 1991 during the Autumn sittings. We should all remember this Bill which sought to introduce a revamped version of the Government's pharmacy black box. It also included provisions for the introduction of privacy guidelines in relation to the conduct of Medicare and pharmaceutical benefits programs. During the debate on this legislation, the coalition, supported by the Australian Democrats, achieved significant improvements to these provisions.

We ensured that these guidelines had effective legal status. The legislation was amended to ensure that any breach of the guidelines would be considered to be a breach of the Privacy Act, meaning that the Privacy Commissioner would be able to use his investigative powers in relation to complaints. We also succeeded in winning amendments that ensured that the Privacy Commissioner's guidelines were subject to proper parliamentary scrutiny as disallowable instruments. Very importantly, given the Government's disinterest in this important issue, we also succeeded in amending the legislation to make it a legal requirement to devise these guidelines. This was a vast improvement on the Government's option of the Minister asking the Privacy Commissioner to devise guidelines.

Most importantly, section 135AA(6) provided that the guidelines must outline procedures which would ensure that information relating to the Medicare and pharmaceutical benefits programs would be de-identified within five years of receipt if it were the subject of a current action. In addition, it ensured that Medicare and pharmaceutical benefits would be kept separately. This was another issue of concern to us because together the data provides an enormous amount of information about the status of an individual or of a family, especially the genetic status.

These two provisions went a long way towards fulfilling the coalition's long held concern that a policy be developed in relation to depersonalisation of health data. The Privacy Commissioner had issued draft guidelines with the Bill with regard to the pharmaceutical benefits program and was required to issue section 135AA guidelines or report to the Parliament by 1 April 1992.

In November 1991, I informed the Senate that the department's annual report stated that a draft policy covering confidentiality, release practice and data retention of Medicare and PBS data had been prepared for consultation with the Privacy Commissioner and that the policy would be finalised that financial year. The Privacy Commissioner proceeded to draft the required privacy guidelines which were circulated for comment in February 1992. However, the Privacy Commissioner did not issue the draft guidelines after receiving legal advice that they may not conform with section 135AA(6) of the National Health Act.

This legal advice is certainly not cut and dried. The Privacy Commissioner acknowledged this when he reported to Parliament his failure to issue guidelines under this section. He stated that two of the concerns expressed by the Office of General Counsel were derived from a strict, literal construction of the language, while the third was much more arguable. As someone who has been involved in both the development of the policy and the legislative debates, I seriously doubt whether this legal advice reflects the Parliament's intentions. However, in the interests of certainty and ensuring that these guidelines are issued as soon as possible, the coalition will support these amendments.

We are comforted by the fact that the Privacy Commissioner has not raised any serious problems with the Bill. He has stated that he will monitor the situation, in respect of both the definition of `database' in the Bill and the fact that the guidelines will no longer apply to paper files, and that he will report to Parliament any emerging difficulties. Hopefully, the passing of this Bill will result in the immediate implementation of the department's data retention policy, particularly the depersonalisation of all patient claims data within five years of receipt.

As one who has been pushing this barrow for so long, I was dismayed to hear the news last week that the Health Insurance Commission still has not commenced de-identifying any information collected since the inception of Medicare. I sincerely hope that a high priority will be given to commencing this process as soon as this legislation is passed by the Parliament.

Finally, I would like to reiterate my concerns about the Government's decision, confirmed by Senator Crowley, to extend the use of the tax file number to its planned child-care cash rebate system. I take objection to a comment that Senator Lees made about the coalition not taking an interest in this issue and going along with the Government. Senator Lees should have sat, as I think her then colleague Senator Powell did, when we went through detail after detail of that tax file number system in the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs to ensure that every effort was made to protect the interests of privacy in that area. In that situation the Government was again holding a gun to all of our heads in that it argued that there would be huge financial implications if the tax file number was not extended. This is not the case in this situation; this is a very different situation. I wanted to put that on the record.

I was informed that during the election campaign the Australian Privacy Foundation was told that tax file numbers would not be required by either the department or the Health Insurance Commission to administer the child-care cash rebate system. It seems that there has been some confusion or some slippage, as in so many other areas—

TALK.START.PARA: —What?

—I suppose that is being generous. The Government's rhetoric prior to the election is not being matched by its actions after the election. Why should we believe the Government? On all the Government's brochures a week before the election it stated, `We'll take all the pensions out of the taxation system' but then, five days after the election, the Minister said, `No, that wasn't meant to be there'. Imagine if we had made an error like that in Fightback and five days after the election we said, `We are sorry, we didn't mean to give you a increase of eight per cent in your pensions. That was an error'. All hell would have broken loose. But the Government can merrily change its mind. On this issue, it seems as though the rhetoric prior to the election does not match its practice afterwards.

PARA.TAB: The last major extension of the tax file number system occurred in 1990 with the introduction of data-matching between the tax office, social security, Austudy and the first home owners scheme. When the then Minister for Social Security was questioned by the Senate legal and constitutional affairs committee as to why the Government was breaking a previous commitment not to extend the use of the tax file number, he had the temerity to tell the committee that nothing was immutable and that the Government kept some promises but broke others. Was that news to us? No.

The most common concern for those of us both in and outside the Parliament who jealously guard the confidentiality of personal information that we provide to government agencies is the ability of computers and nameless, faceless bureaucrats to gather all this information at a central point and compile a detailed profile about us without our knowledge. As Senator Newman said, it does not necessarily have to be at a central point. That is why the ever increasing use of tax file numbers is such a serious matter. The widespread use of this common identifier by so many government agencies means that any number of public servants have the ability, literally at their fingertips, to produce detailed secret profiles on all of us.

This latest encroachment is more insidious and more dangerous than the previous extension in 1990. At least then the Government tried to justify the extension of the tax file number on the basis that it was the price one paid for being in receipt of welfare assistance. Surely this Government will not claim that this universal child-care cash rebate is a welfare benefit—I think Senator Lees also made that point.

At least back in 1990 the Government was able to put forward an argument that the extended use of tax file numbers in data matching would mean substantial financial gains to the Government. However savings of the magnitude estimated from data matching could never be realised from this policy initiative.

The Minister's announcement in the Senate that the Health Insurance Commission would be using tax files numbers to administer the child-care cash rebate will render the greatest fear of all privacy protectors a virtual reality—that is, tax file numbers and Medicare numbers being maintained or accessed by the same agency. In effect, this means that the final link will have been made that enables government to build up an all purpose, all encompassing profile on individual Australians. Senator Newman also referred to what Senator Crowley said in 1987. Senator Crowley stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Tax file number differs not much at all from the Australia Card . . . it would be aiming to do exactly the sort of things that the Australia Card would do.
With that quotation, I rest my case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering the National Health Amendment Bill 1993 and the Health Insurance Commission Amendment Bill 1993. All of the issues in respect of the first Bill have been reasonably canvassed thus far. I have observed the activities of Senator Patterson and Senator Walters—as Senator Newman said—and I commend them for their efforts. It is heartening to see that at last the intentions that have clearly been laid down by both of those senators over a number of years might eventually become realised. To that extent I support the measure.

PARA.TAB: I would like to make some comments about the Health Insurance Commission Amendment Bill. I have listened to the speeches thus far and I was pleased to hear Senator Lees talk about the need to recognise unpaid work by a spouse in the home, whether the spouse is a woman or a man. But by and large at present women are the ones caring for children in the home.

This has been a matter of great concern to me over many years. The value of the mother's unpaid work in the home became obvious to me when my first wife died in 1980. Besides all the trauma, one has to be in that situation to recognise the economic costs. That is, of course, not the major consideration when one is in that situation. I think people must realise that that unpaid work is unrecognised, generally speaking, by governments in Australia and particularly by this Government. One must bear in mind that over the years any recognition of the work of the person in the home has dwindled.

The Health Insurance Commission Amendment Bill 1993 introduces the mechanism for Medicare offices to pay the child-care cash rebates for expenses incurred for work-related child care. The Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) said in her second reading speech that the child-care cash rebate recognises that the cost of child care is a legitimate expense for parents earning an income. I will not debate that now but were that so, one would really have to look at the distinction that is made between certain types of work-based child care and other types of child care. This is probably not the time to go into that debate, but that debate will certainly be a very real one during the Budget session. I want to focus on the logical implications of the Minister's statement and the inequities it illustrates in our tax and spending measures relating to certain aspects of child care.

For a start, we can contrast the proposed child-care cash rebate for working parents with the child-care allowance proposed for mothers caring for children at home. This gets back to the question of unpaid work. The home child-care allowance of $30 a week is not as generous as it seems. The net family gain, with the abolition of the spouse rebate, is only $2.85 per week, regardless of the number of children. Spouses without children will continue to be eligible for the maximum spouse rebate, and that is a measure which I support. When we compare the $30 per week cash rebate with the annual amount of spouse rebate for those with no children, the difference is only $7.37 a week. That $7.37 a week does not increase according to the number of children being cared for at home; it is the same amount whether there is one child at home or 10.

The child-care cash rebate scheme for work-related expenses is an important matter, and it is one in which I have had a great deal of interest. The maximum child-care cash rebate will be $1,466 a year, that is, $28.20 a week for one child; and $3,182 per annum, that is, $61.60 per week for two children.

This is the first inequity which I draw to the attention of the Senate. Some children and some families are apparently more equal than others. If a family has more children either at home or in outside child care, the level of subsidy has little regard to the number of children.

The second inequity which I draw to the attention of the Senate is the enormous difference between the $7.37 per week received by a spouse at home caring for his or her own children and what is received by families with two income earners in the paid work force. In 1991-92, the Commonwealth paid something like $435 million in child-care subsidies under the children's services program. Much of this went to children in professional community care centres rather than children in family day care. Spending has grown from $65 million for 46,000 subsidised places in 1983 to $435 million for 193,000 subsidised places today. The per capita subsidy per place has increased faster than the number of places, from $1,413 in 1983 to $2,254 in June 1992. The average subsidy of $2,254 or $43 per week seems a lot better than the implicit subsidy for a child of $7.37 in the cashed-out spouse rebate. That is irrespective of the number of children a person is caring for—unpaid and unrecognised.

SPEECH.PARA: It may be argued, as the Minister and the Government do, that the purpose of the children's services program is for labour market support. I would have thought that the major purpose of any children's services program would be the welfare of the children. That is something that the Government should have regard to.

On a number of occasions in this chamber, particularly last year, I have raised with Senator Button the issue of persons who have been forced out of the paid work force. People are talking about married women being forced out of the paid work force. As far as I am concerned, that is not an issue. There should be a true freedom of choice. But nowadays the organisation that is pushing married women out of the paid work force is mostly the Government.

PARA.TAB: If honourable senators look at the current unemployment figures to see who has been pushed out of the paid work force, it will be clear to them that the majority are women. I have been trying to ask Senator Button what has happened to them and their families. Women who were pushed into the paid work force just to make ends meet and pay the bills are now, because of the Government's economic policies, being pushed out. Nobody worries about them; they are now unseen. The unemployment figures drop but they are disheartened job seekers. There are no jobs for them.

It is time that the Government recognised this problem and did something about it. It must do something about it in the name of equity and social justice. If it does not do something about it in the name of social justice, it certainly will not last another term because there is a widespread concern amongst the community that families on one income are getting a very raw deal. The income of that family is taxed as though there were no dependants. The income of a family ought to be taxed having regard to the number of persons dependent upon that family income. If that were so, there would be an additional tax free threshold for the spouse—whether male or female—and an additional tax free threshold for each of the children.

Instead, the Government has proposed deferred bribes—that is, it is taking money from one family member and giving it to another. We will debate that when it comes along and see whether there are other possible measures to ensure that the money goes where it ought to go—that is, into the hands of the caring spouse. There are other ways of going about that. In general, the Government is proposing to take it out of the hip pocket of the taxpayer and put it into the purse of the carer. The danger of that, unless it is tied down with indexation, is that what will happen is the same as what happened to family allowances. In 1976 family allowances were introduced and the tax rebate system was abolished. Without costing the Government anything, tax rebates were cashed up into a family allowance to be paid to the spouse. In general, the money was taken out of the hip pocket of the taxpayer and put into the purse of the carer.

Ever since then the Government has been purloining and pinching money from the purses of mothers in Australia. That allowance is now worth only 62 per cent of what it was in 1976—an absolute disgrace. One of the reasons for that is that it has gone from the taxation area into the highly visible social services and social security area. As Senator Grimes and the Minister, I think it was the then Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, said at that particular stage, family allowances were never meant to be regarded as a social welfare payment but as a recognition that at any level of income a family with children is paying more than a family without.

There have been improvements in the family payments scheme, which I and my union have been pressing very strongly. We were recognised by the former Prime Minister on one occasion for our efforts in regard to the family assistance supplement. I think that is very important. That certainly is a welfare measure which is very important. I acknowledge the work that was done and has been done on that.

But getting back to those working families—and I use the term working families whether or not both parents are in the paid work force; they are still working families—a skilled tradesman with three children is just above the family income supplement level. The family assistance supplement is now called the additional family payment. Those families have suffered enormous injustices.

A number of things need to be said about this. I concur with what has been said by those people who raised the issue of the tax file number. The Government has to give a full explanation to the Senate about that issue. We expressed concerns in this chamber during the Australia Card debate. We were given some sort of indication of the views of the people who are now on the Government front bench. I hope they will remember some of the things they said on that occasion.

I think it is fair to say that the Senate would not and does not look kindly on measures taken by this Government or any other government to bring in the Australia Card through the backdoor. I am sure the people of Australia do not look kindly on it. I believe it is for the Minister, either in reply or more particularly in the committee stage of the debate, to set the minds of the Senate and the people of Australia at rest on that particular issue.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank my Senate colleagues for their contribution to this debate. I might address my initial remarks to the National Health Amendment Bill 1993. I think it is very important to acknowledge—it would be little minded not to but it would also be inaccurate not to—the contribution of Senator Patterson, in particular, to the changes in policy about privacy and the management of information about people in the Health Insurance Commission area.

PARA.TAB: I think I have said before, but I am very happy to say it again, that there is absolutely no doubt that Senator Patterson's questions in estimates committee hearings have made a difference. I am a bit surprised that Senator Patterson wonders whether or not departments read speeches that senators make in this place about annual reports. I would have thought that she would know that departments read those things very closely and that a particularly constructive contribution is taken notice of. There is no doubt that we would have to acknowledge Senator Patterson's contribution in this area. I think it is also important to note that there has been an agreed working-through of Senator Patterson's initiatives and the Government's concern about privacy in this area.
