I think these two pieces of legislation are remarkably apposite. Later, I will comment on the Health Insurance Commission and refute some of the claims that have been made, particularly by Senator Newman. The National Health Amendment Bill deals directly with the concerns about privacy that citizens have raised and that have been brought to the Government's attention by Senator Patterson. There is no doubt that this amending legislation goes directly to concerns about privacy. It puts clearly on the record the Government's concern for privacy of Medicare data—in particular, Health Insurance Commission data—and the seriousness with which it considers such matters.

The legislation seeks to repeal a section and to replace it so as to get it right this time. I think it is fair to say that the Privacy Commissioner could not proceed with the guidelines because, if he had, there was a clear understanding that he would have had to delete every piece of information of any kind of relevance every five years. That was never the intention of the amendment when it was introduced in the first place. Getting it right, or making clear what was intended, is much better managed with this amending piece of legislation.

It is true—and I was delighted to hear Senator Patterson mention it—that the process of de-identifying data does not mean that the aggregate data may not be available for epidemiologists and other people who have a proper and right need to study the information of epidemiological processes. There is also a concern about what we now know is a very long lead time for some diseases to emerge.

One example is people who have suffered from and subsequently died of mesothelioma with up to a 25- or 40-year lead time. That is the kind of evidence that the Health Insurance Commission might have in a few years, and it is the sort of information that I think properly ought be held by a society. I am sure it would concern individual citizens who were looking for evidence of something about which they had seen a doctor once upon a time, but of which there was no further evidence and who, therefore, had been denied appropriate treatment or justice years later.

Senator Patterson said that we do need to have a community debate about this information. I think that is a very important point, because there are lively tensions between the requirements of privacy, the requirements of proper collection and maintenance of data for the benefit of individuals, and also the requirements for proper epidemiological studies, for example, or for better programs and planning.

I was advised not too long ago of a doctor in England who was concerned about a patient who had died of a disease which could not be properly diagnosed. I think it was in the 1950s. Subsequently, as evidence of AIDS emerged, the doctor had some of the pathological sections that had been preserved examined and discovered, many years later, that this person had also died of AIDS. That is one of the bits and pieces of evidence that I think are very important in trying to pursue the course of a disease. What are we talking about, for example, in terms of the spread of a disease such as AIDS? We do need a balance, and I think this amending legislation addresses the need for that balance.

As far as I understand, Medicare is approaching its 10th birthday—I think it had its 9th birthday earlier this year—so it really has not yet held information for as long as 10 years. I think it is very appropriate that this process has been put in place with the applicable time lines, but I think it is also interesting to note that there has not been time for the Health Insurance Commission to have salted away too much data yet. It is not even 10 years old, so perhaps in this case we will have got the legislation and the timeliness exactly right.

There is much more that could be said about the need for important health data. For example, in this country we are just establishing a genetic counselling service. There are certainly some families for which genetic counselling and the information that can be provided is of great importance, particularly in their decisions of whether or not to proceed with having children. I am not sure whether thalassaemia has been cited in this debate already, but thalassaemia is one disease of concern. Parents who know about the genetic propensity for that within their families may decide not to have children, but it would also be very useful for that information to be held somewhere—perhaps with the family, perhaps with some other authority for further and future reference.

Indeed, there have been some discussions recently in the newspapers about Huntington's chorea. As I understand that disease, it has something like a forty-year dormant period before it takes its effect. It is a genetic disease, and again if we were looking at the information we would need to maintain an adequate genetic counselling service and the proper information that that would provide to society as well as to individuals, then of course we would have to balance the need to know with the protection of privacy of individuals.

I turn to the Health Insurance Commission Amendment Bill. This is a simple, innocent little Bill whose provisions have been used in this debate to whack a whole lot of other irrelevancies around the head. Senator Newman has got it wrong. It seems to me that she is now devoted to maintaining a wrong position on this. Senator Newman is intending to support this legislation. She knows she can support it because it is quite innocent legislation. It does not address any of the things that she was trawling as red herrings across the debate today. Nothing can be done in the area of implementing the cash rebates until the Child Care Act is amended later on.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge that.

—I am glad the honourable senator acknowledges that. Therefore, we can also acknowledge that everything else Senator Newman said today is pure and absolute speculation. It has nothing to do with this legislation. I am pleased to hear Senator Newman acknowledge that nothing can be implemented about the proposed changes in the cash rebate payments without the amendments to the Child Care Act.
—Be honest! I acknowledged that in my speech.

—Senator Newman keeps asking me to be honest. Is she suggesting that I am a liar? If so, that is very unparliamentary. I think Senator Newman should listen; I listened to her, apart from one muffled interjection, and she might listen to me.

PARA.TAB: Senator Newman persists in getting it wrong. She persists in muddying the waters and in trawling red herrings around the place on this matter. The amendment relating to the Health Insurance Commission allows for the Health Insurance Commission to start the basic preparatory work and nothing further. It cannot do any of those fearful and terrifying things Senator Newman wants to scare the community with. Let us make that first point. I am glad to hear that Senator Newman has got that bit right. People need to be reminded that Senator Newman got one thing right.

I now go to the things she got wrong and persists in keeping wrong. The proposals are only at the administrative and planning stage. That is the substance of the answer I gave her in Question Time and of what was said at estimates. If Senator Newman persists in not understanding that, then I cannot account for the limitations of her understanding. That is what was said in my answer, that was what was explained to her at estimates and that is what she should understand is the case. There are administrative procedures being set up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your answer and the Minister's answer were quite specific.
—I urge Senator Newman to read the answers again.
—I have them right here.

—So do I, and we could have a debate about the meaning of the words. There are proposed administrative procedures for cash rebate payments—and that is what it says, a `proposal'. A proposal does not mean definite responses or things set in concrete. Those procedures are under examination and I have spelt out the considerations. Firstly, I would like to make it absolutely clear, because the comments by Senator Lees led me to understand that she has a misunderstanding about this—
—She has got it wrong too?

—Senator Lees commented that if child-care users had to produce a tax file number to get a rebate, the Australian Democrats would totally oppose it. Child-care users have never been considered as having to provide their tax file number, and never would. There is no point at all in their doing that; it is not part of the proposal. I say again, for the benefit of Senator Newman, the details have not been finalised; they are being considered. But, somewhere along the line, child-care users will have to produce evidence that they have used child care, usually a receipt. They would take that along to the Medicare office and, according to the proposed formula, if it can be matched against a properly registered child-care provider, they would be eligible for the cash rebate, calculated on how much they have paid and so on.

PARA.TAB: Senator Lees suggested that the tax file number might also be attached to the collector of the rebate. Let me make it clear that that is absolutely not the case. The tax file number has been associated only with child-care providers as part of a proposal to identify those providers. That is a proposal. Those details are to be worked out.

I acknowledge the serious points at issue. I would like to make it clear that the Government is very concerned to get it right. As I said in my opening remarks, we have two bits of legislation bracketed here: one going to the Government's concerns about privacy, and one going to proposed changes to enable the Health Insurance Commission to proceed with some preparatory work. However, I do not understand how the Opposition could suggest that the Government is concerned about privacy, on the one hand, and totally disregarding of privacy on the other. Of course we are very concerned about the privacy matters here.

We are also concerned to give honourable senators full and adequate time to examine the final proposal so that they can address those finalised arrangements. Indeed, I assure the principal players in this debate, Senator Lees and Senator Newman, that I want to make as much assistance available as we can prior to the debate in this place. But we take note of their concerns and I can certainly assure them that I have those concerns very well registered.

What I am not happy to settle for is the deliberate muddying of the waters on this issue—the flashing around of words like `Australia Card', `insidious', and `by stealth'. Those sorts of words are not a true description of what the Government is doing, and is proposing to do, in this area. So, if Senator Newman continues to misrepresent it like that, that is a very disappointing, mischievous and unfair way to proceed. I cannot say it more clearly. I sincerely hope that she has it clear now—it is and always has been part of a proposal.
The next point that Senator Newman raised concerned child care for millionaires. This is not really child-care legislation, but I would have to say that that is also wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it means tested?
—If Senator Newman understood the facts and figures in this area, she would understand that it is not about child care for millionaires.
—How? Is it means tested? You will not answer that, will you?
—I will just take a break whilst Senator Newman stops and pauses for breath.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—Order! If Senator Newman has a response, I suggest that she seek leave to give it at the end of the Minister's speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not an example of child care for millionaires at all. I will read some facts and figures. Most importantly, we have added the child-care cash rebate on top of the fee relief, and the fee relief proposals address assistance for people at the low income level. The cash rebate recognises child care as a cost against earning income and, like every other rebate for costs against earning income, it is not income tested. I sincerely hope the honourable senator opposite heard that.

PARA.TAB: For a family with an income of up to $24,000—for example, a hairdresser—the child-care assistance per week would be $92.50 and cash rebate eligibility would be a further $2.85. For a family with an income of $40,000—for example, a waiter or hairdresser earning $22,000 and a teacher's aid earning $18,000—the child-care assistance is currently $50.70 and cash rebate eligibility is $15.40. I will skip some of the other examples and go to a family with an income of $60,000. For a male primary school teacher earning $35,000 and a female data processor earning $25,000, with a joint family income of $60,000, the eligibility for child-care assistance or fee relief is nil and eligibility under the cash rebate is $28.20.

So Senator Newman will find that this is anything but child care for millionaires. In conjunction with our fee relief or child-care assistance, it is an addition which recognises child care as a cost against earning income. As I say, it is like other costs against earning income and is not income tested. Because it comes on top of our very fair fee relief system or child-care assistance, there is no skewing of child-care assistance to millionaires.

Secondly, $28.20 is the maximum figure. Once one becomes eligible for the child-care cash rebate, the maximum one can receive—whatever one's income is above $60,000—is $28.20, which does not sound like a child-care rebate for millionaires. I very much disagree with Senator Newman's assessment. Indeed, she is quite wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —The richer you are, the more you get?

—I do not think there is much point in saying it again. The honourable senator opposite is giving clear evidence of a condition that I have only ever heard the Catholic church talk about—that is, she suffers from invincible ignorance.

PARA.TAB: I have acknowledged Senator Patterson's contribution. I would like to pick up on a point which both Senator Newman and Senator Patterson raised. They claimed that at some time in this place I said that the tax file number would not be associated with Medicare data. Even if the proposal outlined should consider this, that remains absolutely true. It is very mischievous of honourable senators opposite to claim that Medicare data would be in any way accessed by the proposals under the child-care cash rebates. That is precisely what this legislation will be doing: establishing a method for quite separate ways of attending to the payment of the child-care rebate and I will deal with those things at the committee stage. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
The Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the second reading response of the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), she indicated that the real purpose of the Health Insurance Commission Amendment Bill 1993 is to ensure that a proposal is developed and that the Health Insurance Commission Medicare officers would be developing such a proposal. The financial impact statement accompanying the explanatory memorandum says that the estimated cost will be $2.5 million. Is it not a fact that this really will be not a proposal but, as it says here, the planning and establishment of a cash rebate scheme? So this Bill really is giving carte blanche to the Medicare officers and the Government to establish a cash rebate scheme and the operation for payment of that scheme?

PARA.TAB: To my way of thinking, that is like buying a pig in a poke. I really would be very concerned about that. As the Minister has indicated, there is a thought, is there not, that there will be a requirement for the production of a tax file number? I do not want to prejudge that one way or the other, but I would have thought that before we pass this Bill it will be a good idea for the Government to come down with its clear-cut proposal as to what the cash rebate scheme will be. Could the Minister comment on that?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the financial impact statement here of just over $2 million is to cover the cost of staff and systems development work, and nothing further. I have given the assurance, and I can only say it again, that the major work for this proposal in terms of the cash rebate repayment will depend on amendments to the Child Care Act, and nothing can proceed until that whole issue is debated in this place.

—Is there not a more efficient method of providing for the child-care rebate? The people who will be eligible for the rebate are in fact earning income. Therefore, would not a simpler approach be that part of the income as decided by the Government, as the Minister was indicating before, be eligible for a tax rebate and that it could all be done through the taxation system without any substantial cost—and certainly without the cost of $2.5 million? I would have thought that that might be the way of going about it. Can the Minister explain to the Committee whether that has been given consideration by the Government and, if it were given consideration, why was it rejected?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The important point is that many of the people who will be eligible for a cash rebate for child care do not earn income. They will be students and all sorts of people who simply do not earn income. They will not be eligible for a tax rebate in the ordinary way that Senator Harradine is floating as a proposal.

PARA.TAB: All along, one of the concerns of those of us who have worked in the child-care area has been to recognise that women's lives, income and access to study and work have to be addressed in a particular and special way. The standard proposal that Senator Harradine is floating would quite clearly not operate for thousands of women who would, under our proposal, be eligible for a rebate for child care—women who would not be earning any income and would not be eligible for the payment of any tax at all, in many cases. I note Senator Harradine's comments. I will certainly make sure that we give them consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand perfectly well that the proposed rebate is to cover parents using child care while in employment, training, studying or looking for work. Clearly, the people in the three latter categories may not be earning income. That is not the point. An overwhelming number of persons eligible for this child-care cash rebate will be earning money. Perhaps the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) would be able to give the chamber an estimate of how many people in each of those categories will be eligible for a child-care cash rebate.

PARA.TAB: In her second reading speech, the Minister indicated that an estimated 230,000 families with 358,000 children will benefit from the scheme. So she must have a fair idea of how many of those people are in employment, how many are in training, how many are studying and how many are looking for work. At least in respect of those who are in employment, has the Government considered making the child-care cash rebate part of the taxation system and, therefore, not a substantial burden on the taxpayer, which it will inevitably be as a result of its payment through Medicare offices?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The projections for users of child care and for children who will benefit are not entirely aggregate figures but they are in large part. It is therefore very difficult to give details of how many of these people are women in the work force and how many are women studying, et cetera. The other important point is that women move between one category and another. So it is difficult to give hard numbers on that. I will certainly see whether the department has anything further which it can provide.

PARA.TAB: The proposed payment of the rebate through the Medicare offices was to recognise the importance of a return every week or fortnight to those families struggling to make ends meet. This is of great assistance to people, particularly those at the lower end of the income scale. Not many families can wait for a rebate at the end of the year.

It is also important to know that many families do not pay tax, but there are many others who pay a modest amount of tax and therefore would not benefit from the rebate in the same way. This measure is to take account of the needs that we know many families express. There needs to be ease of access to the payment of child care. It needs to be in a place that those families are familiar and comfortable with and the payment needs to be paid regularly so that they are not out of pocket over the long haul in dealing with the very important cost of child care.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not necessarily suggesting that it should be done by way of a rebate at the end of the year but perhaps done in the same way as the spouse rebate. That rebate is retained fortnightly by the employee in his or her pocket. In my view, that is one of the ways the Government should have considered overcoming this problem. I will leave it at that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, that results in the same problem; the DSR is retained by the taxpayer. I remind Senator Harradine that many of the users of child care are not taxpayers.

—I come back to my point. I now ask the Minister directly: how many of the users of child care are taxpayers? I understand that the bulk of them will be taxpayers. We are talking about parents who are in employment, training, studying or looking for work. In the Minister's second reading speech she said that there are 230,000 families who receive child care. I am trying to reach a situation which will assist the Government in implementing child care in a more efficient and cost effective way. I am not trying to make any points. I am just asking the Minister to take that on board. At some stage can the Minister please give me those figures I have requested.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will follow on from the issues that Senator Harradine has been addressing. I am glad to see that, in fact, despite the response of the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) on the second reading, it is not just the Opposition, including me, that have concerns about what the Government is up to, but clearly all speakers in this debate have concerns about this matter. Perhaps the Minister should look in the mirror and ask herself why she should be so out of step with honourable senators who are very supportive of child-care assistance for Australian families but are very concerned about what the Government is up to.

PARA.TAB: The Minister said in her second reading speech that Senator Newman had got it wrong. She said that I was devoted to maintaining my wrong position, that I was trying to draw red herrings across the trial and that I was deliberately muddying the waters. She also said that it is not true what I said about what the Government is up to. The trouble I have with that is that on 6 May the Minister told the Senate, in an answer to a question from me, that tax file numbers would be provided to Medicare offices. No doubt the Minister remembers that herself.

In the Estimates Committee C hearings on 10 May I quoted from Hansard and reminded the Minister what she said. I said, `That is the answer you gave' and she said, `Yes, it was'. There is no doubt that that is what the Minister said was going to happen. During the estimates committee hearings the officers had quite a bit to say about this whole matter as well. The committee was told by Mr Wight:

SPEECH.PARA: The intention at this stage is that those administrative arrangements will include carers providing their tax file number to become approved carers.
Mr Wight went on to say:

. . . the Health Insurance Commission will be issuing the carer provider number, one of the requirements to approve a carer is that the Health Insurance Commission has received the tax file number, because that will be part of the approval process. So it has to be the Health Insurance Commission.

So if I have got it wrong, that is where I got it wrong from. Senator Tate was also, despite the fact that he is a member of the Government, obviously a bit concerned about what was going on too. He asked some intelligent sorts of questions as befit an intelligent man. Some of the things that I would like to draw to the Minister's attention are that this same Mr Wight, further on in the committee hearing, said:
We have looked at a number of alternative methods of doing it, but that was the proposal that the Government has accepted.

Where am I so wrong when I say that the Government is moving down the track to extend the use of tax file numbers, and that we are very concerned because they are going to be given to the Health Insurance Commission? I do not know whether the Minister has missed a cog along the way, but that is what we are concerned about. As I said in my speech at the second reading stage, not only is it an extension of the tax file number, but also, as far as I know, it is the first time that somebody who is not a beneficiary of Government revenue will have to provide his or her tax file number.

PARA.TAB: In this case, it is not the people who will get the child care who are being asked to provide their tax file number, it is the person who will be providing the service. In the previous extensions of the tax file number, it was not the provider who had to provide the tax file number; it was the person who was receiving the Government revenue. There is some argument for that, with proper privacy protection, but not for this.

Mr Bansemer, another official at the estimates hearings, was also good enough to acknowledge that this proposal is subject to privacy concerns and said that advice was being sought about it. Did the Government go to the Privacy Commissioner? No. As I understand it, in rough terms, the Law Reform Commission has a contract with the department to re-do all the children's legislation. It has been asked to look at the amendments to the Child Care Act and also to have a chat to the Privacy Commissioner.

I would have thought the Government would have realised that this is a very sensitive issue. It is a proposal fraught with difficulties and political sensitivities, and fears on the part of citizens of an invasion of their privacy. Before the Government even told the department that—in Mr Wight's words—this was the proposal that the Government had accepted, it should have gone to the Privacy Commissioner and said, `How would we go if we went down this track?', and tried to push the Privacy Commissioner into a corner.

Senator Harradine's questions were pretty interesting. As I mentioned at the second reading stage, at the time of the last election, the coalition had a policy for extra child-care assistance. We had a proposal as to how it could be regulated without an invasion of privacy. In the estimates committee hearings, I asked whether the department had considered the coalition's proposal that the Tax Office provide a registered carer's number to child carers which would be quoted on all rebate claim forms.

I still think that was a very reasonable way to go. It meant that if one wanted to care for somebody's children, one would get from the Tax Office a child carer's number which would be quoted on all rebate forms by the person who was receiving the child care. That is not an unreasonable way of providing some sort of supervision of the system to prevent fraud without going down this dangerous track of extending the invasion of privacy of the citizen.

The department did not give me a direct answer as to whether it had investigated this proposal—sometimes one only realises this after studying the Hansard a few days later. The department suggested it was basically the same proposal; I presume it means the same proposal as the Government's. It certainly is not. It worries me, when I see that answer now, to realise that, if the officer really meant what he said, it shows a pretty keen lack of understanding of this whole problem of privacy.

I do not want to prolong this debate, but I am concerned that the Minister can get up here and, by throwing rocks around the place, think that she has been pretty smart. There is real concern on all sides of this Parliament—I remind the Minister of Senator Tate's concern—about what the Government is proposing. We are being asked to support legislation which will mean expenditure of over $2 million which will plan to put a system in place—and I never suggested anything other than that in my speech—about which we have no information.

We flag pretty strongly to the Government that we will not support this legislation if the Government is going to extend the use of the tax file number in the manner which, it appears from the estimates committee hearings and from the Minister's own answer in Question Time recently, it is. We will not support that sort of measure. If the Government does not want to waste $2 million, it might start changing direction right now. I am very glad, for the sake of both the Government and the taxpayers, that the Government has sufficient warning. It now has plenty of time to reassess the direction in which it is going.

I did not quite get the Minister's words down, but in response to Senator Harradine she gave me the impression that maybe the Government was moving position on this and that it was looking to establish a method for the keeping of separate information. I would like to know what the Minister really meant by that. After all, the critical issue is that there cannot be data-matching. We have to keep this sort of information on citizens separate, so that perhaps under another government of the future there can be no opportunity for big brother and for the George Orwell view of the world to take over in Australia. We do not want the government of the day to have a massive database on all citizens.

This is a proposal with which the Government seems to be going forward unthinkingly. Both the Minister and the department seem to be going along helter-skelter, refusing to acknowledge that it could even be a problem, instead preferring to chuck rocks at me as if somehow that will make it all go away. It will not go away and the Government should be thankful for the fact that this chamber is flagging the view right now that there will not be support for the sort of proposal we think it is on about.

This proposal is canvassed in the Hansard of both Question Time and Estimates Committee C. If the Government is walking away from that, we would like to know that and we would like to know which way it is going now. Perhaps it might be appropriate for the Minister to tell us what she meant in her answer to Senator Harradine about establishing a method for providing separate information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a couple of things clear. Firstly, we are very concerned about privacy in this area; I think I have said that. Secondly, we note Senator Newman's comments, particularly her fairly clear indication of what sort of legislation she would accept. Thirdly, I say again that it is a proposal under consideration at this stage.
—Which the Government has accepted, according to this.

—I wish to make it clear what I am saying. I am saying that the Government is looking at how best it can be done. It is not finalised or set. We note Senator Newman's comments. I would like to simply draw to her attention a comment I made on page 254 of the daily Hansard. In answering a supplementary question from Senator Newman about what the Health Insurance Commission amendments might refer to, I said that the Health Insurance Commission would be looking, for example, at the new database that would be needed. I went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not covered under the Medicare arrangements and will be quite separate from them.

I think Senator Newman is highlighting the fact that we are in a state of confusion here a little bit. I was saying that there is a proposal and it is not definite. Senator Harradine asked how we can discuss this if it is not definite. Today we are discussing enabling legislation only, to enable the Health Insurance Commission to proceed with its necessary basic work. The work of establishing the process for how the cash rebate will be dealt with is not definite at this stage. I appreciate Senator Newman's comments, and when the time is right I will certainly allow her time to discuss them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will certainly discuss them whether the Minister allows me or not. I do not want to sound ungracious, and I thank the Minister for her response. Why did she say to the Senate on 6 May that the tax file numbers would be provided to the Medicare office? Is that not true?

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is being considered; it is part of a proposal. I cannot say it any more clearly than that. Nothing is finally decided.

—I thank the Minister again. Mr Chairman, I am sure you will understand why the Senate is fairly uncomfortable—certainly I am, and I gather there is more disquiet elsewhere—with the answers we are getting. We are getting answers from the Minister and from her officials. Honourable senators should not forget that we also had them during the election campaign, as I referred to in my speech. It was made clear that there was going to be use of the tax file number. When the Australian Privacy Foundation asked what all this was about, Minister Staples' staff and Mr Gration gave total assurances, which were confirmed and written down, that there would not be the use of the tax file number. Australians have already been misled, at the very least, on this issue. It is very difficult to accept what the Minister is now telling us with the certainty that we know where the Government is going on this issue.

PARA.TAB: It says that it is only a proposal, but the officials have said that it is a proposal that the Government has accepted. Those are the words in the Hansard. The Minister is trying to suggest that what she said to the Senate that tax file numbers would be provided to Medicare offices may not be the case. During the election campaign we heard that, yes, there are going to be tax file numbers; and no, there are not going to be tax file numbers. We just cannot trust the Government. While we have made it clear we are not prepared to stop this enabling legislation going through because it will only expand the role of the Health Insurance Commission in terms of planning, we are extremely concerned about what the Government is up to. There is no clear message, and we cannot get clear answers.
Bills agreed to.
Bills reported without amendment; report adopted.
Bills (on motion by Senator Crowley) read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to yesterday's letter from the Secretary to the Department of Transport and Communications in which he makes it clear that the Government knew some weeks ago about technical deficiencies in the MDS tender process—that was at the time of the legal challenge. What action was taken at that time? When was the Minister first made aware of the problem? Why was legal advice not sought at that time? Why was it left until last week to obtain advice from Mr Gyles QC?
—I think that Senator Hill—particularly as Senator Hill is a lawyer—would be able to answer that question himself.
—Not a very good one.

—Well, I do not know about that. He could examine the advice that I intend to table in the Parliament this afternoon—in fact, I will take the opportunity of tabling it now—which is the advice of not only Mr Gyles QC but also the Attorney-General. I had no difficulty with tabling the AG's advice but, of course, I had to check with the Attorney-General himself, and he indicated to me that he has no difficulty with my tabling it either.

PARA.TAB: The events were that after the problem with the five per cent, the lack of deposit requirement, was discovered—and that was the first occasion, not only since I have been Minister in the portfolio but, to the best of my knowledge, in a number of years prior to that, that there has been any evidence of any system failure in the department in respect of tender processes—I asked the secretary to my department to do two things: to investigate the issue immediately as to what happened and why it happened; and to carry out a rigorous examination of all of the tender processes that the department had been responsible for during that time. I might add that I said `everything', and I am told that that even included examination of tenders for the acquisition of computer equipment, for example.

Following that, the secretary to the department advised me that the investigation in fact was already under way. I might add that one of my ministerial colleagues did say to me at the time, when I was explaining to him what I proposed to do, `If you examine any process with the level of scrutiny that you have asked for—any process—you are almost bound to find something'. Be that as it may, I saw that I had no other responsible choice.

I became aware of the problem when, following that examination, I had a meeting with officers of my department and the Attorney-General's Department which indicated to me that there could be a potential problem in respect of defects in the drafting. At that point in time, a number of options were being fairly rigorously debated between the lawyers themselves. I had also asked Mr Evans to ensure that, if it was desirable, as well as AG's being involved—`you get a fleet of lawyers onto this' I think was the expression I used—he should have access to the best possible advice from the private commercial bar.

Over a period of time, that developed to a point where I considered that the only responsible action for me to take, in terms of how finely balanced some of these options were—they are laid out in the advice, I might add, for the Leader of the Opposition's benefit—was to take the matter back to Cabinet at the very first opportunity available to me, which, of course, was yesterday, which is what I did.

In conclusion, I say to Senator Hill in response to his question that I think the reasons for this will be obvious when he reads not only the advice from the QC from Sydney who was engaged in this matter, but also the advice provided to me by the Attorney-General. I table both advices.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question because I am not sure that the advices will, in fact, detail the timetable, which is what I was particularly seeking. We now understand that the Minister asked the department to search for other possible examples of systemic failure. Will the Minister tell me when he asked that? Was it before or after the court case during which Mr Evans clearly was aware of a failure in relation to the MDS procedure? If the Minister was aware at that time, why was the advice of Mr Gyles not sought at that time?

—This will be found in the documentation I have just referred to. At the time the matter went to court in Perth I was involved in discussions with the Commonwealth's legal counsel in Sydney and said at that time, when I was advised they were going to Perth, that it would be a good idea, considering the fact that the Government has always intended to restart the MDS process as soon as possible, to ascertain whether, in discussions with Mr Stokes's legal counsel, it would be possible to settle this issue on a basis that would be satisfactory to both parties. The legal advice I got at the time was that that would be a perfectly appropriate thing to do and, indeed, it was done. Meetings were held between—
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. I refer to the Minister's announcement yesterday regarding conditions of service for defence personnel. Can the Minister inform the Senate how the establishment of a framework of conditions of service for Australian Defence Force personnel deployed overseas will lead to a more timely resolution of these matters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Senate might be aware, in the past conditions of service for ADF members deployed overseas were authorised under several pieces of legislation and were also administered in a range of different departments. For example, tax concessions, of course, were administered by the Treasury; deployment allowances by the Department of Industrial Relations; and compensation by the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

PARA.TAB: When decisions were being made on a case-by-case basis, it sometimes resulted in delays and situations where personnel were deployed overseas without knowing exactly what their entitlements would be. With the establishment of a framework of deployment conditions of service, these conditions will no longer be made on a case-by-case basis. The establishment of the framework coordinates the authorisation of the entitlements so that delays will not occur in the future.

In the future, a deployment will be declared warlike or non-warlike and the full range of service conditions associated with each situation can be assumed approved. The declaration of deployment, warlike or non-warlike, will be made by the Minister for Defence and that will be done in consultation with the Prime Minister in each case. The Government has also approved an enhanced defence home loan assistance benefit for ADF personnel who served or are serving in Cambodia, Somalia and the former Yugoslavia.

For example, soldiers who have completed operational service in Somalia will now have a waiver of the six-year qualifying requirement and an additional three years of loan subsidy and may, depending on whether they have any further service, have the maximum loan subsidy period extended from 20 years to 25 years. The Government hopes that this framework will provide a substantial incentive to personnel returning from these areas to invest in their own homes. The benefit will now be available, of course, for future overseas deployments that are also declared warlike.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I just want to give the Minister four minutes to answer the question. From what the Minister previously said, it would seem that he became aware of the matter some couple of weeks ago when the five per cent issue blew up. But from what the secretary to his department says, the secretary was aware of this technical difficulty before the proceedings to which the Minister referred, which were at least some six weeks ago. So what I specifically want to know is: when did the secretary or senior officers of his department become aware of these technical difficulties that were raised, or were considered, during the court case; and when did the Minister become aware of those difficulties?

—Can I just say that all of that will be made available to the Senate. I will answer the question now, Mr President, but I just indicate that all of the papers will be made available to the Senate. The situation was this: the department became aware of technical defects in the determinations some time early in February. That was confirmed in advice from Attorney-General's some time between 19 and 22 February. I would point out, of course, that the federal election was called on 7 February, but written advice indicated that that was the case.

PARA.TAB: Written advice to the department at that time was to the effect that the court action in Perth would be successful—that is, the Commonwealth would succeed in having its revocation validated by the court—and it was determined at that time, on legal advice, that these technical defects would be corrected at that time. The court case in fact did not have that effect but, effectively, the court—and this is what I was explaining when I got cut off before—took over the process on the basis of agreements that were reached, and this is referred to in Mr Gyles's advice, between the parties.

My involvement was as I described it. The Commonwealth's lawyers met with Mr Stokes's lawyers on the morning before the matter went to court and a satisfactory arrangement was made between both sides, because we were just as anxious as everyone else to get the MDS process under way. That matter was later ratified by the court in these terms—I quote the court order, and this is what was conveyed to me: that the Commonwealth should `accept and treat as valid any tender or revised tender complying with a ministerial direction under which the tender process was conducted'. That is the advice that was given to me.

As Mr Gyles says, and I do not dispute it, that was advice which any layman could accept as good advice, and that is the advice I got—in other words, that the court process had validated the remaining tender process. And that was the advice that I received. I became aware for the first time that a far more significant difficulty existed, in terms of that advice being incorrect, after I initiated the investigation and re-examination that I referred to about a fortnight ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question, and I will press it a little further. The Minister said that he became aware recently of a more significant consequence, or some such expression. But when did he first become aware of the technical deficiencies that are referred to by Mr Evans in his letter that was made public yesterday? What subsequently caused the opinion to be sought from Mr Gyles QC?

—I thought I had answered that. What caused the opinion to be sought from Mr Gyles QC was my request to the secretary to the department—and I think a responsible one—that, as well as having Attorney-General's review all tender processes, the department should seek the assistance of, I said, the best available commercial silk we could find. That answers precisely the last question asked by Senator Hill as to why we sought the advice.
—When did you know?

—I have just answered that question also. Over the period, I became aware that the understanding the department had reached on legal advice—and I said before that I will make this available to the Senate—was that this court order, and it is very precise in its terms and I was certainly told about this—
—Why won't you tell us? When did you know?

—I have just answered that three times. It was, as Mr Gyles said quite reasonably, something that a layman could be expected to accept. We have now had legal advice that that assumption was not correct.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of members of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association branch parliaments of Papua New Guinea, Western Samoa and Vanuatu. The purpose of their study tour is to exchange views on parliamentary practice and procedure with their colleagues in this Parliament and in the Queensland and Northern Territory parliaments. On behalf of all senators, I take great pleasure in welcoming them to the Senate and trust that their visit is informative and enjoyable.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. I ask the Minister to explain why the Government has taken action to protect all shipwrecks over 75 years of age, and could he explain the purpose of the associated six-month amnesty relating to shipwrecks and their relics.

—I suspect it makes a bit of a change to be talking about the consequences of disasters of previous generations. The blanket declaration concerning shipwrecks that we have made is designed to ensure that the wrecks and their relics are protected from disturbance, damage and plunder. Shipwrecks have great historical significance and are a very valuable recreational and tourist attraction, although that is secondary to the fact that they are so fundamental to an understanding of Australian history. Shipwrecks can make an important contribution.

PARA.TAB: Like many other areas, this is an area in which the Government cannot make a contribution alone. We require the assistance of the community and, for that reason, we have been undertaking a fairly fundamental community awareness program and campaign aimed particularly at the diving community and people interested in antiques and their collection.

To supplement that program the Government has introduced an amnesty from 1 May to 30 October 1993 so that people who had a relic in their possession before 1 April may report that without penalty. The object of the amnesty is not to confiscate those relics, but to acquire information about lost aspects of our maritime history and record that on a register.It is very important that we do receive the cooperation of the diving community and to date, substantially, we have been doing so. The dive shops, dive clubs and dive magazines have been giving us a lot of support and distributing material to divers so that they become sensitive to the importance of historic relics under the sea.

The shipwrecks were described previously as time capsules. Things are preserved remarkably well under water and have a capacity to be studied and tell us things about our history that otherwise might not be available. It is an important initiative; one that I am pleased to be associated with and for which, to date, I am pleased to say we are getting a significant level of cooperation and support.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Does the Minister accept that, under him, the actions of officers of his department have repeatedly undermined the Government's policy on pay TV? Is he aware of a widespread view within the communications and electronic industries that his department has pursued a deregulatory communications policy without any regard to the national interest? What will he do to ensure that the Department of Transport and Communications actually serves the Government and stops trying to run it? Does he consider that a Senate select committee could assist him in achieving that aim?

—In respect of the first part of Senator Bourne's question, no, I do not accept that officers of the department have undermined the Government's policy on pay television, nor do I think that any of the evidence supports that. What has happened—and I regret it—is that unnecessary confusion in the industry has been caused by two identifiable problems: firstly, the failure to impose a deposit as had previously been imposed in respect of tenders; and, secondly, the problem with this drafting matter which has now had the consequences that it has indicated. I might add that my advice is that, as a result of this scrupulous, rigorous examination of all of the tender processes, there are no more problems with this process. But that, I have to say, could hardly be termed as undermining the process.

PARA.TAB: Am I aware of industry views about a deregulatory approach? Of course I am. I respect the Democrats' position on this. We have in fact debated this in the Senate before, because this essentially revolves around an ongoing argument between the relative merits of price based and merit based systems of allocation. All I can do is repeat what I said earlier. The Opposition, of course, supported the Government's position on the price based system. As Senator Bourne has quite correctly said, Senator Alston went far beyond the Government's position on price based processes.

I have extensively looked at the application of both merit based and price based systems around the world. On balance, in my view a price based system returns a better real value for an asset than a merit based system; that is, any judgment made by a government body or a government appointed body. On balance, the validity and the viability of a company are no better determined—and that is the very least we can say about it—by a merit based than a price based system. One of the problems with the merit based system—and have a look at one of the more recent examples—

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody talked about a merit based system.

—That is in fact the crux of this argument. The process of allocating the third commercial television licence in Perth took over two years, cost the public a fortune, resulted in something like 15 separate legal actions being launched in respect of it—which is inherent in such a subjective system—and, at the end of the day, robbed the taxpayers of a very large amount of money. As I say, I accept the Democrats' philosophical position on this matter but, with respect, disagree with them.

PARA.TAB: What will I do to ensure that DOTAC serves the Government and stops trying to run the Government? Rather than answering that question in four minutes I can, I think, answer it very effectively by tabling the report from the Canberra Bulletin of Public Administration about the very significant achievements of this department over the last five years. I will table that, but there is something in it that I think is relevant and which the Government has to accept responsibility for. Page 15 of this document lays out the Ministers who have been in this portfolio. Anecdotal evidence has it that a Minister spends an average of about a year in a portfolio, which I think is unsatisfactory. What this graphically demonstrates—and I was well aware of it at the time—is that when I assumed portfolio responsibility for this department in May last year I was the fourth Minister in less than a year to do so. That is entirely unsatisfactory.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. My question is prompted by the fact that small business is Australia's fastest growing area of industry and that the most dynamic exporters identified by the recent McKinsey report are predominantly small and medium sized businesses. Is the Government taking any measures to facilitate this growth and encourage small businesses to join the 700 identified by McKinsey as meeting the challenge of the export drive?

—Senator Colston has quite rightly identified the importance that the McKinsey report accords to the role of small business in our economy. Manufactured exports, particularly from the small and medium size firms, are improving dramatically. This has not just happened by itself. It has happened as a result of a number of government decisions to assist small and medium size businesses to export.
—In spite of your Government's decisions.

—Senator Macdonald abhors the fact that the Government would assist small business to export. After his recent performance in the election campaign on behalf of local government and the GST, why anyone would believe anything Senator Macdonald says is beyond me. We have established a number of conditions to help small business. They include low inflation, industrial harmony, competitive tax, depreciation on investment allowances, productivity growth and increased profits. This policy environment has resulted in over 20 per cent growth in manufactured exports over the past year and augurs well for the future.

PARA.TAB: Under these circumstances, we have a new breed of emerging exporters in Australia. Last year these 700 emerging exporters, which were identified by McKinsey, exported over $8 billion worth of exports. It is estimated that within the next five years that figure will have doubled to nearly $15 billion. They have been assisted by government programs, particularly export access, which is a new program that has come on stream in the past 12 months. This program will help us to get the 6,000 further firms that McKinsey identifies as being available for exports into the export market.

Yesterday I had the opportunity to attend my first National Small Business Forum. Some 20-odd small business organisations were in attendance, representing tens of thousands of small businesses across Australia. Those small business organisations were very constructive in putting forward ideas on how further assistance could be provided to the small business sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did they ask you about the payroll tax arrangements?

—Senator Kernot interjects about tax arrangements. They did raise a number of those issues. Minister Griffiths and I indicated that we will arrange for them to have access to the Treasurer and other senior Ministers in the Budget process to put forward their views about these tax matters. It is only appropriate that it be done that way. It is not my job or that of any other Minister to speculate about tax changes prior to the Budget being announced. It was an excellent forum, and I look forward to participating in such forums in the near future.

PARA.TAB: The export access program has already had some very successful outcomes. Of its first 80 clients, 86 per cent already have an indication of an export order. That is in the first nine months of operation. We are looking forward to that progress being further added to over the next 12 months. This is where government and small business can cooperate for the benefit of Australia as well as small business.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many small businesses have gone bankrupt under your policies?
—It is unfortunate that people such as Senator Macdonald do everything possible to talk down the success of small business rather than talk it up. But that is the role of the Opposition.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is it correct that at all times the Government's intention, in relation to MDS licences, was to have a pooling system, as described in the MDS information paper prepared by the department in December last year? I note that the Minister nodded, so we can save time by his not having to answer it. Why, then, did the Minister proceed to sign a determination on 7 January which prescribed quite a different approach involving the sequential allocation system and which was strongly criticised by Gyles QC, who said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . such a procedure will give rise to its own set of considerable difficulties in relation to allocation . . .
Before signing that determination of 7 January, did the Minister read it? Did he realise that it conflicted with the information paper? Did he seek or receive any written legal advice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston has proved me wrong again. I said to my staff this morning that I did not think even Senator Alston could ask a question like that with a straight face, and he has proved me wrong. Senator Alston has no doubt seen the determination, seen the gazettal notice and seen the information paper. Now what he has in front of him is the very detailed and complex legal advice that has been provided by both AG's and Mr Gyles on this.

PARA.TAB: There is one thing that Senator Alston said on AM this morning with which I agree; that is, this issue has to be considered completely separately from the issue of the non-deposit, and it does. The facts are that if this issue, however regrettable, had happened on its own, it would have been a matter of great regret but it would have been in that sense a non-event when one considers how arcane the legal difficulties were that caused this.

Senator Alston is seriously suggesting that when I picked up that determination to sign it, I should have picked up that in clause 3 of the determination there was a reference to `the licence' instead of `licences'; that I should have picked up that the normal statutory interpretation rule that singular also should read plural except where otherwise determined was potentially voided by references to `the licence' elsewhere in the determination; and that the frequency bands between 2300 megahertz and whatever the other determination was did not quite accord—in other words, that there were technical drafting difficulties in this determination which, in the event, indicated that a single licence could be applied for.

What I would then have to have done a fortnight later when the gazettal notice was published—Senator Alston might like to refer to the legal advice that says in fact that the determination was legally valid—was that I should have got the gazettal notice and then personally compared the gazettal notice against the drafting errors in the determination. I should have then determined, all on my own, that there was an error.

Senator Alston is asking why I did not read the determination. Yes, I did read it. Frankly, I thought that Senator Alston would stick to a reasonably believable line on this. I simply ask anyone who supports the proposition that Senator Alston has just put to me to read the determination, read the gazettal notice, read the information paper that then goes out, read the two advices that I have just tabled and come to a conclusion that it would have been a reasonable thing for me to have seen that drafting mistake in the determination. It is a nonsensical proposition.

What advice I did receive—and I was providing this in an earlier answer to Senator Hill when time ran out—I have provided to the Senate. I said to the people who were acting for us, `See if an agreement can be reached that will provide a satisfactory outcome to the court case'. The lawyers met and an agreement was reached, which was later ratified by the court which then took over the process in the way in which I determined. The court ordered us to treat as valid any tender. It was considered that that then rectified the earlier drafting problems. The precise advice I received on 8 April was:

ANSWER.PARA: The order enables the MDS tender process to be completed under the existing ministerial determination. All parties to the proceedings accepted the court orders as a workable way of proceeding.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is clear that the Minister is now acknowledging that he knew that the information paper proclaimed a pooling system and that what he actually signed for was a sequential allocation system. He has also confirmed that he did not understand the difference. At 7 January did the Minister have any advice at all that drew his attention to the fundamental differences in approach? Did the Minister of his own volition take any steps to inquire as to the significance of that document before he signed it?

—I have tried to put this in the answer I just gave. In sheer logic, how could I have had such advice when it was not until I signed the determination that later re-examination discovered the legal defects? What Senator Alston is putting to me is, in fact, a logical and legal nonsense. As Mr Gyles's advice has made clear—read it—the determination I signed was legally valid, but it gave effect to a policy process which would have been administratively very clumsy and difficult to—
—Mr President, I raise a point of order on the question of relevance. The Minister is being simply asked whether he had any advice, legal or otherwise, before he signed that document and whether he—
—I have just answered it.
—The Minister is talking about the court case and subsequent events. I am asking a question about 7 January: please answer it.
—There is no point of order.

—Senator Alston knows that it was not until the determination was at large that it was subsequently discovered that it referred to the singular instead of the plural. How could I have had such advice? I point out the nonsense. Of course I did not. I confess I did not pick up—those opposite should look at the megahertz bands quoted and the fact that the word `area' was used instead of `location'—in the determination that it was singular instead of plural.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to reports in today's media to the effect that there is to be a meeting of senior officials from ASEAN nations, as well as a number of other countries, in Singapore this week to discuss matters affecting regional security. Is the Minister able to inform the Senate as to whether or not Australia intends to participate in that meeting and, if so, what is the Government's assessment of the significance of the gathering?

—Australia will be represented at this week's meeting in Singapore which does represent a significant step forward in the implementation of Australian policy objectives on regional security. The meeting is essentially an officials level prelude to the ministerial level ASEAN PMC conference which is designed to sharpen regional focus on security questions and to develop some strategies by which governments can engage themselves more specifically in the consideration of appropriate policy responses to regional security in the post-Cold War world. Australia will be going to the meeting this week, and hopefully again in July, with some quite specific suggestions in this respect.

PARA.TAB: The need for a new approach to security has been a constant theme of the kind of approaches that we in the Australian Government have been making on Asia-Pacific political issues over recent years, in which we have stressed the concept of security as a multidimensional, multilayered problem in which we have developed a philosophy of common security, so-called, in which the basic notion is seeking security with others rather than against them. The Government has been specifically advocating the development of confidence building measures, transparency and greater cooperation among armed forces in the region.

A lot of progress has already been made in establishing the kind of security dialogue which is the necessary starting point for developing the kind of common security philosophy that I have just mentioned. We do not underestimate the sensitivities of our neighbours on these issues, nor the time frame that is involved in making significant progress, but we will continue to seek ways of taking forward these various ideas in close consultation and cooperation with other Asia-Pacific governments.

Let me add finally that we have been very heartened to see, in particular, the approach taken by the new United States administration on this issue in endorsing the need for multilateral dialogue on Asia-Pacific security issues and its attendance at the Singapore meeting. Like almost all countries of the region, we continue to believe that the United States has a key role to play in enhancing the security of the region.

In the past Washington has tended to play that role through its bilateral security agreements with countries of the region, including of course Australia, and it has been inclined to be less interested in a multilateral approach to these sorts of issues. The United States has now indicated that it sees value in complementing these bilateral ties with multilateral security discussions. Since we have been advocating such an approach over recent years, we warmly welcome that development.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Last week the Minister decried any suggestion that Christine Goode should be dissuaded from her offer to stand aside. Yet when the secretary to the department, Mr Evans, offered to resign, the Prime Minister would not have a bar of it. I ask the Minister: is there any explanation for this blatant double standard other than that the Prime Minister realises that if he acknowledges Mr Evans's acceptance of the doctrine of responsibility for the actions of one's subordinates, then the Minister would have no option but to do the same?

—Mr President, I absolutely fail to understand the logic of that question because I applied precisely the same standard to Mr Evans's decision as I did to Ms Goode's. That is, I assumed they were both—and they are—mature and sensible adults who could reach decisions on their own. As Senator Crane knows, I did not interfere with either decision, despite the absolutely outlandish suggestion of Senator Alston—laid out in Question Time—that I should have physically gone across to the department and tried to persuade Ms Goode not to do it.

PARA.TAB: As I said to others afterwards, just imagine the repercussions of that. Had I been so foolish—and I would never have been—to have gone across to the department, attempted to intercede in a personnel issue which was entirely a matter for the Public Service and had nothing to do with me, attempted to persuade anyone not to resign and failed, and that person had gone ahead and done it, can the Senate imagine what would be being said in here? It is a nonsensical proposition.

I accepted the advice I received in the first instance as being honest advice—knowing the integrity of the two officers concerned—and that that decision had been taken by Ms Goode by agreement with Mr Evans. I had no dispute with the course of action that Mr Evans proposed to me that he intended to take. That was also a matter for him. But I said to Mr Evans that I would say to the Prime Minister with regard to his proposed course of action that these errors, however regrettable—and they are indeed regrettable—would have to be set aside from the very significant record of achievement of this department over the last five years in the areas of shipping, the waterfront, road and rail, infrastructure, telecommunications, broadcasting and aviation. In my view, it is a significant record of progress over the last five years and one which the Government and the department should rightly be proud of.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. In the Minister's answer to Senator Bourne, he said that the Department of Transport and Communications had not undermined the Government. In the pay TV legislation drafted by his department, debated last November, is it not clear that the Government's mandated satellite delivery for pay TV was undermined by the free kick given to microwave? Is not this view of

QUESTION.PARA: departmental responsibility given further credibility by the determination drafted for the Minister by DOTAC in January which gave Mr Cosser automatic rights to convert narrowcast licences to broadcast? And, if it is not the case, why then did the Prime Minister himself allege that the department had notoriously misled Cabinet over the potential of microwave to supplement satellite delivery?

TALK.START.PARA: —I reiterate what I said and, in fact, confirm it. I apply to the word `undermine' what I think is the commonsense interpretation of that word—that these problems occurred with intent, that is, it was the cold-blooded, conscious intention of the department to subvert a policy. I do reject that because the facts speak for themselves. I have acknowledged that the Australian Democrats were the only people in this chamber who doubted the advice that we were given of the commercial viability of MDS—indeed, Senator Bourne has confirmed that that was her view, and clarified it—in that the Australian Democrats did propose to the Government during the negotiations that we should consider mandating narrowcast only for MDS.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot should read the full advices that were given to the Cabinet—both briefs that were given to me on the day that I met Mr Cosser—which laid out the considerable technical difficulties in attracting any significant level of support for MDS. That opinion of the department, which was, in fact, the opinion expressed, was echoed by widespread industry appreciation. I said in the Federal Court—and it has been confirmed—that others I consulted at the time, in particular the ABC, which does have a very good working knowledge of the broadcasting potential of MDS, said in the phone call I got from Mr Hill, `We were all wrong'. That expression `we were all wrong' referred to the commercial understanding we had that, because of the difficulties of this technology, it would not be financed or potentially financed in a way which would threaten the viability of the satellite.

I acknowledge that the Opposition also had that view and that if we had not had that joint view we would not have spent months putting conditions on the satellite involving the ABC and industry which were never put on MDS. That view was wrong. But, I assert again, it was not wrong because of some conscious intent on the facts of the department to undermine a policy. It was wrong because we all accepted advice about the commercial realities of the marketplace which the marketplace had a distinctly different view of at the end of the day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister avoided the last part of the question. Under the Minister's definition, can one notoriously mislead Cabinet without cold-blooded intent?

—Of course, one cannot. The Prime Minister was angry at that time, as I was, that the ABC's view was wrong. Industry sources, such as Mr Fred Kenyon, one of the most respected consultants to everyone at large on this particular technology, were wrong—that is, that it should never be backed by what he called `management types' for this kind of technology. Indeed, the Prime Minister was angry. From time to time the Prime Minister has made telephone calls, and this was not the first one that received publicity.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer the Minister to the opening paragraph of `Government guidelines for official witnesses before parliamentary committees and related matters, November 1989', which says:

QUESTION.PARA: In the Australian system of parliamentary government, and consistent with the traditional understanding of ministerial responsibility, the public and parliamentary advocacy and defence of government policies and administration has traditionally been, and should remain, the preserve of Ministers, not officials.

This being so, why is Senator Collins hiding behind his officials—allowing them to cop all the responsibility for the maladministration in his portfolio? Why will the Minister not do the right thing and stand aside?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will get to the heart of the matter: because this is not a question of policy. On this particular matter, I agree with Senator Alston: this is a matter of arcane legal drafting for which nobody, I thought, sensibly could even suggest that a Minister could be reasonably responsible. Today I tabled in the Senate advice from Mr Gyles QC and advice from the Attorney-General. It is all important but I will read out the two key paragraphs in the Attorney-General's advice that indicate what the problem was. They are contained in the Attorney-General's advice; honourable senators can read it themselves. The problem was as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In my view the notice of 18 January 1993 was defective in that it did not specify, as required by clause 4, the area—

will relate. What it did was set out a number of `locations'—eg `Sydney', Wollongong', `Brisbane', `Gold Coast' etc—and indicate the number of licences which would be available in each `location'. There is nothing in the statutory documents which is of any assistance in ascertaining the boundaries of the `locations'. It is not clear, for example, where the boundaries of `Sydney' end and `Wollongong' begin or whether there is a gap between them. It is not clear to me from the Radio Communications Act 1983 or the Determination what is meant by the `area' to which the licence relates. Given the clear objective of the Act to minimise interference (see Part IV (radio frequency planning); ss.24, 25, 25A (conditions of transmitter licences) and Part IX (settlement of interference disputes)), I think that the Determination must have intended that either be capable of being determined with certainty from the terms of the invitation to tender of itself.

Even if the contrary view is taken as to `area', I think there can be little doubt that for the notice to state: `the frequencies to which this tender relates lie within the bands 2076-2111 MHz or 2300-2400 MHz as specified in the MDS Band Plan' is not to specify `the frequency to which the licence will relate' as required by the Determination. The Frequency Band Plan prepared under section 19 of the Act on 9 June 1988 (as amended on 3 June 1992 and 23 September 1992), which I assume is the `MDS Band Plan' referred to, is of no assistance in allocating a particular frequency or frequency band to any particular licence offered.
That is the heart of the matter, and I have no doubt that Senator Alston would have picked that up instantly.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. In the quotation I cited from government guidelines the Minister picked up the word `policy' but he did not pick up the word `administration'. I quote the words again:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the public and parliamentary advocacy and defence of government policies and administration has traditionally been, and should remain, the preserve of Ministers, not officials.
I ask the question again: why is Senator Collins hiding behind his officials and allowing them to cop all the responsibility for the maladministration in his portfolio?

TALK.START.PARA: —What I previously said about this issue, and I stand by it again, is that Ministers should accept responsibility for maladministration in their departments when it can be demonstrated that that has been a systemic problem, in other words a continuing problem, which the Minister has done nothing about. I was made aware for the first time in the three years I have been a Minister and prior to that of a problem with process in the department. I immediately instigated an investigation, a re-examination of all of the tender processes, and provided this Parliament with a determination which will be achieved of placing all that before the Senate. I will discharge that obligation and, in so doing, I believe I have done everything that could have properly been required of me as a Minister.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Is the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service's endangered species program currently funding a study aimed at improving the conservation of the giant freshwater crayfish in the Gog Range of northern Tasmania? Is the study focusing on the area under imminent threat from a plantation establishment being conducted by the Tasmanian Forestry Commission with funding provided by the Commonwealth department of resources?
