During January, investors in satellite pay TV, including the media mates of the Federal Government, started worrying about the capability of MDS technology to distribute a complete pay TV service.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will tell you what. If they were my mates, I would hate to do something to upset them.
—Is that right?
—Have a look at the wall to wall press.

—A lot of people are upset by what the Minister has done. That is why I am sure this saga will go on for the next few weeks, particularly when we have the findings from the Minister's department—and, I hope, from a Senate inquiry, as soon as we can get the Australian Democrats to agree to have one.

PARA.TAB: We had the amazing decision, based on what happened in January, to call off bidding for the MDS pay TV licences the day before the tenders were due to close. At this point it was clear that the Minister was not exercising authority over the tendering process for MDS pay TV licences. He claimed to be ignorant of the potential of MDS technology to provide a comprehensive pay TV service, despite meetings between departmental officials and representatives of Mr Steve Cosser, who had a clear intention of pursuing broadcast services using MDS technology.

In addition, in order to reach the decision to call off the MDS tendering process, the Prime Minister had to intervene with the Department of Transport and Communications. Surely this is a clear indication that Senator Collins was not exercising proper authority and control over the tendering processes being run by his department. This is especially the case, given that the Prime Minister felt the department had notoriously misled the Cabinet on the extent to which MDS might be used for pay TV.

Senator Collins was not keeping up with what his department was doing, or what it knew. This is, of course, if we accept the claim of Senator Collins that he was ignorant of the potential of MDS. It would seem extraordinary that the Minister was not aware of the capabilities of MDS technology.

Mr Cosser's intentions seemed clear. There have been numerous claims that industry representatives had discussed the issue with both the Department of Transport and Communications and the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. Someone is not being completely truthful and we have yet to discover who.

The fact remains that the Minister was not aware of the potential of MDS technology, and he should have been. If the department was aware of that potential and it did not inform the Minister of this, as it should have, the implication is that the Minister is not exercising enough authority within his department. Subsequent to the decision being made to call off the tendering process for MDS, it came to light that the decision was in conflict with the objectives of the broadcasting Act. Therefore, legislation was necessary to give effect to the Minister's decision.

This is yet another example of a government making decisions with regard to pay TV without properly looking at all the implications of the action. Additionally, the inevitable legal action followed with both Kerry Stokes and Steve Cosser launching legal proceedings for misleading and deceptive conduct in regard to the MDS tendering process.

The reason given by the Minister for abandoning MDS tendering was to stop `inferior technology' from coming onto the market. This conflicts with the original intention of the government legislation being technologically neutral and flies in the face of plans which were clearly under way to establish a broadcast pay TV service through MDS technology.

Even Senator Richardson noted on the Hinch program on 22 February that the Government `had a problem' when it realised that pay TV could not be provided by MDS to most of Melbourne and 70 per cent of Sydney. Not surprisingly, in March this year the Federal Court ruled that the Government had invalidly terminated the tender process for MDS pay TV.

The Government then offered an additional explanation for its decision on MDS technology and that was that satellite technology was the preferred option of the Government. This appears to contradict its original claims of the desirability of technologically neutral legislation governing the pay TV industry.

We then discovered yesterday that the reopened MDS tendering process, which only had 10 days to go before tenders closed, would have to be abandoned because the process was, according to Mr Roger Gyles QC, `invalid and of no effect in law'. This problem arose because of the technical difficulties which came about because the ministerial determination for the reopening process was gazetted incorrectly.

However, the secretary of the department became aware of these technical difficulties during the preparation of the case for the Federal Court proceedings some months before. For some inexplicable reason, this information was not passed on to the Minister until late last week.

TALK.START.PARA: —Correct.
—I see the Minister nodding his head. I would really like to know why the Minister was not informed earlier and, if he was, why did he not act earlier?

PARA.TAB: The whole unfortunate debacle with regard to the tendering process for MDS pay TV licences clearly shows that the Minister has not been exercising proper authority or control over the process. He did not keep abreast of developments in the industry; his department did not keep him informed; the Prime Minister had to intervene; and decisions were made without really looking at the full implications of those decisions. If this is not enough to show that the Minister has lost control and seems to have no authority over his department, we can look at the other side of the pay TV debacle, that of the tendering process for satellite pay TV licences.

The tenders for satellite licences closed on 28 April 1993, with speculation that the winning bids would be between $50 million and $80 million. The Government announced, however, that the winning bids came from UCOM and Hi Vision, with bids of $177 million and $212 million. It was immediately apparent that these successful applicants would have great difficulty in raising the huge amounts of money that they had bid. The tendering process had obviously been a farce. There was no requirement for a five per cent deposit in the tendering process, a requirement common to the MDS process and tendering for the third mobile telecommunication licence.

The Minister claimed that the change in policy to omit the requirement for a five per cent deposit was not pointed out to him by the department and that, therefore, he cannot be held responsible for the joke that the tendering process has become. The Minister then changed the tendering process so that, if UCOM and Hi Vision fail to finance their bids, the next highest bidder will have to find the five per cent deposit within three days of being advised it is in the running for a licence.

This has been described as unprecedented and heinous legislation, retrospectively changing the rules for a tender halfway through the bidding process. This also fails to address the other problem within the bidding process, that of multiple collapsing bids. It would appear that the department had been informed of the possibility of multiple bids but, again, it remains a mystery as to why the department failed to act to prevent this. It also remains to be seen why the Minister was not informed of the possibility of these bids and why he failed to act.

The problem is clearly that the Minister does not have control over his department. He has not exercised any authority or control over the tendering processes for pay TV licences. His department is not briefing him properly, and the Minister has not shown any desire to be briefed properly. The Minister is signing determinations and authorisations without having all the facts or, indeed, understanding what he is signing. That is a neglect of responsibility which he must accept, and his failure to do so is a disgrace. Like his senior public servants who have offered to do the right thing, he should stand aside.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Alexis de Tocqueville once wrote of the American republic in its infancy that the final frontier would be the courts. Had de Tocqueville toured Australia at a similar time, in the 1830s, I am sure he would have been astute enough to write that of the early Australian colonies; indeed, it could have been written at the turn of this century about the infant Commonwealth of Australia.

PARA.TAB: The final frontier in our political system now is undoubtedly the Australian judiciary. We really need to take that into consideration whenever we deal with legislation and matters of public policy. That is what is at the core of the debate this afternoon—whether the Parliament will be cognisant of the legal ramifications of what it does, not only in terms of legislation but also in terms of delegated authority over legislation. At all times we need to guard against making the Commonwealth liable to litigation, vulnerable to rebuffs in the courts and rejection of legislation in the courts or, equally, determinations being made by the courts that are at variance with public policy as set down by the Parliament of Australia.

This brings me to look momentarily at the Opposition's matter of public importance. It really is a repeat of a matter which the chamber debated a fortnight or so ago. That proposition had absolutely no impact upon public policy whatsoever; it had no impact upon the political process whatsoever.

This afternoon we have had a repeat performance. Again, the Opposition has failed to display any sense of originality of purpose. It is unable to cite a single example of wrongdoing at any level of the department or at any level of the Government. There is no evidence of ministerial failure apparent in the debate. Nothing has emerged at Question Time, nothing has emerged during the course of the debates and nothing untoward has been discovered in the process whatsoever. That leads me to conclude, not unreasonably, that the proposition before the chamber again this afternoon takes us nowhere. Justice could have been put in train a fortnight ago.

As Senator Collins made clear in his earlier remarks, Senator Alston is again endeavouring to make bricks without straw and, as in biblical times, that is an impossibility. He is not even endeavouring to achieve that hopeless end very successfully. All that we have seen this afternoon is a series of unbelievable assertions. This brings me to the observation that the current state of the coalition is very reminiscent of the Australian Labor Party after the 1961 general election. We had suffered a string of losses and had been defeated in a general election that we ought to have won. That was an election that the ALP ought not to have lost under Mr Calwell. There is no question that in our history we had a front bench that was devoid of strategy, just as exists in the coalition now. We had a party that for a time appeared to be devoid of hope, just as exists in the coalition now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you doing so badly in the polls at the moment?

—Just as the ALP in 1961 faced a decade in continuing opposition, so does Senator MacGibbon and the coalition now. We have just had another decade of frustration where members of the coalition can give vent to phobias, frustrations and obsessions. Quite frankly, as everybody in the political process in the country knows, the coalition effectively denied itself the right to govern. It denied itself the capacity to experience the dilemmas, the challenges, the pressures and demands of government and to understand and appreciate the complexities. Every MPI we see in this chamber demonstrates vividly and graphically the fact that there is virtually no experience of the government process whatsoever in those opposite. We are happy in government to let the coalition sit in comfortable impotence, perhaps for a decade or perhaps for an even longer time.

PARA.TAB: This afternoon we are really talking about arcane legal technicalities where singular may or may not mean plural. As Senator Collins made clear, had he not acted in the manner in which he did, with total ministerial propriety, the process could have been, unlikely or in a remote sense, open to abuse. It could have been open to manipulation or it could have been open to the unscrupulous. That may well have meant that it was open to litigation. We had the experience of the arguments, the long legal debates and the long legal charges and countercharges in Perth over the issue of the FM licence which took some two years and cost millions of dollars. We certainly do not want to see a repeat experience.

Frankly, broadcasting legislation and the broadcasting industry in this country, rightly or wrongly, for good or ill, has really become a lawyers' springtime and everyone is aware of that. Certainly everyone in the ranks of government is aware of that. The court may have had no choice but to award a licence to the unscrupulous—a remote possibility, but a possibility nonetheless—had Senator Collins not acted in the way that he did.

That brings me to the point of ministerial propriety. The Minister acted properly wherever there was an obligation to exercise ministerial discretion or authority. I do not believe that is in doubt. It is not possible in every situation for legislation to cover all the circumstances, particularly all the circumstances in the light of court rulings. It is impossible for legislation to anticipate every eventuality. But what we have seen time and again when the process has been subject to examination and scrutiny is that Minister Collins acted responsibly on the basis of advice, particularly on the basis of the advice from Mr Roger Gyles QC, as well as on the basis of advice from the Attorney-General's Department. Again, the process could not have been more straightforward, open and honest. A Cabinet determination was sought and the Minister acted to take matters to Cabinet, to lay out the legal advice and the available options. Again, he did nothing untoward in the process.

We are talking about dealing with matters sometimes in the small hours of the morning when complexities are compounded by fatigue. But, again, Minister Collins acted properly. There is no suggestion to the contrary. Maybe the option of a realignment or restructuring in the department needs to be looked at and canvassed at some appropriate stage during the life of this Government or at a time subsequent to the next general election. We have a vast bureaucracy here dealing with a vast number of complex, technical areas—a multitude of complex issues.

But this afternoon we can say with absolute certainty that when the Minister knew of the problems he acted. I have not heard anyone argue that to the contrary—not from any of the backgrounding of certain elements of the media and not from anything that has been said in the chamber. I take aboard the Minister's remarks earlier today about the number of Ministers who have occupied the portfolio. I thought that was a valid observation so far as the democratic process is concerned.

I want to deal very briefly with the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on 17 May. I think it is worth noting in the chamber the manner in which the Prime Minister sets out the passage of events and makes some pertinent observations. There is no doubt that Mr Graham Evans also acted with total and complete propriety. His judgment was understandable given the circumstances of the general election. There is no doubt that the legal advice, as the Prime Minister makes clear, could be understood by a layman. As a matter of fact, I think that legal advice puts that matter beyond doubt.

I want to put on the record in the Senate this afternoon that I have worked with Mr Evans over a long period in different capacities and in different policy areas. He is a man of very great ability and integrity, and I have never known him to act other than with total application, total propriety and a great deal of skill.

I also think it is worth while noting that the Prime Minister's letter—I intend to quote it—sets out in some detail the achievements of the Department of Transport and Communications over time. The Prime Minister stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Major legislative reforms have been implemented covering broadcasting and radiocommunications, and telecommunications and aviation have been opened up to competition with substantial benefits to consumers. The vexed question of the third runway at Sydney airport was dealt with and construction is underway. The Department has supported the reforms of shipping and the waterfront and it has been responsible for establishing new national bodies for the reform of rail freight and road transport.

None of that can be denied. When I first came into Labor politics in the 1960s the most vexed question facing the district in which I grew up, St George, was that of Sydney airport and the runway extensions. That problem alone, having been solved, is a great credit to the department. I think the Prime Minister has really put matters in a proper context and a proper perspective.

PARA.TAB: I turn briefly to Senator Bourne's remarks. She normally makes a thoughtful contribution. That could be said again of her contribution this afternoon. Nothing that Senator Bourne said in detail about ministerial responsibility could possibly suggest to anyone that Senator Collins ought to stand down. Nothing that Senator Bourne outlined, and I think it was a fair outline, as to the doctrine of ministerial responsibility could possibly suggest that Senator Collins ought to stand down.

I now turn to my friend Senator Cooney, who gave another outstanding performance in the chamber. As Senator Cooney made clear, the Opposition is endeavouring to set an absolutely ridiculous standard—a standard which has no application in the real world, which has no application in government and which has no point of reference to the requirements of actual government of the Commonwealth of Australia. All the media coverage has indicated to date that all the coalition is about is trying to score the very shortest term gain possible.

The coalition makes no contribution to public policy. It has no impact upon the political process and has no objective beyond giving Minister Collins a difficult time for two hours of an afternoon. What is the point of that? Surely people opposite can learn from the fact that after 10 or 11 years the Australian people do not respect that. They look for alternatives in public policy. What have we had today? We have had no perspective from those opposite on MDS, broadcasting or pay TV in the most general sense of the term. All we have had is just a little flak which we have had to deflect over a couple of hours.

I return to the question in hand. As Senator Cooney made clear, there is no evidence of dishonesty or impropriety. There is no suggestion that the Minister did anything other than follow the appropriate advice in detail and to the letter. In that respect, I draw attention particularly to the advice of 12 May 1993—followed to the letter. In every instance where it may be suggested, even remotely, that a flaw or a vulnerability existed in the Commonwealth's objectives, the Minister acted.

This afternoon we do not have before us any attempt to find a resolution. Senator Collins has not misled the Parliament; he has not misled the Cabinet; he has not misled the public. He has been open, honest and forthright in all his dealings with the chamber. Walter Lippman once made the observation that a democratic society cannot function without a capacity to detect lies. That is true. It was true of the United States; it is certainly true of the rest of North America and of western Europe; and it is certainly true of our own political system.

The problem that the coalition has this afternoon is that no lies have been told. We have mechanisms to detect lies which, though not perfect, are very effective: we have the Parliament, we have the media and we have opinion. But no lies have been told. There is not a single example of dishonesty. Nowhere has that been suggested. All we have, as Senator Tierney made clear, is a series of phobias and obsessions from those opposite in the area of the media. It is impossible for the coalition to talk about media without talking about the mates. This is extraordinary. If people knew the kinds of tensions that exist from time to time between government and some of the significant media players, they would dismiss that kind of nonsense for what it is: an obsession on the part of the Liberal and National parties. No lies have been detected because no lies have been told. None have even been suggested. For that reason alone, the Senate should not agree to this proposition.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! The discussion is concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—During Question Time today Senator Tierney referred to a debate in which I had participated in the Northern Territory Parliament nine years ago. I chanced my memory—and I confess it—and I am pleased to say I came up trumps. Senator Tierney quoted what I had said about ministerial responsibility in relation to a memo, which I correctly recalled had been signed by the then Minister for Housing, Mr Dondas, currently the Speaker of the Northern Territory Parliament, and asserted that the comments I had made about ministerial responsibility in terms of this memo did not relate to the memo. I chanced my memory, as I have said, and I have come up trumps.

PARA.TAB: I have the documents. I must give credit for this to the Clerk of the Northern Territory Parliament, a former officer of this Senate. They are pretty efficient up there. In about half an hour he has dug out the memos and the complete records of this debate that occurred in the Territory Parliament nine years ago. All I have to say is that Senate training of Clerks at the table must be pretty good. I am indebted to him. I will table this as a bundle of documents. It is fascinating—even after nine years—to read this.

The memo, as you will see when you read it, Mr Acting Deputy President, offered to relieve the Minister of his discretion in waiving interest penalty payments from public servants who had bought their own houses, to relieve the Minister of the problem of `the irritation to you of signing instruments on an almost daily basis'. What the memo went on to say was astonishing. I suggest to Senator Alston and some of his colleagues that they read this, because the Minister did not actually resign. In the final paragraph the memo said, `Whilst not strictly in accord with the letter of the Act . . .'. The Minister's department gave him a memo which proposed relieving the Minister of all of his discretion and having it exercised by the department—and this was a brand new Act of parliament that had only just been passed.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is unlawful.

—It is unbelievable. The memo advised the Minister that the action they were proposing for him to take was unlawful. I knew there was something extraordinary about this memo. It is a pity Senator Tierney is not here. It is that old story—and he is an educational expert—that a little knowledge truly is a dangerous thing. This is fascinating stuff because the Minister, despite this, did not resign. I give this undertaking to Parliament now: the day that I receive a memo from my department proposing a course of action to me which the department advises me in the memo is unlawful and I approve it, I will resign.

PARA.TAB: I would like honourable senators to refer to the memo from the old Minister—I am indebted to the Clerk of the Northern Territory Parliament for providing this—and also to refer to the first direction issued by the new Minister. It is worth reading, particularly the clause in response to the Minister's earlier discretion, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: It seems that people who could be described as being `without influence' have penalties imposed on them whilst people who might be described as influential get them waived.

I commend it. I table this afternoon as a bundle the memos referred to by Senator Tierney, for the extraordinary evidence they display about true ministerial impropriety and lack of responsibility, along with a number of pages of Senate Hansard of the time which honourable senators opposite who are baying for blood might do very well to read.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Defence--Defence Science and Technology Organisation

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the documents.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to speak to the Department of Defence, Defence Science and Technology Organisation, Commercial Activities Trust Account, report and financial statements of 1991-92 and the Department of Defence, Defence Science and Technology Organisation, Commercial Activities Trust Account, Australian National Audit Office report on accounts and records for 1991-92.

PARA.TAB: These reports were prepared for the financial year 1991-92 in a period when Dr Ward was the chief defence scientist. He is now retired and I would like to put on record in public the service that he gave the Commonwealth through the not terribly long period in which he was chief defence scientist. He fulfilled that role with distinction. I wish every success to the new chief defence scientist in his task, Dr Brabin-Smith.

The principal report deals with the commercial activities, the balance sheet, for the Defence Science and Technology Organisation. I have no quarrel at all with getting a return from the research work done by the Defence Science and Technology Organisation because it is a very big body and a very expensive body for the Australian taxpayer. Not too many people know that it is second in size as a research and development organisation only to CSIRO. As I say, there is no quarrel at all about getting a commercial return from that if it is possible because it is a very big national resource.

I have been a bit uneasy at some of the public statements that have emanated from the two preceding Ministers responsible for this—Minister Kelly and Minister Bilney—because they have tended to portray DSTO as a cornucopia of money that is just there to be plucked, a virtual licence to print money. Some of the statements they have made are more adulatory of their own cleverness at finding that there is a source of money there to be tapped.

It is a matter of balance. Of course there are civilian applications for some things that are done purely for defence purposes and the taxpayer and the nation should get any commercial benefit coming from the application of that research. But the basic point seems to me to be often overlooked: the Defence Science and Technology Organisation exists only because what it is tasked to do is not being done by civilian or private industry, for very good reasons. The basic role of DSTO is to do that research which is not being done and which is essential to support the defence of Australia and national security. As I say, it is a matter of balance.

I was in the United Kingdom recently. I believe it has changed its equivalent body into being a purely contractual research body. I think if that happens there is only limited value in having something like the DSTO. We cannot measure the success of the DSTO in terms of a balance sheet. Many of its greatest achievements would not be recognised until we got into a defence emergency and in that case it would be quite impossible to ascribe a financial value to it.

I welcome this report because it shows that people are thinking about the balance that is required in this area. Some of the points raised in the report revolve around the amount of effort that goes into setting up the sales organisation, preparation of the product for sale, and whether it is intellectual property, patents, hardware or software.

The audit report raises a number of points about the analysis, the need to identify and analyse cost overruns that were not always performed, the shortcomings in reviewing overhead rates and things like that, because it is always difficult in a big research body to specifically ascribe some of those overhead costs to a project and recover them from the client.

The scale of the profit reported here is only $184,452, which in the context of the commercial world is really quite small. It reinforces the need for balance. If all this work is being put into commercialisation we would hope that we would have a bigger return from it. I would also hope that the profits from the commercialisation would be retained by the DSTO without prejudice to its present budget.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation--Honeybee Research and Development Council

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not the first time that I have spoken in the Senate about the work of the Honeybee Research and Development Council. I want to congratulate the council on the work that it is doing for the honey industry.

PARA.TAB: Included in this report are: details of the honey research levy; the role and objectives of the Honeybee Research and Development Council; and details of research strategies and priorities. Matters relating to nutrition and disease are detailed on pages 15 and 16 of this report. Then there is information regarding resource management and the value of the industry. I was very interested in that section of the report which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The resource base for honeybees is being eroded for a number of distinct and unrelated causes:
. deliberate clearing of forested country for other agricultural purposes;
. clear felling for pine or other timber production or for woodchipping;
. destruction of useful nectar producing plants through uncontrolled burning or through regular controlled burning or other management practices;
.control of plants useful to beekeepers by biological or other means;
. rural dieback and the absence of adequate regeneration of nectar/pollen trees in rural Australia.
The terrible drought we are having in Queensland and New South Wales would be very detrimental to beekeepers. The report then talks about:

. the conversion of Crown land to reserves or National Park status combined with an increasing tendency by land managers to exclude beekeepers from servicing traditional apiary sites in these classified areas.
It goes on to state:

Council fully recognises the problems posed to beekeepers by the significant loss of useful nectar and pollen sources and acknowledges that this problem is likely to be exacerbated by competing demands on these areas, and by increasing pressures from the conservation lobby for the exclusion of all exotic flora and fauna from reserves and National Parks. The loss or potential loss of traditional nectar and pollen sources has been identified as the single major problem confronting the industry.

Undoubtedly, this would be a concern. We have to be very careful that the conservation lobby does not harm our rural industries in so many areas. That does not apply only to the honey industry; it can also apply to kangaroos. There is a concern about conserving kangaroos, but it is not realised that so many kangaroos in Australia eat up valuable grass where there is still some grass. In the early days not too many people had water supplies, and the more water was supplied, the more kangaroos seemed to hang around. At one stage my son John had a tremendous number of kangaroos and emus on his property in central Queensland, but a terrible flood a couple of years ago stopped the problems that he was having.

PARA.TAB: Access to most established bee sites on public lands is assured in the short term in all States at the present time but no State has any guarantee of future access, so the report says. The report also says that there is continued expansion of national parks, wilderness areas, World Heritage areas and special parks. This is probably not helping the beekeepers, who need to be assured of places where bees can be placed for the production of honey.

A number of years ago at home at Kingaroy we grew kiwi fruit, and we always had to bring hives of bees from various places so that they could pollinate the plants. I must say that the honey that came from there was very nice indeed. We still need bees to pollinate the avocado trees that we grow. Nice, light, clover honey is what I like best. I do congratulate the Honeybee Research and Development Council for the work that it is doing to try to ensure that the beekeepers in Australia have areas that are satisfactory for the bees to gather honey from.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to speak but briefly on the Australian Dried Fruits Board annual report for 1991-92. The Australian Dried Fruits Board, set up under the Horticultural Corporations Act 1987, replaced the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation. The report is for another particularly good year as far as production is concerned. The organisation represents one of the really good smaller industries in Australia that is well run, well organised and well-founded and which produces world quality fruits absolutely second to none. It has done a tremendous amount in the last few years with improved technology and research. Everything it does is now modern, and marketing is a particularly strong point in its activity.

PARA.TAB: I notice from the statistics in the report that prices for 1989 averaged out at $1,734 a tonne and for 1990 at $2,050 a tonne. But what the report does not show is that in 1991, for which the figures are still to come, the prices will be down and the overall results will not be as favourable as they were the previous year. The expectation for the 1992 season was for 102,853 tonnes of combined fruits, but for 1992-93 it was expected to be only about 50,000 tonnes because of bad weather, stress on the grapes and problems overseas. There is also a large carryover of about 60,000 or 70,000 tonnes from the previous year. So marketing will be a little bit difficult for this industry this year in comparison with the last year or two.

Australia consumes nearly 30,000 tonnes per year and our exports total about 45,000 tonnes a year. That puts us into fairly good company with the other producing countries of the world. We export to many countries, 21 of which import over 100 tonnes a year. Our biggest markets are Germany, to which we export about 18,000 tonnes; Canada, about 11,000 tonnes; Great Britain, about 8,000 tonnes; and New Zealand, about 5,000 tonnes.

These countries have the usual problems of expenses and costs. I am indebted to Senator O'Chee for drawing my attention to the fact—and I would like to draw Senator Collins's attention to this fact also but he seems to have left the chamber although I was expecting him to be here—that the port service charge to load a 20-foot container in Melbourne, destined for Europe, was $96.19 in 1990, $94.25 in 1991 and $91.95 in 1992.

We have heard of all of the enormous improvements that have occurred on the waterfront as far as costs and other things are concerned, but I would like to know who, with all of the benefits of reductions in price and labour et cetera, is getting the benefits? We do not seem to have been able to get that information and I leave it up to Senator Collins to perhaps advise us on his next visit to the chamber, if he is coming back.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is indeed a pleasure to follow Senator Archer on this particular issue as I know that he has done a lot of work over the years in relation to dried fruits. I want to speak on one very small part of the report of the Australian Dried Fruits Board, and refer to the comments on page 9 in relation to the cost of shipping. Senator Archer has tried on numerous occasions to obtain from Senator Collins an indication of who has supposedly received the benefits of this waterfront reform we are hearing about all the time. We never cease to hear from the other side of the chamber in Question Time—day in, day out—about the so-called benefits of waterfront reform. But this is what one of the users of the waterfront has had to say. The Australian Dried Fruits Board annual report says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . freight rates to Canada and New Zealand remain relatively high making these markets costly to service. With the continuing highly competitive nature of the international dried fruits industry and the proximity of Australia's competitors to the major markets, freight movements and reliability of shipping services will have a continuing effect on growers' returns and ultimately on the ability of the Australian Industry to export.
As Senator Archer has already said, we have seen that there has been very little change in the cost of loading a 20-foot container in Melbourne, from which most of the container trade goes out.

PARA.TAB: This report says that unless the users of the freight services start to get some of the benefits of this waterfront reform, we are not going to be selling into these markets. Canada, one of our larger export markets, is right next door to the United States of America. It has substantially lower transport costs than we have in getting its produce to market. That $91.95 charge in the 1992 year was not the cost of transporting the container; it was the cost of loading the container in Melbourne. Added to that, of course, is the cost of actually transporting it from Melbourne to the port where it will be disembarked. So there is not only that cost, but all the other transport costs on top.

The board is clearly saying that the Government has to get serious about waterfront reform. It makes it very clear that the cost of waterfront reform is not just something that gets passed around and we all put the hat in for the wharfies, but that waterfront reform should be about giving businesses a chance to enjoy the benefits of what they produce. Every extra dollar that we have to pay on the waterfront is a dollar that comes out of the pockets of a farmer who has produced this good. It is as simple as that.

This report speaks eloquent tomes in just those few simple paragraphs of the need for the benefits of waterfront reform—if there has been any waterfront reform—to be passed on. We cannot have a situation where farmers get a fairly low net return on their production, yet huge amounts are extracted in the process by people who do very little. It is quite absurd—Senator Panizza is shaking his head—that it would cost $91.95 to pick up a container off the wharf and put it on a ship and load it. It is not worth $91.95 to do that, especially when one considers the net return the farmers get for all the work they do throughout the entire season. I am saying, and the report is saying, that there is something very inequitable happening in Australia at the moment: the people who produce the real wealth are not getting a decent enough return on their hard efforts and hard labour.

It is absolutely critical that the Government really starts to get serious about waterfront reform. Senator Collins should start to answer some of the questions that Senator Archer has been putting to him so that we can ensure that the good people who are the backbone of this industry start to get their fair share of the money for the hard work and investment they put in. It is a great industry and this Government should not stand in the way of efforts to ensure that those people get a decent return for their work.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Employment, Education and Training

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Petition to the Court of Disputed Returns

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—On behalf of the President, for the information of the Senate, I present a petition to the High Court, sitting as the Court of Disputed Returns, relating to qualifications of members of Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President, I table a letter from the Minister for Finance relating to the cessation of the publication of Budget Paper No. 3.

—On behalf of the President, in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 32 of 1992-93—Efficiency Audit—Implementation of an interim greenhouse response—Department of Primary Industries and Energy—Energy management programs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Report No. 32 of 1992-93, which is an efficiency audit by the Auditor-General into the implementation of an interim greenhouse response, is quite damning in its criticism of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. Once again, we have to decide who was responsible for the action—or is it in this case the inaction?—of a department. Is the concept of ministerial responsibility still alive and well in Australia? It appears not from what we have seen so far in the Department of Transport and Communications, but now we have a matter of gross dereliction of ministerial duty in failing to establish that the department was carrying out government policy. I do not know whether the Minister will regard himself as not bound by the old principle of ministerial responsibility. He has not been sacked, stood down, suspended or criticised by his Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: I wonder whether this will just be another of those instances where a Minister has presided over what is clear incompetence without suffering any of the normal consequences that have flowed under the Westminster system in the past from that kind of behaviour. The question we have to ask is why the Minister allowed this situation to develop and to continue for so long. I will outline the failures of the department in this area in just a moment.

The fact is that a government instruction was given, government policy was set, public statements were made about what the Government would do and what its intentions were, but the Audit Office has found that the department did not adequately respond to the Government's instructions. Who is responsible for a government department's failure to respond to government determinations and decisions? Surely the Minister should be monitoring whether or not government policy is being implemented by his department. Yet we have no evidence whatsoever that the Minister is either concerned, involved or taking any kind of rap for this failure to implement a policy which was publicly stated.

By way of background, back in October 1990 the Commonwealth Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) and the then Minister for Resources announced an action package of immediate measures—I stress the word `immediate'—to improve the use of energy in Australia and to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Whether one is of the view that this is as urgent a matter as some people say is beside the point. The fact is that the Government said it was urgent and that immediate measures were needed. Senator Coulter has indicated that he will take this matter up after I have finished speaking.

The Ministers nominated a range of activities, including the expansion of some existing programs, to be run by their department in cooperation with other bodies and governments. They said that the programs were aimed at seeking better use of energy in our factories, offices, shops, homes and our roads. What did the Auditor-General find in his efficiency audit of this determined government policy? He found the following:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . The package had not been adequately implemented by the Department. It has taken longer than anticipated to achieve significant advancement of the policies. In the implementation of some significant measures many months had elapsed before initiation of any action. After just over two years of elapsed time the ANAO has estimated that the package was one year behind what could have been achievable. The ANAO considers that this delay is unreasonable, in view of the sense of urgency envisaged by the Government and justified by consideration of the issues involved.

Here we have massive delay in implementation of this program, and criticism of the department. What was the Minister doing? Did he ever go back to Cabinet and say, `Hey, my department and I are not doing too well on this. We need a few new resources, or something, but we are not doing it'. Maybe the Minister did do that, and maybe this Government, as is its custom, did not care that it was breaking its own word yet again on an issue that many Australians feel is very significant.

PARA.TAB: In this report with which we are dealing, the Audit Office noted:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that insufficient attention had been given to managing the programs, including those which had been in place prior to the announcement of the expansion—
this immediate, significant, urgent, so-called expansion—
in 1990. A number of the programs which had been started had not been able to approach their potential, because of deficiencies in planning and delivery.
The Audit Office continued:
In short, the Department did not fully respond in the manner expected of it.

Who was responsible for that? Did some poor bureaucrat get his head kicked in? Or is it the Minister who is responsible? The Government, of course, is only too happy to allow members of the bureaucracy to stand aside, to `carry the can'. But the buck stops with the Minister. The report continued:
Right up to the announcement in October 1990 it had not fully anticipated the greater priority to be given to the subject. Subsequently, it—
meaning the department—
did not provide the numbers of people approved for the programs or make full use of those that were there.
The question is whether the Minister knew this and, if he did not, then why not. The question then is why the Minister did not inquire. The report continued:

Staff meant to be available for putting the programs into place were heavily engaged on other tasks . . . This was the case right up until the time of our audit, more than two years after the announcement—
that is, the announcement of the program. The report continued:
There were a number of major organisational changes in 1990-91 which the Department allowed to disrupt the efficient implementation of the programs.

I will not continue with the general question of Australia's poor record in energy saving—no doubt Senator Coulter will talk about that—but I want to deal with the failure by the department and by the Minister. The department's research had shown that few people in Australia were aware of the need to save on energy. The ANAO concluded:
The public is still unaware and sceptical about Government programs and pronouncements on the topic—

namely, the topic of energy saving. In other words, not only did the department do nothing itself, but it also failed to promote or encourage other people to do anything. The Government was allegedly desperate to implement an urgent, immediate policy, yet the Minister failed to ensure that the stated policy was implemented. The report continued:

Although the Department maintains that its aim has been to achieve steady and reasonable progress across all sectors, the ANAO considers that to date it has been unable to demonstrate significant and measurable energy savings in any of the energy end-use sectors.
That represents a 100 per cent failure rate. The report continued:

The slow progress in improving the Commonwealth's application of its programs for energy efficiency within its own responsibilities is not conducive to obtaining rapid and effective responses from the community at large.

In other words, this was not a don't-do-as-I-say situation, because nothing was being said, and it was certainly not a don't-do-as-I-do situation, because nothing was being done either. The department's own research showed that the Government was seen to be asking for action from other energy consumers but was not active in improving its own energy use. The report continued:
The failure to allocate the full complement of resources to the task as originally anticipated risked confirming that view—
that is, the view held by the public. I conclude my remarks by referring to another comment by the ANAO in its report. It said:

PARA.TAB: The Department's reports—

SPEECH.PARA: meaning the reports on this matter—
have concentrated on presenting the range of activities it has undertaken and which improve its public image.
It then makes this telling point:
They have not provided information on the real achievement in progress against objectives as called for by an accountability document.

The Auditor-General, in the report's conclusion, considers that the department has not provided an objective view of its overall performance with the programs in its public reports. In other words, it has misled the public. The question is whether it has misled the Minister or whether the Minister went along with the misleading nature of these reports. The conclusion continued:

In addition we note that there has been a tendency to reinforce this public face within the Department itself. DPIE has not fully explored opportunities to place hard information in the public arena concerning the potential for economic gains in our usage of energy in Australia.

The final conclusions of the Auditor-General in respect of ministerial responsibility and departmental competence—and the Government and people of Australia should take note of their significance—are these:

The ANAO considers that the administrative platform established for the energy management programs would have been insufficient for ensuring the most effective contribution by DPIE to the longer term National Greenhouse Response Strategy. A key aspect is the importance of recognising practical implementation problems and structuring programs and implementation methods accordingly. The experience of the Department over the last three years is, however, a basis from which it can now move to a new level of achievement in national energy management.

It is very polite of the Australian National Audit Office to say that the department has learnt from its experience of doing nothing and might now be able to actually do something. The report continued:

The ANAO has made a series of recommendations which will contribute to this objective. DPIE has responded positively to almost all of the recommendations made for improving future administrative effectiveness, expressing disagreement with only parts of two recommendations out of a total of nineteen.

PARA.TAB: That sounds like a mea maxima culpa from the department which now, at last, says it will do something. The major area of disagreement on recommended action relates to management of current evaluation programs. In this report we have a clear indication of failure of ministerial responsibility backing up a failure of departmental activity. We have to ask seriously who was responsible for these kinds of mistakes, these kinds of `administrative error' when there is a Minister who is getting paid for being the `responsible' Minister. If people are prepared to take the money, they have to take the flak and cop the responsibility. We have seen too many Ministers in this Government prepared to take the money but not do the job.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will begin where Senator Baume left off. The plot is even more sinister than is revealed in this Auditor-General's report because we have a government and a Minister intent on giving the impression that something is being done about greenhouse, whereas the Government, the Minister and the department under his direction have no real intention of doing anything at all. Thank goodness for accountants rather than economists because this is an excellent audit report and an excellent criticism of this Government.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats have no doubt about the seriousness of the greenhouse problem. Perhaps rather than use that term, we should simply talk about the change in the global atmosphere. While there is some concern about the effect and rate of onset of those changes, there is no doubt that we are very rapidly changing the composition of the atmosphere—faster than at any time since life appeared on this planet. We are uncertain as to whether there will be a sea level rise, the extent of that rise, how rapidly it will come on, the effect of changes of climate, how quickly they will appear, and what will be the effect on agriculture. Because of the uncertainty principle, which is fundamental to the notion of ecologically sustainable development, we should proceed cautiously. For that reason these changes should be addressed urgently. We should vigorously attempt to slow down the rate of change because we do not know what the effects will be or when they will occur.

That brings in the very important principle of intergenerational equity—the fact that we should not be imposing upon future generations problems to which we do not have a solution. This matter is also urgent for Australia because, although we have a relatively small population and our contribution to global atmosphere changes is small—somewhat less than two per cent—nonetheless on a per capita basis our contribution is very large. The report draws attention to that factor. If responsibility lies with people—and I believe it does—then the responsibility individually and collectively on Australians is very large because our per capita contribution to changes to the global atmosphere is very large.

With that as a background and recognising that a large number of Australians thought that this was an important issue which Australia should do something about, I suggest that it is clear that the Government wanted to give back to the community the perception that the Government was doing something about it but it had no real intention of changing anything at all. It simply wanted to continue with business as usual while keeping up the nice facade that, yes, it was addressing this greenhouse problem.

This became quite evident to me and to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology during its inquiry into the greenhouse question. The people from DPIE came before the committee and it was quite clear that they had no clue as to how they would address the problem. They were the people who had been specifically appointed within that department to address the problem of greenhouse, yet it seemed to me that they had been appointed to go through the motions of addressing the greenhouse problem but in fact had no intention of seriously doing anything about it.

The report says that the programs which were set in place in 1990 were minuscule compared with the ultimate target which the Government had set—namely, the 20 per cent reduction by the year 2005. That is a 20 per cent reduction compared with the 1988 level of greenhouse gas emissions. Yet what was envisaged here was simply a four per cent reduction on the projected levels in the year 2005—a much more modest decrease. It was a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions brought about by energy efficiency improvements which would nonetheless save $1.5 billion annually. Yet, as Senator Baume has pointed out, two years on we are already one year behind in the implementation of even those very modest aims set in October 1990. The detailed report is extremely damning in many other respects.

Late last year while Senator Button was Leader of the Government in the Senate, I asked him a couple of questions in relation to this greenhouse problem. I asked him, firstly, was the Government aware of the warning given at that time by 1,500 of the world's leading scientists, including half of the living Nobel Prize winning scientists, in relation to the need to change our attitude with respect to greenhouse gas emissions, with respect to resource use generally, with respect to population increase and so on? And, if so, would it make any difference? The answer he gave was, yes, he was aware of that warning but, no, it would make no difference to policy.

Later in a further question I asked him whether he was aware of the warnings coming from the Munich Reinsurance Company—the largest reinsurance company in the world—in relation to the costs of greenhouse and taking that into account against the costs of implementing energy efficiency changes and so on. But he was not even aware of those matters. Clearly, in a number of government reports and a number of reports from private right wing think-tanks, we see that the costs of addressing greenhouse are taken into account but the costs of not addressing the greenhouse problem are totally ignored.

In the last couple of years we have seen record grain crops in Western Australia and South Australia essentially destroyed by heavy tropical rain coming across from the Timor Sea late in the season and ruining those crops through rust and various other diseases. The temperature in the Timor Sea has risen by some five degrees in the last decade, and the storms which came across and brought that rain to South Australia were quite without precedent. Throughout the western parts of Queensland and New South Wales we are seeing drought which again is without precedent in the history of Australia since white settlement.

No scientist is prepared to say that either of those things is directly related to greenhouse. However, most scientists are prepared to say that they are consistent with the sorts of changes one might expect with greenhouse. Both of those things have caused enormous losses to Australia. So the problems in relation to the cost of greenhouse certainly need to be taken into account, and the equations need to be done properly.

The Government has also failed to take more concerted action in relation to electricity utilities to force them to a situation in which they recognise themselves as providers of end use energy services rather than simply as providers of electricity. There is an enormous amount which could be done in that respect.

I want to pick up one or two specific things which the Auditor-General says. One which I have found quite fascinating, because it is totally different from the approach which the Government has consistently taken over some time and totally different from the sorts of reports and the philosophical foundation we are getting from the Industry Commission, is the suggestion regarding the injection of an energy efficiency perspective into the taxation policy advising area. In other words, just as we recognise that we can intrude health considerations into the tax on cigarettes and alcohol, so should we take a wider view of taxation as a policy instrument—something for which the Democrats have been arguing for a long time. We recognise that taxation is a very useful instrument in changing people's behaviour in the way in which they use and abuse energy and therefore contribute to greenhouse gas emissions.
In conclusion, the important point to be brought out is the point made by the Auditor-General, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Department's reports have concentrated on presenting the range of activities it has undertaken and which improve its public image. They have not provided information on the real achievement in progress against objectives as called for by an accountability document.

That is the point Senator Baume concluded with. I think it is a point which should be stressed. I believe the problem goes deeper than just an apparent conflict between the Minister and the department, which is the point I think Senator Baume was making. I think that the Minister, the Government and the department are in collusion to give the impression that something is being done about greenhouse, whereas in fact very little is being done and very little will be done until this Government is pushed much harder. The problem is urgent, and I think that we could do a great deal more, with enormous cost savings to Australia. It will not cost the amounts that the Tasman Institute and other institutes have pointed to. Energy efficiency is not only good from the point of view of greenhouse, but it is also very good from the point of view of saving money. There are enormous opportunities in that respect.

PARA.TAB: The $6 million that was announced in the Governor-General's speech is paltry compared with what we could do with one technology alone: solar hot water services. If we spent a hundred times that amount of money as seed money to get over the capital hurdle, the savings would be enormous in energy and greenhouse gas emissions, and we could expand an industry which could employ literally thousands of people and be worth billions of dollars. Australia has the leading edge in technology in this industry. It is an industry that is crying out for encouragement, using Australian labour and materials. It is just one example of a direction that we could take and of the way in which the Government is simply turning its back on what could be done.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an important issue. It is most pleasing to me that a couple of speakers in this debate took the time and trouble to highlight what the Australian National Audit Office has unearthed. This is a matter of some importance across a number of government departments. In this particular instance the report is directed towards the energy management program of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, but its implications stretch across a number of other departments. The report reveals an attitude that to flurry about and to be seen to be doing something is perhaps good enough; to actually do something is just a bit hard.

PARA.TAB: The report mirrors the deceptions, the superficiality, the magic show for what it is. The department's attitude has been revealed as being superficial and without commitment. As previous speakers have said, it is no wonder the public is sceptical about the Government's commitment, firstly, to reducing greenhouse emissions in Australia and, secondly, the whole idea of reducing waste and benefiting Australia. I mean that sincerely. The department would benefit Australia if it were to show leadership in achieving either sustainable practices in agriculture or savings as a result of reducing waste.

What makes this whole matter so sensationally important as an example of what is wrong with the Government's attitude is revealed by a joint statement made on 23 October 1990 by Ministers Kerin and Griffiths. In that joint statement we see what I described earlier as the flurry, the fanfare, the big joint announcement. As Senator Coulter said earlier, we were told in this announcement that we were having initiatives put before us which would achieve $1.5 billion worth of energy savings annually by the year 2005. We were told in that announcement that this was the first step towards achieving the interim planning target to reduce greenhouse emissions by 20 per cent by the year 2005.

That first step was never really completed. The department is still on one leg; the other foot has not touched the ground yet. The leadership has not been implemented. The public is still waiting to be shown the path of savings and benefits to Australia. The $1.5 billion was a wonderful sounding figure but, of course, mentioning that figure and actually doing something are two different things. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) stands accused of having failed to ensure that the department implemented these programs.

What was needed was persistence and leadership. Instead, we have seen superficiality. As far as I am concerned, it has been demonstrated quite clearly over a number of years now in answers to questions that I have asked in this place. That applies not only to me, but to several others who have asked questions.

One of the first questions I asked in this place related to recycled paper and why it was not available for all members and senators. An excuse was given—that it was something to do with its being the fault of the Department of the Senate, that there was no communication with the Department of Administrative Services, or that the matter really belonged with the Joint House Department; I cannot remember what it was. But that excuse, of course, is reflective of an attitude which the Australian National Audit Office was able to detect throughout Australia, which it criticised and for which it gave a quite simple explanation of how the matter might be resolved. What is needed is better cooperation between departments, sharing of goals and a little understanding of what each department is trying to do.

On page 74 of this report, we can see that the Audit Office is able to instruct DPIE on how it might go about coordinating this approach and suggests which particular departments it might be good to talk to—for example, local government associations; motorists and motor trade associations; building trades and building managers; energy appliance associations, especially for airconditioning; national industry extension services; energy supply associations; cross-sectoral industry associations; and other government departments, be they the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories or the Department of Housing, Local Government and Community Services.

The idea that these departments and organisations should be included in an understanding of the Government's true goal or what the Department of Primary Industries and Energy was trying to achieve as a result of the joint statement announcement on 23 October 1990 seems to be too simple to overlook. Yet it is obvious that the department did overlook it. We do not know whether the idea was intentionally overlooked or whether it was not adopted due to a lack of capacity. But the result has been the same: the attempt to reach the target has slipped.

I want to look at one simple example—paper usage. Senator Bolkus, quite rightly and proudly, announced a number of measures that were taken in his department 18 months or two years ago in order to reduce the use of new paper when it was not necessary, including the collection of waste paper to enable it to be recycled, thereby setting an example.

Envelopes made out of recycled paper were introduced in this place for use by members of parliament and government departments. However, one of the strange features of those envelopes is that they have little slots cut in the back of the flap that is folded down. This might not seem very important, but the function of those little slots means that if the envelope is used again, it tears. They are put there by design in order to stop people using the envelope twice. Those honourable senators who are nodding their heads or staring in blank amazement while wondering why I think this is important might like to consider how often these envelopes tear when opening them. That little cut works extremely well in preventing their reuse.

A department which allows that slot to remain on the envelopes that it uses is revealed as a department which does not have its heart in the whole issue. It does not understand what it is trying to achieve and it has not followed through. It has not been persistent in trying to get across the idea that the stated goal is essentially reducing waste. It has not delivered.

There is an appearance of being concerned, but it is superficial, as is revealed by another seemingly tiny and insignificant matter. Day after day in Parliament House we see kilowatts of energy being wasted in illuminating globes that face daylight. I am indebted to Senator Coulter for doing a calculation which suggests that some 27 trillion kilowatts of light are available and hitting the earth's surface daily yet we find it necessary to illuminate another couple of dozen 50-watt globes in order to light our way around Parliament House.

It is ridiculous; these lights are not needed at all. There is no reason to have those lights illuminated during daylight hours. They have been so illuminated since the day this place opened, I have asked a few questions about them and no reason has been advanced as to why they are there blazing away, chewing up energy in daylight hours. Those lights blazing away in daylight reveal and highlight the Government's misunderstanding, lack of commitment and total superficiality in this area of energy conservation and the reduction of waste. Those lights stand as a beacon revealing this Government's lack of commitment to that which it likes to trumpet as its common goal—the goal of annually saving $1.5 billion by the year 2005. It will never get there; that other foot will never hit the ground while there is such a lack of commitment which has been revealed by this particular audit report. I could go on for days—

TALK.START.PARA: —I know!
—The Minister might find it boring, but it is crucially important that this report is recognised as a revelation of this Government's lack of commitment.

PARA.TAB: I will give another couple of examples, because this needs to be rubbed in. A considerable amount of the $1.5 billion in projected savings is real money that is spent overseas, especially on importing oil. Some of the earliest questions I raised here in this place concerned ethanol. I know that some honourable senators were reduced to tears at the thought of another question on ethanol because there seemed to be an answer. There was no answer; there was an excuse about why the Australian Government was not intervening to assist with the development of an ethanol industry as an alternative fuel to add to our petroleum to replace some of the petroleum that we bought from overseas.

That question was only ever examined in a naked, pure production-cost comparison sense. There was no regard for the benefits that could accrue from such an activity—whether those benefits be in local employment, in the balance of trade, or in strategic benefits that would arise from the fact that we would have a variety of sources of fuel for our transport industries, or even environmental benefits such as the reduction of greenhouse emissions. There was no attempt to add those into the equation.

But not very long ago we had a great fanfare about this wonderful new stuff called `diesohol'—the addition of some 10 per cent or so of ethanol to diesel as a fuel with an emulsifier. Now we see a flurry of press releases, a bit of fanfare and a few clever one-liners on TV. But where is government commitment and intervention to encourage this industry? Where is government purchasing or support in terms of real tangible work? We do not see it. Instead, we see the superficial attention grabbing, sort of chameleon-like hopping onto one issue for five minutes by various Ministers. When it comes down to it, the world has not changed and Australia has not progressed towards saving this $1.5 billion per year.

We see that same attitude repeated throughout government activities, I would suggest. We see electricity-saving programs with a few stickers thrown out, a bit of a show here and there, a couple of posters—but no follow-up; it does not get done. The public can still see waste, whether it be in the lighting and heating of government buildings or the larger issues such as the motor vehicle fleet of Australia, which is again revealed in this report on page 50. We see it there, and it is quite easily understood. The audit office has drawn a pretty picture for the Government and the department cannot help understanding this. Here we have the Australian fleet new vehicle fuel consumption shown to have reached a flattening point on the graph, which is above the fuel consumption of such vehicles in the United Kingdom, Canada, USA, Japan and Italy—with Italy setting an example which is at least three, perhaps four litres per 100 kilometres leaner, more efficient than the Australian fleet.

We do not seem to be interested enough, we do not seem to be committed enough and we do not seem to be prepared enough to take the necessary steps to actually achieve progress in this area. Whether or not the steps that are necessary for government intervention are steps towards, as Senator Coulter suggested, actually intervening and striving for the goal of using that 27 trillion kilowatts of energy available from the sun by the use of solar hot water heaters, or whether we take up and market better the woollen insulation available in Australia, we must do something. We cannot send out another press release making another statement which, with present attitudes, is not achievable.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On behalf of Senator McMullan, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, he will move:

PARA.TAB: That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to amend the law about collecting and recovering income tax, to change the Corporations Law, to amend some other Acts, and for related purposes.

DEBATE.TITLE: CHARTER OF THE UNITED NATIONS AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: [COGNATE BILL:

PROCTEXT.PARA: INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATION (FURTHER PAYMENT) BILL 1993]

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 6 May, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is now debating two important pieces of legislation and the coalition will be supporting both. The first, a Bill to amend the Charter of the United Nations Act 1945, will implement changes that would facilitate the support by Australia of international sanctions under the auspices of the United Nations. In principle we support it and, furthermore, we are prepared to support the detail. The second Bill, the International Development Association (Further Payment) Bill 1993, is the tenth IDA replenishment Bill which provides further commitments by Australia to the soft lending arm of the World Bank to help in the alleviation of global poverty, and we also support that.

PARA.TAB: I return to the UN Bill for a few minutes. I know the Senate is under some pressure of time already this session; nevertheless, there are a few things that I wanted to say on behalf of the coalition. It is a difficult time for the international community, as we have passed through the Cold War phase and now find the establishing of a new world order much more difficult than many envisaged. Unfortunately, we are in a period of international development where ethnic, communal, religious or national conflicts seem to have broken out and have replaced the former major, superpower tensions with numerous smaller conflicts. Nevertheless, they are conflicts of great brutality and often of a highly complex and difficult nature in terms of providing a resolution.

The coalition obviously supports the international community through the auspices of the United Nations doing all that is reasonably possible to try to stabilise these conflicts. Therefore, it supports the commitment of Australia as part of the United Nations. We have often commended the contribution of Australia in peacekeeping forces throughout the world. I think one should put on record the very worthwhile contribution that Australian military forces have just made in Somalia—the prime part of that force is about to return to Australia—as well as the highly commendable work that Australia's defence forces are continuing to perform in Cambodia and elsewhere throughout the world.

The issue is how Australia might better or further contribute to this work. This Bill looks at one particular contribution, where the international community as a group has decided that the imposition of some pressure is necessary to try to bring a state to recognise that a peaceful resolution of problems is the way we would all prefer in terms of the new world order. We think of the imposition of sanctions in such places as Iraq, some of which still apply, and particularly—as I think is the cause of this legislation—sanctions that have been imposed in the former Yugoslavia.

We accept that there are a number of different tools that the international community has to try to bring conflict to an end. Inducements can be offered; diplomacy can play its part; but there is in some circumstances the need for the international community to apply pressure, in the form of, say, arms embargoes or economic sanctions. Ultimately the pressure might be in the form of the application of military force, as we saw in the case of Iraq. Nevertheless, it is important that the Government of Australia has a reasonably free hand in meeting our international responsibility in this regard.

We accept the argument that the Government has put that to date it has been a difficult process and the reform of the law would facilitate our contribution in this way. Thus, we are prepared to support this piece of legislation. On another occasion, when the Senate has more time, we on this side of the chamber would appreciate a wider debate on how the future development of the UN might occur and how Australia should contribute further to peacekeeping, peacemaking and peace enforcing roles; the issues of a ready deployment force, other opportunities for preventative action by the UN, the establishment of permanent funds to enable the UN to better meet the responsibility given to it by the international community in these tasks; the role that we and others in the international community can play in promoting democracy as a contribution towards stability and, therefore, peace.

I recognise the Australian Government's willingness to send observers, of which I was privileged to be one, to the recent referendum in Eritrea. I think not everyone understands the contribution that good governance—as it has being referred to these days—can play in contributing to peace; just as development aid can contribute to stability and, therefore, ultimately to peaceful environments. It is a complex issue and our contribution is made at a number of different levels. One of the levels at which we are definitely required to make a contribution from time to time—and would want to make a contribution—is the application of sanctions. This Bill better enables the Australian Government to do that and we are therefore prepared to support it.

In relation to the IDA Bill, there is an ongoing debate as to what part of Australia's total aid contribution should be made up of support for the international financial institutions—in particular, support for the soft lending arms such as the IDA in relation to the World Bank and also the soft window of the Asian Development Bank.

We have been somewhat critical of World Bank operations in the past. I think I acknowledged in the last speech I gave on this subject that there had been improvement in the World Bank in looking at the broader development agenda.
