I agree with Mr Laver that an early review is necessary, and whilst I acknowledge that NBEET does undertake some important work, these functions can be undertaken more efficiently through the structure proposed by the coalition before the last election.

The question is why the Government did not agree with Mr Laver and why the extension of the review under this amendment is for one year as opposed to the six months that Mr Laver wanted. It is disappointing that the review has been delayed, because the sooner we have a review of NBEET and its functions the better.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak specifically on the Australian National Training Authority Amendment Bill 1993. I fully endorse the remarks of my colleague Senator Tierney in relation to some of the issues that have arisen in relation to this new authority. The focus of my remarks will be specifically directed to the secondment of a new chief executive of ANTA. My colleague in the other place, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews), has drawn attention to the fact that this amendment was required to allow the new chief executive, a gentleman by the name of Mr Terry Moran, to have a salary in the order of $170,000, rather than the limit of $120,000 which was placed on his appointment as a result of his not being able to be seconded from the Victorian Public Service.

PARA.TAB: This raises the issue of salaries that the Commonwealth Government is paying to chief executives. This major issue has occurred as a result of the Government's need—I think an appropriate need—for salary and wage restraint in other sectors of the economy. One of the issues that has emerged in relation to the payments to senior public servants is the issue of performance based pay. The Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), who is at the table, may be able to indicate whether Mr Moran will be coming under this scheme of performance based bonuses. I would like to explore this issue.

From 1 July this year the Senior Executive Service of the Public Service will be entitled to very substantial bonuses as a result of the performance based system that was agreed between the former Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, and Jenny George of the ACTU last December. It is interesting that the ACTU was involved in this. I am at a loss to understand why it agreed to very substantial effective pay rises as a result of the performance based pay system to senior public servants, while at the same time insisting on pay restraint by lower paid workers in the public and private sectors. It is an important issue that has started to emerge in the press, and I hope the Minister may be able to tell us whether Mr Moran is entitled to these performance based pay arrangements, and whether this will act as a pacesetter for the Public Service and public authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should not.

—It should not but it may well do so. People naturally look at what other people are being paid, and there will be a lot of senior public servants who will be looking at the salary package of Mr Terry Moran and wondering why, in this climate of restraint, the Government is agreeing to this particular package.
—And senators?

—I do not think that we are on a performance based pay system. As Senator Carr would probably remind me, the Government promised the workers of Australia prior to the last election that 1 July would be the day when they would be receiving their $8 a week pay rise. That has now been put on the backburner. On 1 July, all the Senior Executive Service will be entitled to be assessed for performance based pay rises. This may involve a cash bonus of up to $15,000 to the top levels of the Senior Executive Service. That is for people regarded as a `five' performer. There are five divisions in the performance based pay scale. Some of the members of the Senior Executive Service after 1 July will become eligible for this $15,000 pay increase.

PARA.TAB: This Bill before us highlights some of the problems that the Government now has in the industrial relations area, particularly in relation to wages and salaries. Whereas I may not agree with Senator Carr on many issues, I wonder whether in this climate of restraint this sort of salary package is appropriate for the Commonwealth Government to be setting—a further pacesetter. Because of the procedures that the Commonwealth Government has adopted, with the endorsement of the ACTU—let us be blunt on that—performance based pay rises will be very substantial indeed.

A number of important issues are raised by this Bill. In some ways, it goes to the heart of the industrial relations approach that this Government is taking on wages and salaries; it is a debate which I suspect will continue for some time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I found the dialogue that Senator Kemp had with Senator Carr fascinating, especially as it was only one way. I say to Senator Carr, `You have got him spooked already'. We have had several contributions tonight. Not many of the contributions spent a long time on the actual Bills before us—the Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill and the Australian National Training Amendment Bill—but the opportunity has been used to raise general attitudes on the effectiveness of the ANTA board and also NBEET. The general comments reflected people's views as they have previously expressed them. I will not respond to those.

PARA.TAB: Senator Teague asked five specific questions not related to the Bill. I do not think he expects me to respond on the spot, but I have asked the officers to write to him by Friday with answers to those five questions. I do not deem it necessary for those answers to be cleared by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley); so we should get them to him by Friday.

Senator Teague was a little cynical when he said that this was put off maybe for other reasons other than an upcoming election and a possible coalition win. Maybe he is right; maybe none of us thought they could win. But he is wrong when he says that we did not have the inquiry because we thought we might be embarrassed during the federal election by the results of the inquiry. We are skilled enough to hold an inquiry and have the results come after an election rather than before. I think that rather detracts from that particular conspiracy theory.

I am sure that some of the advice—I cannot say this with absolute authority—from the department would have been, `Look, you are setting up terms of reference for an inquiry. We have to remind you that in a few months or in a few weeks time you will be in caretaker mode. We have examined the Opposition policy and it is quite diametrically opposed to this and it would be a waste of resources to set up an inquiry and appoint an inquirer if there is a change of government. You might want to go in a completely different direction'. I think generally it is a fairly genuine attitude in this regard to have put it off. As Senator Teague has said, away from the atmosphere of partisan politics in this next year the review may be even more wide ranging than before because at least there are no political imperatives to be met over the next year in the electoral process.

Senator Teague went on to make a rather anguished cry about relative wage justice. All I can say is that he will not find much disagreement with me on what he has said. It is very hard to find comparative wage justice in terms of executive salaries. Recently the managing director of AMP got a $130,000 pay rise after a rather unsuccessful year in running the company. That is double Senator Teague's salary in one salary rise, let alone the quantum, which is of the order of $800,000. Many people in this chamber have spoken on the lack of restraint in executive salaries. However, I do not think we can resolve all those issues here today.

Not just the Commonwealth Minister but the Commonwealth ministerial council wanted this particular individual. Again, he was not known to me—he is apparently known to no-one in the chamber, but that is not surprising. It was their decision. It was found that, due to the provisions of a previous Act, it was not possible to second this person and, therefore, the adjustments have been made.

Senator Sowada made a more general contribution. I stopped listening when she told us that she was not into conspiracy theories. I was a bit stunned by that so I did not take in the rest of her contribution. Senator Tierney made a very succinct contribution tonight—he hid all the major points and did not repeat himself over and over again. I thought it was quite a good contribution.

Senator Kemp complained that someone is being paid more than Commonwealth department heads. At the Estimates committee hearing I expressed some surprise at that. I remind Senator Kemp that the Kennett Government negotiated this contract. This contract was negotiated on 1 January. The Kennett Government determined the salary of $170,000 a year plus extras. The State Liberal governments have been the major pacesetters in executive salaries. The head of the Victorian Education Department gets $250,000 a year. There is at least one public servant in Victoria, I understand, who is on $300,000 a year. All this started with the Greiner Liberal government in New South Wales. It changed the name from that of secretary of department to chief executive officer and offered enormous salary packages in an attempt to steal public servants away from Canberra. And now we are into the rat-race.

It is anomalous that someone with 80 bureaucrats working under him is getting paid $40,000 more than my departmental secretary who has at least 23,000 civilians working under him. My CDF, who has 68,000 people working under him, gets far less salary than someone with 80 bureaucrats working under him. It was not the Commonwealth which set these standards; it was the State governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't have to pay it.

—If the honourable senator wants to go through the process of secondment, I do not think it possible in the modern world to offer far less than a person has been getting. We have been left in that particular situation. I draw Senator Kemp's attention to his ideological colleagues in Victoria who set the level of this salary package.
—Yes, but you don't have to follow.

—Senator Kemp probably does not own up to them any more; they are probably just the ugly cousins down south—the hick State government he does not want to recognise any more because it is a bit nasty. He does not want to take responsibility for it. The fact is that State governments have been the trendsetters in this area. They have not followed any national wage principles whatsoever and have gone out and headhunted individuals, no matter what the cost.
—Why do you follow them?
—The decision to employ Mr Moran was a ministerial council meeting decision, and not a decision simply by the Commonwealth Minister.
—Employ someone else.
—`Employ someone else', says Senator Kemp. I would invite Senator Kemp to come up with some names; let us know.
—What else do you want me to do?

—The fact that Senator Kemp does very little around here has been quite obvious from his vacuous and empty-headed speech tonight. That is in vast contrast to the rest of his colleagues, who made substantial contributions.

PARA.TAB: These Bills really only hit two basic areas: the delayed inquiry and the secondment issue. All the other contributions were interesting in relation to the philosophy of training and the philosophy of setting up ANTA. Those issues have been the subject of previous debates in this chamber. Nevertheless, I thank those honourable senators who contributed to the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating tonight the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Amendment Bill 1992. Briefly, in January 1990 the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act was amended by the Courts and Tribunals Administration Amendment Act to allow for the president of the tribunal to be responsible for managing the administrative affairs of the tribunal. Following the commencement of separate administration, it was agreed that the operations of the tribunal should be reviewed to assess the delivery of services, efficiency and so on. However, the review was deferred at that time until the new president, Justice O'Connor, had the opportunity of familiarising herself with the operations of the tribunal. She was appointed in June 1990, and the review took place between October 1990 and November 1991.

PARA.TAB: A series of amendments is proposed which basically seeks to do eight things. The amendments are directed at streamlining the procedures of the tribunal and clarifying the powers of the tribunal in procedural matters. I will briefly refer to the eight matters that are dealt with: firstly, a clearer statement of the president's role and functions; secondly, two additional methods by which the tribunal can be constituted; thirdly, an application is not validly lodged unless the prescribed fee is actually paid; fourthly, formal recognition for directions hearings; fifthly, a discretion to determine whether or not a conference should be held; sixthly, a discretion for the tribunal to decline to make a decision in terms of an agreement that the parties might come to; seventh, participation in proceedings by means of closed circuit television and any other means of communication; and, eighth, the power to dismiss applications for delay or where the application is frivolous or vexatious.

As matters go to the substance of this Bill—that is, an amending Bill—I want to say no more other than to add that the Opposition does not oppose the Bill. However, it is worth mentioning that one of my colleagues who will participate in the debate later this evening has had a significant role to play and a significant interest in the development of the tribunal. He is one of the few remaining people who were here when the tribunal was set up and who had something to say about what the Bill that would set up the tribunal offered and did not offer and who had something to say when the Bill needed amendment. He has had a close interest in those matters ever since. I am referring to Senator Durack, from Western Australia, who is retiring at the end of June. He has served in numerous capacities in this Parliament, not the least of which was as Attorney-General. I think this Bill was first passed in 1975.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—Yes, the Minister is nodding. I think I could be forgiven for suggesting that in 1976 Senator Missen, a former Victorian senator in this place on my side of the chamber, may have asked a dorothy dixer along the lines of, `What is wrong with the Bill?'. Senator Durack took the opportunity to say that what was wrong with the Bill was what had been pointed out originally but that the Government would not listen and that now we were in government we would make amendments to fix those problems. Again, I think in 1977, a further contribution was made.

PARA.TAB: I simply draw attention to that—I will stay to listen to what Senator Durack has to say about this and possibly some other matters on the development of administrative law in Australia—not just because Senator Durack is serving his last couple of weeks as a senator in this Parliament but also because the view is held, sometimes mistakenly, by those on the other side of the chamber that it is they who have been the great law reformers all the time. That is simply not the case, and I think Senator Durack's involvement is a good example of that. I look forward to hearing his contribution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate today is debating the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Amendment Bill 1992. The purpose of this Bill, as has already been stated, is to give effect to recommendations of the report of the review of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to make specific provision for mediation and to provide that the tribunal is able to accept documents lodged by electronic means.

PARA.TAB: The main amendments in this Bill, which implement the review's recommendations, are firstly, a clearer statement of the role and functions of the President of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in relation to the arrangement of business and the personnel of the tribunal; secondly, the provision of a discretion in the president to convene a preliminary conference to determine the matters in issue prior to a hearing—this implements what has already become practice of convening such conferences where a significant proportion of cases are resolved—thirdly, provision of a discretion for the tribunal to decline to make a decision in terms of the parties' agreement if it is inappropriate to do so; and, fourthly, to introduce a power to dismiss applications for delay if they are frivolous or vexatious. The Government says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . such matters, although few in number, are very resource intensive and divert resources away from legitimate applications.
I too look forward to the comments that we can expect from Senator Durack on this matter, which he has obviously researched to a great extent.

PARA.TAB: The Bill also introduces mediation in the AAT as an alternative to formal hearings in order to provide a greater choice of methods of dispute resolution in a manner similar to the legislative framework for mediation-arbitration which is in use now in the federal and family courts. Mediation will, however, not be used where the president considers that the matter in dispute is of sufficient public importance for a decision to be made by the tribunal on the merits of the case or where there is such a degree of animosity between the parties that mediation would be inhibited. Finally, the Bill proposes to allow the tribunal to accept documents lodged by electronic means—a move which is certainly to be welcomed. The Australian Democrats will be supporting this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had hoped that tonight perhaps we would have had more time to debate these amendments to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act because, although the amendments in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Amendment Bill are not extensive, they do make some important changes to the administration of the Act, and in that regard they are most welcome. I am pleased that the debate in this chamber indicates that they will be passed without dissent or amendment.

PARA.TAB: However, I would like to take the opportunity, albeit a somewhat attenuated one now under the pressure of time in this chamber this evening, to say a few things about the creation and the progress of this most revolutionary change in the public administration of Australia—a change which I hope will be implemented in all States of Australia in due course. It has been followed in some States but has yet to be followed in others.

The basic reform created by the establishment of an administrative appeals tribunal was to give individuals affected by administrative decisions of government—in this case of the Commonwealth—a right of appeal to an independent or external review body. When this was first considered by a committee set up in the late 1960s, there were very limited areas of government where the decisions of a Minister or departmental official, apart from some internal review processes perhaps, could be reviewed by an external body. There has been great debate not only in the country but in other similar jurisdictions about the lack of rights of an individual against government decisions whereas individuals affected by the decisions of other individuals, large corporations or whatever have had rights of redress in the ordinary court system. When

SPEECH.PARA: individuals' rights were affected by decisions of government—these are largely whether the Government's discretion was exercised in a justifiable way, not whether the Government was acting legally—there was no similar redress.

PARA.TAB: Australia has been a great pioneer in providing redress for individuals against claimed infringement of their rights by others—whether they be government, other individuals or major institutional bodies. Over a century ago, the Australian conciliation and arbitration system was introduced. When it was established it was hailed as a new province of law and order. Although many changes are now being made to that system, and many more will be made, I think it is fair to say that the establishment of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal on 1 July 1976 was hailed as a new province of law and order for Australia. Indeed, the way in which this system has flourished in the past 17 years indicates that it is an extremely vigorous and successful teenager. I am sure it will go on for easily as long as the arbitration system has existed, and probably longer.

The Administrative Appeals Tribunal was set up as a result of bipartisan actions through this Parliament. As I said, the original committee, which proposed a body of this kind, was set up by a Liberal government. The legislation, when finally brought into this Parliament in 1975, was brought in by a Labor government. The legislation was welcomed by the then Opposition, of which I was a member. We found some very grave deficiencies at the time in that legislation. The legislation set up the shell structure of an appeals tribunal but did not give the tribunal any jurisdiction. It was in the process of the debate in this chamber on the original Bill that the tribunal was granted a wide and special jurisdiction which enabled the tribunal when it was first established to rapidly obtain a very substantial workload.

Over the years, that jurisdiction has been greatly widened, and is widened almost continuously in legislation dealt with in this chamber and probably unnoticed by most of us. The body itself has certainly become of major significance in what I would call broadly our judicial system or rule of law. It has led to the creation of a number of specific administrative appeals tribunals, some of which are overseen by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Others have their own independent life, such as the migration review tribunals. All in all what this legislation has led to is a major change in the way in which the public administration of the Commonwealth goes about making its decisions.

In this relatively short period of 17 years, it has led to some very major changes in the practices and the better performance of the public administration in Australia, and the Public Service of the Commonwealth in particular. I would have liked to have elaborated somewhat more on that, but I just refer to the fact that a few weeks ago I attended a conference in Canberra put on by the Australian Institute of Administrative Law and the Royal Institute of Public Administration of Australia. It was very well attended, largely by public servants, but others such as myself were there. The most pleasing aspect of that conference was the extent to which the administrative appeals system of administrative review in Australia has been accepted and become part and parcel of the culture of public administration. It has been a most successful and welcome development. As I said, I foresee it being not only part of the architecture of administration but retained as a vital feature of our public administration.

I turn to the way in which the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has been structured. When I talk about the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, I should speak generally of these other bodies associated with it, either subject to appeal to it or existing in their own independent right. There is a major philosophy behind the structure of these bodies. They are separate from the judicial traditional court system within our legal system, or rule of law. There are appeals to the courts on points of law and lawyers, and in some cases judges, have played a role and will continue to play a role as presiding members of many of the tribunals, certainly those dealing with the more difficult areas of appeal.

The important thing—this was applied from the very beginning in the original Act and is still a major feature—is that it is simply not a lawyer's paradise or a lawyer's monopoly. The tribunals have been structured in such a way that some may be presided over by lawyers, sitting in many cases with experts in the various fields that are covered under the appeal, whether that be in taxation, customs, veterans' affairs, social security or whatever the area may be.

The tribunals are tailored to deal with a particular area of administration and appeals are heard by people who would be qualified in that area. At a time when a good deal of criticism is being made of our ordinary judicial system and many people are talking about the sorts of reforms that should be made to it, it is pleasing to note that this system of broad right of appeal against administrative decisions—which we have had now for the past 17 years—has been reflecting, and will continue to reflect, means and methods of giving citizens the right of appeal with minimum legal formalities using a combination of legal and other diverse skills which people in the community can contribute to bring about the solution of these conflicts.

The resolution of conflicts is a major role of government; it is a major part of a democratic and free society. The rights of the individual should always be paramount, but it is how we give effect to them that is perhaps more difficult to achieve. I believe our administrative appeals system has been highly successful in achieving those goals.

This Bill adds further to that progress by acknowledging the alternative dispute resolution system, as it is called—namely, the opportunities for mediation or arbitration of disputes and, in particular, the encouragement of settlement of disputes. These have always been part and parcel of our judicial system. Nevertheless, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, despite all its informality and wider representation of interests than would be available to the court system—apart altogether from the use of juries in that system—has not yet had the opportunity of exploring other new dispute resolution methods such as mediation and encouraging parties to settle their disputes. That does seem to create some difficulty for appeals against decisions by administrators under legal discretions. But I cannot see any reason why those methods should not be just as available in these cases as they are in our ordinary legal system. I am sure these new proposals will fit in very well with the greater informality of a tribunal based system as opposed to a court system.

Another feature of our established system is that a wide pool of people, including lawyers, have participated in it and have been members of the tribunal. I think the Attorney-General, Mr Lavarch, who wants to widen the selection pool for the court system, might profit by looking at the way in which people have been selected to serve on the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. There is—and I noticed it particularly at this conference—a great opportunity for women who have played, are playing, and will continue to play, a major role in the work of this appeals system, both with regard to the tribunal itself and similar tribunals operating under its umbrella. I welcome the introduction of this Bill and look forward to its speedy passage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended to speak on the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Amendment Bill 1992 [1993], and I will only do so for a very short time. I thought it appropriate to acknowledge in a bipartisan way the great contribution which Senator Durack has made to the development of this area of Australia's public life. When inhabitants of this great Commonwealth are affected by a decision taken by a Commonwealth department or agency, or by any decision maker, which can affect their enjoyment of life—or access even to a livelihood by way of a licence that could be granted by some Commonwealth agency—then it is extremely important that the decision maker be subject to scrutiny and judgment, and that the person affected know that any grievance will be looked at in a fair way. As Senator Durack pointed out, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, in its various forms and subsets, has been a very important safeguard for Australians against the kind of arbitrary or partial decision-making that can have such an adverse effect on a person's life.

PARA.TAB: It is important to acknowledge the contribution which Senator Durack has made to the evolution of the system. He spoke modestly—almost as though he were a mere observer—of the genesis and birth of this particular Administrative Appeals Tribunal process. Of course, he was more than an observer; he was a very active participant. Much of his creative work as a member of the Liberal Party in this Parliament—in opposition and in government—and particularly as Attorney-General, will be found in the contribution he has made to this area of decision making within the community.

Senator Durack also mentioned that the scope for women to participate in the tribunal indicates a way in which decision making tribunals might be better constituted to serve Australian society. This particular organisation, which is only 17 years old, has the capacity to be innovative, not only with regard to the development of alternative dispute resolution processes, but also with regard to the personnel of which it is formed. In many different and perhaps unexpected ways, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is part of Australia's pre-eminent contribution to the protection of citizens against arbitrary or partial decisions of governments, which is acknowledged internationally as of worldwide significance. I believe that the tribunal has much to commend it. In so far as its genesis enjoyed the support and encouragement of Senator Durack, it is appropriate in the course of this debate to pay him tribute.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)
