DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AMENDMENT BILL 1993VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 13 May, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will concentrate my remarks on the Social Security Amendment Bill 1993, while my colleague the shadow Minister for veterans' affairs, Senator MacGibbon, will concentrate on the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill. This Bill seeks to facilitate three of the Government's masses of election promises, namely a reduction in the withdrawal rate under the age pension assets test, an extension of the income free area for jobsearch allowance, newstart allowance and sickness allowance and the rationalisation of the normal waiting period for these three benefits.

PARA.TAB: As with all the Government's pre-election promises, each of these initiatives will have an impact on the Government's Budget outcome. When the Budget comes out I will be interested to see how the Government is going to pay for those promises. It is estimated that these measures will cost some $71.6 million in 1993-94 and $90.6 million in 1994-95. In the light of these not insignificant costs it is important that these measures are given careful consideration by the Senate.

This Bill will amend the Social Security Act by introducing an additional free area of $30 a fortnight in earned income for single recipients of jobsearch, newstart and sickness allowance, while the additional free area for earned income for partnered recipients of these benefits will be increased by $20—from $30 to $50 a fortnight. An estimated 89,000 benefit recipients will be affected by this measure.

This initiative means that single people on the dole will be able to earn an additional $30 a fortnight from working before their rate of payment is reduced. A partnered person on the dole will be able to earn up to $50 a fortnight from working before his rate of payment is reduced. This earned income, or in layman's terms earnings from work—this free area—is in addition to the basic free area of $60 per fortnight which applies to ordinary income from any source.

This Bill also amends the Social Security Act by consolidating all the current normal waiting period exemption provisions for jobsearch, newstart and sickness allowance into a single across-the-board exemption that applies to anyone who has been in receipt of income support within the previous 13 weeks. According to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca) in the House of Representatives, these provisions will `improve the financial return from undertaking part-time or casual employment and reduce client uncertainty about the effects of such employment on future entitlements'.

The coalition obviously supports the social security income test and a system of waiting period exemptions that provide the unemployed with a greater incentive to undertake part-time and casual work. Far too frequently in this country we hear people claiming that it is pointless working because they can do as well from being on the dole. Such an attitude should not be tolerated or encouraged; nor should a social security system engender that attitude. It is a fact of life under the economic policies of this Government that neither the public nor the private sector is able to generate anywhere near enough full-time jobs to overcome our massive jobless problem. It is also a fact, for a variety of reasons, not least the huge costs entailed in employing people on a full-time basis, that many employers are relying more and more on part-time and casual employees. The coalition believes that if someone who would otherwise be unemployed, can obtain work on a part time or casual basis, he or she should not be disadvantaged for doing so by the social security income test or any waiting period.

On the contrary, unemployed people should be actively encouraged to maintain links with both the paid and the unpaid work forces because such links are often vital to their later full-time, paid employment prospects, opportunities for references and other things that we all understand people need if they go into full-time employment, as well as the importance it has for their own self-esteem. For this reason, the coalition is supporting both of these initiatives.

It must also be stressed that part-time and casual work, whilst important, particularly for women, is not the panacea to our jobless problem. The massive underemployment rates we have witnessed over the last three years show that hundreds of thousands of people who are now working part-time or in casual employment would like to work more hours a week. The Government should not forget that the vast majority of people still want full-time work and they are entitled to get it.

The third Government promise contained in this Bill is the lowering of the pension withdrawal rate for pensioners with assets about the assets test threshold for the full-rate pension. Currently, the pension is reduced by $26 per year for every $250 of excess assets about the full-rate assets threshold.

Under these new provisions, commencing on 20 September, a person's pension will be reduced by $19.50 per year for every $250 of excess assets. This is a 25 per cent reduction in the assets test withdrawal rate.

Lowering the assets test withdrawal rate means that some current pensioners will be eligible for higher part-pensions, while others who previously were not eligible for any pension will become eligible for a part-pension. The department estimates that another 8,400 non-pensioner retirees and 1,300 other people will be eligible for the pension for the first time as a result of this initiative. A further 39,100 current pensioners will get an increase in their part-pension.

The coalition supports this initiative because, to an extent, it belatedly addresses the financial problems faced by retirees on very low fixed incomes who are disqualified from the pension due to the assets test. These retirees have received very little assistance from the current Government over the last three years, while their fixed incomes have dropped drastically due to falling interest rates. They continue to pay tax on any income they earn above $5,400 a year while pensioners with higher net incomes enjoy the benefits of the pensioner rebate. They continue to be ineligible for a wide range of fringe benefits that are valued at an estimated $1,500 per annum. If some of these retirees become eligible for the pension for the first time as a result of this initiative, the coalition certainly does not begrudge them that.

However, a word of warning for these first time pensioners. It is now obvious that the Government has hopelessly under-funded its fringe benefits extension promise. At this stage, it is totally up in the air whether this extension will be able to continue beyond 30 June this year. A further increase in the pensioner population as a result of a lower assets test withdrawal rate will put even more financial pressure on this government promise. It would be appreciated if the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) could put pensioners at ease by committing his Government to continuing to provide 100 per cent compensation to the States beyond 30 June for this fringe benefits extension.

While we welcome this initiative, the opportunity cannot pass without highlighting the Government's proposed inequitable treatment of unrealised capital gains on shares compared with other pensioner investments. Take an example of two pensioners with equal income and assets. Both exceed the income and assets test full-pension thresholds. One of these pensioners has an investment in real estate, the other has an investment in shares. Both investments make an unrealised capital gain of $5,000 over a 12-month period. In neither case does the unrealised gain take the pensioner over the income or assets test part-pension threshold.

The pensioner with the real estate suffers a reduction in pension of $390 a year as a result of a reassessment under the new pensioner assets test. In practice, this is probably a worst case scenario because a pensioner in this situation is likely not to be reassessed under the assets test at all. However, the pensioner with $5,000 unrealised capital gain on his share portfolio suffers a pension reduction of $2,500 a year. This is because, as the legislation currently stands, as at September his unrealised capital gain will be treated as income under the pensioner income test. As he is over the full-pension income threshold, 50c in every dollar of this $5,000 unrealised capital gain is taken out of his or her pension. And the Minister has the gall to claim that treating unrealised capital gains on shares as income will mean a more equitable means testing system.

This is just one of the numerous inequities, anomalies and poverty traps in the current social security incomes and assets test system that resulted in the coalition committing itself in Fightback to a thorough review of the current means testing procedures for pensioners. Whilst it is a beneficial initiative, lowering the assets test withdrawal rate is really just another example of the Government tinkering at the edges but not having the courage to foster a comprehensive and open debate on pensioner means testing.

In the interests of reasoned decision making, I am sure the Minister would assist my colleagues and me by informing the Senate how the Government settled upon the $19.50 withdrawal rate figure. I foreshadow that the Opposition will be moving a second reading amendment condemning the Government for its failure to address the special needs of the unemployed and the aged. I also foreshadow that in the committee stage I will be moving an amendment which will, in essence, repeat the amendment I put forward in the private member's Bill last week, which was supported by the Democrats.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Amendment Bill and the Veterans Affairs' Legislation Amendment Bill before us tonight will not be opposed by the Australian Democrats. They contain positive measures, which we welcome. In fact, we have been calling for the introduction of some of these measures for quite a considerable time. The actions that are now being taken by the Government certainly vindicate our stance.

PARA.TAB: In particular, we welcome the move in the Social Security Amendment Bill 1993 to permit single people receiving the jobstart, newstart or sickness allowances to earn an additional $30 a fortnight from employment before their payment is affected. The Democrats have been calling for increases in these three areas across a range of pensions for quite some time. The inadequacy of these areas has been a major barrier to part-time and casual employment. It is extremely important that those who are unemployed have the option, if it presents itself, to take up part-time and casual work to keep their skills and their self-esteem, as well as to earn those additional few dollars.

The Democrats are very pleased tonight to see that the Government has finally taken some action on this matter. It is really disgraceful that it has taken so long to do something about it because virtually every welfare and charitable organisation in this country has been calling for this measure as well. The Democrats have been telling the Government for the past three years that this needed to be done but until now the Government has done absolutely nothing.

The Democrats also welcome the new provisions which mean that people claiming jobsearch, newstart and sickness allowances will not have to serve the ordinary one-week waiting period if they have been in receipt of income support within the previous 13 weeks. Again this is a long overdue and welcome measure. For years unemployed people have been discouraged from taking on short-term employment because they cannot afford the loss of income involved in going through yet another waiting period at the end of the job. I do not know how many times I have stood up in here and called on the Government to do something about waiting periods. It has been blatantly obvious, and apparent to everybody except the Government, that waiting periods are a major contributor to hardship. The Salvation Army, St Vincent De Paul or Adelaide Central Mission will all state that many people they support are in fact eligible for social security payments but are serving some sort of waiting period or other.

Instead of moving to reduce or abolish waiting periods, in recent years this Government has actually increased waiting periods and dreamed up a few new ones to introduce. Time and time again I have sat in this chamber and listened to the Government trying to justify its refusal to reduce waiting periods. There has certainly been a wide variety of excuses. Meanwhile, unemployed Australians and their families have continued to suffer. So I say a rather belated congratulations of sorts to the Government for finally waking up and taking some action.

The Democrats will be moving amendments to abolish another waiting period, the 12-week wait for those unemployed persons who allegedly reduce their employment prospects by moving to a different area, although we will be doing this without much hope. We have tried to do so before and have not been successful, but we do want to make the point again that this is yet another major hole in our social security net through which many people fall. It means that people cannot travel to look for work and take the risks. It means that people, particularly those who have been long-term unemployed, cannot take options in rural parts of Australia for cheaper housing. In my State in particular I emphasise moving to places such as Millicent where housing trust accommodation is often available.

The rule makes it extremely difficult for DSS to deal constructively with unemployed people who are highly mobile. It also makes it virtually impossible for unemployed people, especially those with families, to move to areas where living costs such as housing are cheaper but, by the Government's definition, unemployment prospects might be slightly worse.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AMENDMENT BILL 1993VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact is that the labour market has deteriorated considerably since the introduction of this rule and it is no longer appropriate, if it were ever appropriate, for this rule to be in place. Senator Bolkus indicated to the Senate late last year that DSS and DEET were going to have another look at this reduced employment prospects rule and that the Government was going to report back around April. I take this opportunity to ask the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson): at what stage is that report? When will we be seeing it? If we could have a look at it before the Budget session it would certainly help us to see what the Government is thinking.

PARA.TAB: I turn briefly to the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1993. Again, the Democrats support this piece of legislation. We are pleased to see the reduction in the assets test withdrawal rate. We also support the extension of coverage under the Veterans' Affairs Entitlements Act to members of our defence forces who are serving with the United Nations forces in Somalia, the former Yugoslavia, and Cambodia. If we are going to continue to contribute to international peacekeeping efforts, it is only fair and just that we recognise the contributions of those who serve in these very dangerous and certainly highly unpredictable circumstances. I believe that it is something all Australians would agree with.

I turn to the other amendments the Democrats will be moving tonight. They relate to the issue of pensioner shares. These amendments represent a continuation of the Democrats' efforts to reverse a decision made by the Government last year to treat as income the unrealised capital gain on listed shares for the purpose of income tax for pensioners.

Last week both the Democrats and the Opposition introduced Bills designed to achieve this end. We ended up supporting Senator Patterson's Bill. Our amendments today use the Bill that was passed, as it is that wording that this House has already accepted. Therefore we will move our amendments tonight in the hope that they will be supported.

Obviously, with any private senator's Bill there is a problem. It can get through the Senate quite easily—and perhaps not so easily, but at least it can get through—to go nowhere, to sit on the Notice Paper in the other place and gather dust for months.

TALK.START.PARA: —For ever!

—Yes, perhaps for ever and ever and never actually see the light of day and certainly never get to the point where it is on the Notice Paper and is debated. Therefore tonight we will move amendments designed to ensure that the House of Representatives has a further opportunity to review the Bill. The House will actually have to vote on the amendments when the Bill gets back there.

PARA.TAB: I know that the Government is going to say all sorts of things about threats to the legislation and the sorts of games that were played last year, but that certainly will not dissuade us from moving these amendments tonight. These amendments give government members in the House of Representatives a chance to look again at this proposal, not just to take the department's word or the Minister's word for what is going on, but actually to look at the measure for themselves. It will also give those people in the community a chance for a week or so at least to put further pressure on the Government, and I am quite happy to say that one of the Democrats' aims is to actually keep pressuring the Labor Government until it does something about this matter.

The Bill is demonstrably unfair and inequitable and we, the Democrats, are entitled to use every possible means to see this matter resolved. If the Senate amends the Bill along the lines of our amendments and the House of Representatives rejects it, obviously the Senate will deal with it again. But I hope we would not get to the stage where that happens. We will not be bullied by the Government; we will not be threatened by the Government. We will proceed with our amendments tonight. The Senate has had a chance to look at this Bill. Many members of the House of Representatives have never seen it. There are a number of new members in the House of Representatives and they should have the opportunity to look at this legislation again—and, for some, to look at it for the first time.

I do not think there is any shortage of reasons that the Minister could give for not accepting our amendments, but we will not be moved on this issue. I look forward to some of the Minister's comments. If I look at some of the excuses he gave last time, we should have some interesting discussions in the committee stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1993, which was introduced into the other place on 5 May. The Bill was guillotined and passed in a few minutes on 12 May with the usual respect for the democratic process for which the Labor Party is so well known.

PARA.TAB: This piece of legislation is not controversial. I do not intend to take too much time tonight speaking about it. The Opposition supports this Bill. Briefly, we are pleased that the Government has consulted with the interest groups—namely, those in the veteran community—on the matter of pensions and benefits on this occasion. We contrast that with its behaviour last year in relation to the so-called Bushell legislation amendment of the Veterans' Entitlement Act where there was simply no consultation.

One interesting thing at present in the Department of Veterans' Affairs is audit report No. 8, which deals with aspects of compensation for veterans. I hope the Government honours the undertakings that it has given to consult fully with the veterans organisations in Australia on this matter and has a full consultation with them before it comes to any decision on the implementation of the report. It is a very controversial report because, rightly or wrongly, large numbers of veterans feel that their entitlements will either be reduced or even disappear as a consequence of the Auditor-General's report.

This Bill implements an election promise of the Government to reduce the assets test withdrawal rate from $104 to $78 per annum for each $1,000 above the assets test threshold. As the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Faulkner) explained, the level of assets a person who is a home owner will now be able to have before a service pension ceases to be payable will increase by $26,500 for a single pensioner and $22,000 for a pensioner couple. The Government has estimated that about 2,500 veterans and their spouses will become eligible for a service pension as a result of this increase in the level of assets. Those qualifying under this change to the assets test withdrawal rate will receive a pension of about $25 per fortnight. Currently, almost 9,000 service pensioners receive the pension at the reduced rate because of their assets.

In December last year, the Government passed legislation to deal with unrealised capital gains on shares and listed securities. I have moved a private member's Bill to rescind that legislation. In concert with that tonight, I give notice that in the committee stage of the Bill I will be moving the amendments circulated in the name of the Opposition that will amend the provisions of the Act which apply the unrealised capital gains on shares and listed securities.

The rest of the Bill deals with the extension of benefits under the Veterans' Entitlement Act to those members of the ADF who served in Yugoslavia and Somalia who are either back in Australia or who are coming back in the near future. The Australian service personnel in Cambodia have already been covered, but extension is now made to those who served within 50 kilometres of the border of Cambodia in either Laos or Cambodia.

These changes and designations mean that the ADF personnel involved will now have an entitlement to things such as service pensions, home loan assistance and a more generous standard of proof being used in determining their entitlements with respect to incapacity or death. The Opposition supports the extension of those entitlements to members of the ADF who served in peacekeeping units. It is fair that that be done on the basis of equity.

This is the first opportunity I have had to say something about the Australian contingent serving in Somalia. I was fortunate enough to be able to visit Somalia in April per courtesy of the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray. I thank him very much for that generous invitation and for the facilities he made available to me and three other parliamentarians during our visit to the Australian contingent.

The comments I will make relate principally to the 1st Battalion Royal Australian Regiment of the Army and its associated personnel, who made up the great bulk of the Australian contingent in Somalia. But they also cover the movement control officers, who did a marvellous job at Mogadishu basically as RTOs for the UN contingent passing through the airport and the port; the Royal Australian Navy personnel, principally those on HMAS Tobruk, who have been in the area of operations for the whole of the deployment; and the RAAF personnel, who maintained the courier service that kept the units there supplied.

But most of my comments relate to the battalion. Firstly, the contingent we had posted there was very well trained with very high professional standards. They were very well led by good officers and good NCOs. They were also very well disciplined. One element of that discipline shows in the fact that they drove for many miles—to the best of my knowledge, in excess of half a million kilometres—over very bad roads and remained accident free. There was an accident with an APC in Baidoa, where there was mechanical failure of the track, one of the drive shafts or something, but for the road operations it really was a marvellous record. All the troops were dedicated with very high morale. During my time there, I observed them going about their duties with unfailing enthusiasm.

Somalia itself is a very isolated, tough and harsh country. It reminded me of western Queensland in a bad drought. It is very hot and dusty for most of the time and when the monsoon comes, as it does twice a year in that area, all that dust turns to clay like a black soil plain in central Queensland—although it is red soil there. The conditions that the Army served under were really very harsh.

Sailors and airmen often have sheets on their beds when they are in the field and they have many of the amenities of civilisation when they are on operational postings. Soldiers from time immemorial have lived very close to the earth, and the Australian troops in Somalia were no exception. They had good drinking water from their own resources, they had food and they had transport. But apart from that, they lived as hard as the Somalis themselves did. There were certainly no cool drinks, cool beers or anything like that. Their rations consisted of MREs which we bought from the American forces and ration packs from the Australian Army. There was very little fresh food in the field.

The Australian troops worked seven days a week, and the battalion's companies were out on rotation in various parts of the province for three or four days at a time, rotating back through the headquarters. There was no relaxation of the tension under which they were operating. When they were in camp they were behind barbed wire, and at all times they carried their weapons and magazines. The moment they went outside the camp area everyone wore flak jackets, there was a round in the breach, and they were at full alert for the whole time. Those conditions might not sound harsh, but I can tell the Senate that if one lives that way for a period of months on end without ever relaxing, the cumulative stress is really quite considerable. Given the harshness of the conditions, the troops' morale and enthusiasm which I witnessed 17 weeks into their deployment was quite remarkable.

The main purpose of the troops when they first went to Somalia was to control the lawlessness in the countryside. It was almost like a movie of the wild west. There does not seem to be much sense of nationalism in Somalia. There seems to be a very strong tribal system. There was tribal warfare, with the warlords, the head of each tribe, using the armoured utilities and other such vehicles mounted with heavy machine-guns or recoilless rifles to run around literally shooting up everything in sight. There was individual banditry to a very high degree. That had to be suppressed and was suppressed by the Australian contingent when it went into Somalia because, until that lawlessness was dispelled, it was quite impossible to have food convoys moving through the area.

When the Australian contingent moved into Baidoa in excess of 300 dead bodies a day lay in the streets just as a consequence of the famine and starvation. The first duty of the Australian contingent was to bring law and order into the community, and it did that very well. It did that in the traditional Australian way of very active patrolling. One of the traditions and great strengths of the Australian Army is the fact that it has always been a great patrol master.

Going out on patrol in those areas, as it did constantly and relentlessly, is not without its risk. The surprising thing was that a large number of Australian soldiers learnt Somali so that they could converse with the locals. It is the sort of community where people aggregate in great crowds and the nature of the Somali dress is such that it is quite possible to conceal automatic weapons under the cloaks that so many of the men wear. The troops never knew when they came up to a crowd whether they were dealing with people who were armed and intending to take action. The Australian troops coped with that particularly well. They exercised very high levels of discipline and great restraint in apprehending armed personnel, and I think that is reflected in the very few times that they had to actually discharge weapons against any of the lawless members of the community.

Associated with this active patrolling right from the outset in all parts of the province was a very active program of involvement in community affairs. The troops talked to the village elders—they talked to everyone—and mixed with the Somalis wherever possible and befriended them, and that really paid off. We had a large number of meetings with as many village elders as possible. We met with the marine commander from the American force, of which the Australian contingent was a part, and General Bir, the Turkish UN commander for the whole force, and they were all fulsome in their praise for the Australian troops.

But the real test for me was driving around the area. We did a great deal of driving around the area. Everywhere we went the Somalis cheered, clapped or waved at us. Given the dreadful terror that has reigned in that country in recent years, if the Australian troops had not been doing a very good job and if that had not been known and appreciated by the Somalis, they would have looked the other way, thrown rocks or done something like that. But everywhere we went and at all times we met this spontaneous applause from the Somalis. We were always travelling with a fully armed platoon, three trucks and a radio jeep, and every time we stopped a crowd would form and in a short time we would have several hundred friendly people around us. We can be very proud of the achievements of the Australian contingent in Somalia. It fulfilled the expectations of this Parliament when we made a contribution to the United Nations force in Somalia and it fully deserves the provisions of this Bill being applied to its members. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—There is not much to answer from the contributions made by the previous speakers, given that they have all supported this legislation. I will not belabour the point by repeating all they have said about this legislation. We have all now learnt what it does. I will not press on with that nor will I proceed to repeat all the comments that I made last week in opposing—I thought quite well—Senator Patterson's Bill, which was supported by the Australian Democrats.

PARA.TAB: Now we have got both of them proposing to move the same amendments to this legislation. I am not quite certain who will get a guernsey first, but the Government will maintain the stance that it took last week and oppose those amendments, and we will divide on them. There is money at stake. At the outset of her contribution, Senator Patterson asked the question: where is the money coming from—the $70 million? There is $80 million they are trying to take off with the amendments, so that is where the money is coming from.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is fake! It is monopoly money.
—It is not monopoly money. It is a fact, a fact which Senator Patterson does not seek to acknowledge. I can understand why she would not.
—That is wrong.
—Do not get irritable. We can all get through this.

PARA.TAB: I would like to very briefly answer the comments of Senator Lees on the question of reduced employment prospects, and the rule that prevents people from moving into areas where those prospects are less. Obviously, there has always been the basic obligation on all recipients of those benefits to do their best to get employment. Obviously, if they move to an area where there just is not any employment, or there is less than the area in which they are in and they are significantly reducing their chances, it is reasonable for the Government to move to prevent that. While Senator Lees may have had complaints about the way that this provision may have operated, the truth is that many honourable senators have had the other complaint, coming from the other direction, that too many people have abused the system in the past and just sought to go to areas where there would be no prospect of gaining work. All of us would want to ensure that people genuinely seek work in accordance with the legislation as laid down.

Senator Lees referred to the review which the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, approved in October last year. That review is currently being conducted by DSS in consultation with other departments. It is a wide-ranging review and includes an examination of the appropriateness of this policy in times of an economic downturn. It is expected to be completed in June 1993, and the views of ACOSS and other welfare groups have been sought. I would assume that the problem of the April date has been the intervention of the election, which did interrupt business for all but a short time.

I hope that that explanation satisfies the concerns of Senator Lees. I am sure that in the first week or two when we come back in August we will be able to debate the results of the review. It is a matter of concern, and I know it is something she was complaining about when I was Minister for Social Security all those months ago. I would also like to acknowledge that a number of the measures in the legislation tonight were raised by her on occasions. Senator Lees said that we have taken too long to act. I think there is always a problem in acting quickly to simply take away all of the disincentives that people have. However, when we are responsible for managing the finances of the nation, we cannot take these steps lightly. We also have to balance the public concern on the whole issue of unemployment against the kinds of concerns she has been raising. Nonetheless, the Government is acknowledging tonight in a number of areas that there is room to move. In so far as the other question of reduced unemployment prospects is concerned, we are looking at that as well. At this time it may be appropriate to table a corrigendum to the Bill.

I understand that an Opposition amendment will be moved. I will make a couple of comments on it because it has been circulated, and I hope that the Senate does not take too long with the amendment tonight. The first point is that Senator Patterson and a number of her colleagues have painted themselves as the pensioners' friends here tonight. I wonder where they were when Fightback was being produced and when it pronounced that $1 billion would be taken out of the social security system.

Had the Opposition gained government, we would not be worried about the simple measures contained in this legislation tonight; we would be debating a whole series of cuts—a slashing of social security expenditure. Those opposite would cut the heart out of unemployment benefits, the pension and pension benefits. The word `heart' has been used often by the Liberals—but, I might say, only since 13 March. Before then it was a dirty word. I think Chris Puplick referred today to `their painted lips with the venom of a spitting cobra'. I am glad it is being mentioned. It is a good thing to see. But I think it would be a lot more credible if some of those opposite had fought that appalling decision in Fightback—one only one among many—to rip $1 billion out of the social security system.
For a start, the amendment to the motion that those opposite seek to move is pretty suspect given that sorry record. Point (b) of that amendment says:

SPEECH.PARA: the abandonment of the promise to remove pensioners from the taxation system by 1995;

It is pretty rich for those opposite to be telling us tonight that we ought to do things because pensioner groups and ACOSS are saying that we should. The truth is that pensioner groups and ACOSS have been lobbying against the move to remove pensioners from the tax system by 1995 because so many of them take the view that it will be a hindrance to equity. I think that is a legitimate argument to have and one that we ought to have over the course of the coming months. But, again, if the $1 billion cuts had been applied, none of these would have been a problem: everything would have gone.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition has made constant reference to the Government's failure to guarantee the extension of full Commonwealth fringe benefits to all long-term retirees beyond the remaining three months of the 1992-93 financial year. While it is cute to draw attention to it by this form of proposed amendment, as Senator Patterson would be aware, the matter is inevitably and properly bound up with discussions between the Commonwealth and the States. Any lack of guarantee of State concessions is due to the fact that the States have again wanted to review responsibility for concessions. That situation was reviewed in 1991-92 as part of the broader review of Commonwealth-State functional responsibilities, but the States want another crack at it only a year later. The difficulty for the Commonwealth, which must work with the States for the provision of fringe benefits—obviously we must, because a great many of them are dealt with directly by the States—is that it is impossible to simply ignore that kind of State request.

As Senator Patterson and, I am sure, most honourable senators are aware, a working party of Commonwealth and State officials is presently looking at the question of the options for ongoing funding of those concessions and who should be responsible for them. That review was undertaken at the request of the States, not the Commonwealth; it is not something that we sought, but it is happening. The Commonwealth holds the view, with some strength and passion, that all pensioners should have access to all Commonwealth and State concessions. All Commonwealth concessions are guaranteed and I sincerely hope that the States will negotiate to achieve an extension of their concessions too. The working party is due to report to the heads of government meeting in early June. I remain hopeful that there will be no problem. The Commonwealth is certainly not holding back; we are trying to urge the States forward but some of them are showing a degree of reluctance.

As a late-night stunt, and a pretty poor one at that, the Opposition's proposed amendment completely ignores the record of the Opposition, the authors of the amendment, which has been one of an ongoing, unhealthy disdain for the welfare of pensioners and unemployment beneficiaries. The Opposition sought to deal those people out of the system with its Fightback package—the package which the people of Australia so soundly and sensibly rejected just a few months ago. It shows that some people learn nothing from bitter experience. While that is disappointing, it does keep us all in business.
Amendment (by Senator Reid)—by leave—proposed:
At end of motion, add:", but the Senate noting:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)the comments of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training that the number of long-term unemployed would inevitably rise to between 400 000 and 500 000 in the next 12 to 18 months;
(b)the abandonment of the promise to remove pensioners from the taxation system by 1995;

(c)the Government's failure to guarantee the extension of full Commonwealth fringe benefits to all long-term retirees beyond the remaining three months of 1992-93, even though the Prime Minister made special mention of this `promise' in his campaign policy speech;

(d)the Government's failure to rule out major increases in taxation and to outline a planned program of expenditure reduction to enable responsible implementation of its campaign commitments in relation to social security matters;
(e)further changes and tampering with the assets test for pensioners, adding further confusion and insecurity to their retirement plans; and
(f)the need for a full and complete review of the inter-relationship between income and asset tests for better integration of the taxation and social security systems,
condemns the Government for its failure to address the special needs of the unemployed and the aged".

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the amendment moved by Senator Reid. The Australian Democrats do not have any great problem with the first two parts of the amendment. We must all acknowledge that the long-term unemployed are growing in number, as are those who are totally disillusioned and giving up the search for work. With respect to paragraph (b), as the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) has already noted, the Australian Democrats have some concerns about the removal of all pensioners from the taxation system, particularly in view of the Government's targeting. If we are to continue along that line, these people should not be in the system at all.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats have no great problem with paragraph (c) but we certainly have problems with (d). We have to acknowledge that our taxation system has problems. We have to acknowledge that, together with the United States, we are the second lowest taxed nation in the Western world. The only country in which workers pay significantly less tax is Turkey. On the smell of an oily rag, we are trying to run a health system, an education system, a social welfare system, and all the rest of it. If, as the Opposition is suggesting here, we make further cuts in expenditure, the people hit will be those who are already hit. In other words, the people who can already afford private education for their children will not be affected, but those who send their kids to state schools will be. People with enough money to afford private health care will not be hurt by cuts to health expenditure, but those people who rely on the public health system will be. The taxation cuts will help those people who, if they need to, can afford private insurance against injury or loss of income. The people who will be hurt by social security cuts are those who cannot afford it.

Paragraph (e) deals with further tampering with the assets test. The Australian Democrats see problems there. It has been an ongoing problem for pensioners who think they have their affairs settled but who have to face yet further tampering with the assets test. We would like to see greater changes. We do have some problems—we could debate this all night—with the fact that, at a time when people are making nothing, the family farm still remains within the assets test. In some cases they are trying to support three generations on the family farm.

The Australian Democrats do not have any problem with paragraph (f)—`the need for a full and complete regard of the inter-relationship between income and assets test'. The Government has put the whole package to us tonight for a yes or no answer, and the Australian Democrats' answer will be no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage of the night there is no merit in debating this question at length. It would have been preferable to have a provision that recognised the importance of ensuring that people are able to retain as much of their own income as possible. The tax mix in Australia is skewed to disadvantage income earners, and particularly pay-as-you-earn taxpayers. The Government has not given sufficient consideration to other aspects of tax, including the question of land and resources.
—What about inheritance?

—That is another aspect. For example, I would like to see the development of a loan scheme against estates. People who are rather well off assets-wise and income-wise could have a loan scheme applied against their estates. I would like to develop that aspect at some stage. I am opposed to the current unjust system which taxes the income of families without regard to the number of dependents on that income. That is where the injustice lies. This should be considered in the Social Security Amendment Bill because the Government is taxing families substantially, and then dribbling some of the money back through the social security system. It is demeaning, it is degrading, it is unfair and it is unjust.

PARA.TAB: I feel that it would have been of benefit to go into this amendment. The only opportunity I have had to read this is in the last hour. Because of the time and because it is merely a second reading amendment and will not affect the legislation, I do not propose to vote for it.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: SOCIAL SECURITY AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take up much of the time of the Committee because we have already been through the reasons why the coalition is moving this amendment to the Social Security Amendment Bill. In essence, it is the private member's Bill which I moved last week and which was supported by the Australian Democrats. It reviewed the situation which the Government had introduced at the end of last year which meant that unrealised capital gains of pensioners would be treated as income.

PARA.TAB: This was an issue that we were concerned about at the time when the Bill went through but it was linked to another series of benefits for pensioners. We said at that time that we would be reviewing it, and in fact we moved a private member's Bill to address that concern.

As Senator Lees has said, private members' Bills do not have a happy history in this place. They go to the lower house and sit there. I think there is just over a handful of private members' Bills that have ever been passed. So I was under no illusion that it would get through, but it was an expression of the concern of the coalition and of the Democrats about this measure. Tonight we are moving in essence that Bill as an amendment to this Bill to force the Government to address the issue and to rectify this inequity. I move:
After clause 3, page 2, insert the following Part:
"3A. Section 3 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting the following entry from the Index:
"3B. Section 9 of the Principal Act is amended:

TAB.TAB: (a)by omitting the definition of "investment product" in subsection (1) and substituting the following definition:
"`investment product' in relation to a managed investment, means all the investments that are:
(a)with the same body corporate or in the same trust fund; and
(b)subject to substantially the same terms and conditions as the managed investment;";
(b)by omitting the definition of "listed security" in subsection (1).

TAB.EMPHASIS: Heading to Subdivision AA of Division 1 of Part 3.10

PARA.TAB: "3C. The heading to Subdivision AA of Division 1 of Part 3.10 is amended by omitting "and listed securities".
"3D. Section 1073 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting from the table "STRUCTURE OF DIVISION" the following figures and words:
"4. Shares and other listed securities1084—1089".
"3E. Section 1074A of the Principal Act is amended by omitting subsection (2).".

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be supporting this amendment to the Social Security Amendment Bill as it is identical to the amendment that was circulated earlier today. If I could take issue with one of the matters raised by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) last time we discussed this matter in this place, he noted that there was a difference now of some 20-odd thousand pensioners between those that were officially recognised as having listed shares and those that now have them.

PARA.TAB: May I suggest to the Minister that from the information supplied to me by pensioners it is not that pensioners have gone out and purchased shares but rather, because of what the Government has done in relation to additional benefits, that people who have small pension entitlements and happen to have shares have indeed joined the pensioner group, if you like, and become pensioners in order to get those additional entitlements. So it is not simply a matter of additional people purchasing shares but rather the other way around. People who have had share portfolios and maybe were only entitled to a few dollars a week pension have decided that in order to get the fringe benefits it is worth while their becoming part-pensioners. That is the information I have from some pensioners.

I support the amendment and say that it is now well over 100,000 people who will be affected. While some of them, in effect, may not have their pensions cut, particularly in the short term, the threat of the possibility of losing pension is sufficient for many of them to be certainly rethinking. Some of them have put their decisions on hold for the moment. But we do not want a situation where people are dissuaded in any way from investing in Australian companies; nor do we want a situation where we have pensioners without anything in hand whatsoever losing income. I do not think we need to say any more at the moment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not acknowledge Senator MacGibbon earlier on, but I will certainly pass on his thanks to Senator Ray for sending him to Mogadishu. I am not sure I would have been as fulsome in thanking him had he sent me, but I will make sure I thank him for sending Senator MacGibbon.

PARA.TAB: What Senator Lees has said is, in part, true: there is no question that some of those who have come onto part pension have held shares and that that has pushed the numbers up. The figures illustrated, however, that there had been no wholesale selling of shares by pensioners. That is the point I was making at the time, and I still believe that to be the case. I do not really think we are at cross-purposes, but I guess it is a matter of what happens from here. No doubt it is something we will monitor and debate at another time. So far as I am concerned, it is not germane to the argument. Obviously the Government is opposed to this amendment, and we shall seek to divide on it. I do not think it is worth making the same speech as we made last week.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Patterson's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: 2.After clause 12, page 6, insert the following clause:

TAB.EMPHASIS: Abolition of reduced employment prospects rule

PARA.TAB: "12A. Sections 518, 550, 597 and 634 of the Principal Act are repealed.".

SPEECH.PARA: Our first amendment is the same as the one that was just passed and which stood in the name of Senator Patterson. This amendment deals directly with the abolition of the reduced employment prospects rule. As I said in an earlier speech, this is one of the major problems with the Social Security Act as it now stands. The Minister for Health (Senator Richardson), who represents the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin), says that people are somehow going to reduce their chances of employment by moving. I suggest that he look at the boards at the CES in Adelaide and he will realise that people have virtually a zero chance in many occupations as it is, particularly men in their 40s and 50s.

PARA.TAB: One thing the unemployed can at least do is go to rural areas in Australia, look for casual employment and take opportunities that arise for cheaper housing. But if they take those options and move their families, they face a 12-week wait for social security benefits. I believe that, as the Minister said, it is a measure which the Government is looking at. But the Government needs to do far more than just look at it. Therefore, tonight we are again bringing this issue to the attention of the Senate.
Amendment negatived.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 30 March 1993:

PARA.TAB: Could a shell copy of each letter sent by the department at any time during the past three years to the department's clients advising of a change in entitlement due to a policy change or due to indexation please be forwarded; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Department is not able to provide shells of letters for every rate change which resulted from policy change or indexation over the last three years.

Most of the Department's letters are constructed individually from a range of approved paragraphs. For example, there are around 2,500 paragraphs maintained for letters produced by the pensions system, 1,500 in the Newstart system and 1,000 in the Families system. The system only holds those paragraphs which are current. As events change, the paragraphs are changed. Older versions are not kept on the system.

Recipients of Job Search or Newstart Allowance are not sent a specific letter when the rate of payment increases due to indexation. The new rate is shown on the income statement sent to clients each fortnight.

Before releasing new letters into production, test copies are produced to check the operation of the system. A range of test letters are retained on file and copies of these letters will be provided to the honourable senator. These represent the types of letters issued to clients.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Foreign Affairs and Trade: Media Releases

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 30 March 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the department routinely disseminate or circulate all or some of the media releases of its responsible Minister or Ministers, to organisations apart from national media organisations; if so, for what reasons are Ministerial media releases circulated by the department and to how many individuals or organisations.

(2) For each, and which, Ministerial media release circulated in the past 18 months, what was the estimated cost of printing and circulating the releases and how many copies of the release were circulated.

(3) Does the department circulate copies of some or all of the speeches made by the Minister: if so, for each of those circulated in the past 18 months, what was the estimated cost of printing and circulating the speech and how many copies of the speech were circulated.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. The department routinely distributes Ministerial media releases to a wide range of individuals and organisations in addition to national media organisations. It does so in response to public interest in the substance of a particular release and in support of the Government's policy to encourage a wider public understanding and discussion of foreign and trade policies issues generally. The extent of distribution varies according to the level of interest in a particular release, but a typical release would be sent to as many as 112 individuals and organisations, including, for example, to foreign diplomatic and consular missions in Australia, representatives of the foreign press based outside Canberra, business and academic enquirers.

(2) The estimated cost of printing and circulating a typical Ministerial media release in the past 18 months (for example, release No. M32 of 15 February 1993) was $125. The department circulated 474 copies of that release. In the past 18 months the department issued 337 media releases.

(3) Yes. Ministerial speeches are circulated both as media releases and in collated form in a quarterly series. The estimated total cost of printing and distributing a typical speech in the quarterly collated form was $90; as a media release, $265. There were 145 copies circulated in the quarterly form and 474 copies circulated in media release form.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 11 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to an answer to a question without notice asked by Senator Tierney (Senate Hansard, 8 October 1992, p1429) which states that `The [evaluation] panel had many problems with the University Partnerships proposals. . . but encouraged them to talk with Monash University to see if they could resolve some of the differences between consortium partners in the interest of achieving the best possible national result':

(1) Is the Minister referring to `consortium partners' within the Monash-led consortium, or is the Minister suggesting that `consortium partners' means the University Partnerships (UP) bid and the Monash-led bid; if so, does this mean that the UP bid had already been rejected; if not, does this mean that the panel expected the two rival bids to offer a joint proposal; and (b) if the panel expected a joint proposal, in what form was this expectation conveyed to the rival consortiums.
(2) Did the original bid from the Monash consortium propose that Monash University have absolute control over the Open Learning Initiative.
(3) When did Monash University agree to the current proposed composition of the nine member board of the Open Learning Initiative.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The evaluation panel was advised that on the final day for lodgement of expressions of interest, a number of universities which had been involved in the Monash University bid asked University Partnerships Pty Ltd to put forward a separate bid on their behalf. The panel was advised that this action was taken because some differences of view had developed among the parties. The panel took the view that as a number of universities were members of both bids, it should provide representatives of the two bids, submitted by University Partnerships Pty Ltd and Monash University, with the opportunity to resolve the differences of views that had emerged. The panel therefore separately

ANSWER.PARA: suggested to representatives of each of the two bids that they hold further discussions.

PARA.TAB: In the event the panel was advised that they were not able to resolve all of their differences of views and no further consideration was given to the possibility of a single proposal.

(3) Monash University accepted a conditional invitation to establish the Open Learning Initiative on 23 September 1992. At that time, Monash proposed to increase the number of board members from nine, as proposed in the conditional invitation, to eleven in order to increase the number of universities represented to five (including Monash). That proposal was formalised in the agreement between the Commonwealth and the Open Learning Agency of Australia Pty Ltd signed on 18 January 1993.
